column1: R (Programming) |Computer programming (often shortened to programming) is a process that leads from an original formulation of a computing problem to executable computer programs. Programming involves activities such as analysis
column2: developing understanding
column3: generating algorithms
column4: verification of requirements of algorithms including their correctness and resources consumption
column5: and implementation (commonly referred to as coding) of algorithms in a target programming language. Source code is written in one or more programming languages. The purpose of programming is to find a sequence of instructions that will automate performing a specific task or solving a given problem. The process of programming thus often requires expertise in many different subjects
column6: including knowledge of the application domain
column7: specialized algorithms and formal logic.Related tasks include testing
column8: debugging
column9: and maintaining the source code
column10: implementation of the build system
column11: and management of derived artifacts such as machine code of computer programs. These might be considered part of the programming process
column12: but often the term software development is used for this larger process with the term programming
column13: implementation
column14: or coding reserved for the actual writing of source code. Software engineering combines engineering techniques with software development practices.|

column1: time-series |A time series is a series of data points indexed (or listed or graphed) in time order. Most commonly
column2: a time series is a sequence taken at successive equally spaced points in time. Thus it is a sequence of discrete-time data. Examples of time series are heights of ocean tides
column3: counts of sunspots
column4: and the daily closing value of the Dow Jones Industrial Average.Time series are very frequently plotted via line charts. Time series are used in statistics
column5: signal processing
column6: pattern recognition
column7: econometrics
column8: mathematical finance
column9: weather forecasting
column10: intelligent transport and trajectory forecasting
column11: earthquake prediction
column12: electroencephalography
column13: control engineering
column14: astronomy
column15: communications engineering
column16: and largely in any domain of applied science and engineering which involves temporal measurements.Time series analysis comprises methods for analyzing time series data in order to extract meaningful statistics and other characteristics of the data. Time series forecasting is the use of a model to predict future values based on previously observed values. While regression analysis is often employed in such a way as to test theories that the current values of one or more independent time series affect the current value of another time series
column17: this type of analysis of time series is not called "time series analysis"
column18: which focuses on comparing values of a single time series or multiple dependent time series at different points in time.Time series data have a natural temporal ordering. This makes time series analysis distinct from cross-sectional studies
column19: in which there is no natural ordering of the observations (e.g. explaining people's wages by reference to their respective education levels
column20: where the individuals' data could be entered in any order). Time series analysis is also distinct from spatial data analysis where the observations typically relate to geographical locations (e.g. accounting for house prices by the location as well as the intrinsic characteristics of the houses). A stochastic model for a time series will generally reflect the fact that observations close together in time will be more closely related than observations further apart. In addition
column21: time series models will often make use of the natural one-way ordering of time so that values for a given period will be expressed as deriving in some way from past values
column22: rather than from future values (see time reversibility.)Time series analysis can be applied to real-valued
column23: continuous data
column24: discrete numeric data
column25: or discrete symbolic data (i.e. sequences of characters
column26: such as letters and words in the English language).|

column1: probability |Probability is the measure of the likelihood that an event will occur. Probability is quantified as a number between 0 and 1 (where 0 indicates impossibility and 1 indicates certainty). The higher the probability of an event
column2: the more certain that the event will occur. A simple example is the tossing of a fair (unbiased) coin. Since the coin is unbiased
column3: the two outcomes ("head" and "tail") are both equally probable; the probability of "head" equals the probability of "tail." Since no other outcomes are possible
column4: the probability is 1/2 (or 50%)
column5: of either "head" or "tail". In other words
column6: the probability of "head" is 1 out of 2 outcomes and the probability of "tail" is also 1 out of 2 outcomes
column7: expressed as 0.5 when converted to decimal
column8: with the above-mentioned quantification system. This type of probability is also called a priori probability.These concepts have been given an axiomatic mathematical formalization in probability theory
column9: which is used widely in such areas of study as mathematics
column10: statistics
column11: finance
column12: gambling
column13: science (in particular physics)
column14: artificial intelligence/machine learning
column15: computer science
column16: game theory
column17: and philosophy to
column18: for example
column19: draw inferences about the expected frequency of events. Probability theory is also used to describe the underlying mechanics and regularities of complex systems.|

column1: classification |Classification is a general process related to categorization
column2: the process in which ideas and objects are recognized
column3: differentiated
column4: and understood.A classification system is an approach to accomplishing classification.Classification may refer specifically to:|

column1: anova |Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a collection of statistical models used to analyze the differences among group means and their associated procedures (such as "variation" among and between groups)
column2: developed by statistician and evolutionary biologist Ronald Fisher. In the ANOVA setting
column3: the observed variance in a particular variable is partitioned into components attributable to different sources of variation. In its simplest form
column4: ANOVA provides a statistical test of whether or not the means of several groups are equal
column5: and therefore generalizes the t-test to more than two groups. ANOVAs are useful for comparing (testing) three or more means (groups or variables) for statistical significance. It is conceptually similar to multiple two-sample t-tests
column6: but is more conservative (results in less type I error) and is therefore suited to a wide range of practical problems.|

column1: mixed-model |A mixed model is a statistical model containing both fixed effects and random effects. These models are useful in a wide variety of disciplines in the physical
column2: biological and social sciences. They are particularly useful in settings where repeated measurements are made on the same statistical units (longitudinal study)
column3: or where measurements are made on clusters of related statistical units. Because of their advantage in dealing with missing values
column4: mixed effects models are often preferred over more traditional approaches such as repeated measures ANOVA.|

column2: a confidence interval (CI) is a type of interval estimate of a population parameter. It is an observed interval (i.e.
column3: it is calculated from the observations)
column4: in principle different from sample to sample
column5: that frequently includes the value of an unobservable parameter of interest if the experiment is repeated. How frequently the observed interval contains the parameter is determined by the confidence level or confidence coefficient. More specifically
column6: the meaning of the term "confidence level" is that
column7: if CI are constructed across many separate data analyses of replicated experiments
column8: the proportion of such intervals that contain the true value of the parameter will match the given confidence level. Whereas two-sided confidence limits form a confidence interval
column9: their one-sided counterparts are referred to as lower/upper confidence bounds (or limits).Confidence intervals consist of a range of values (interval) that act as good estimates of the unknown population parameter. However
column10: the interval computed from a particular sample does not necessarily include the true value of the parameter. When we say
column11: "we are 99% confident that the true value of the parameter is in our confidence interval"
column12: we express that 99% of the hypothetically observed confidence intervals will hold the true value of the parameter. After any particular sample is taken
column13: the population parameter is either in the interval
column14: realized or not; it is not a matter of chance. The desired level of confidence is set by the researcher (not determined by data). If a corresponding hypothesis test is performed
column15: the confidence level is the complement of the level of significance
column16: i.e. a 95% confidence interval reflects a significance level of 0.05. The confidence interval contains the parameter values that
column17: when tested
column18: should not be rejected with the same sample. Confidence intervals of difference parameters not containing 0 imply that there is a statistically significant difference between the populations.In applied practice
column19: confidence intervals are typically stated at the 95% confidence level. However
column20: when presented graphically
column21: confidence intervals can be shown at several confidence levels
column22: for example 90%
column23: 95% and 99%.Certain factors may affect the confidence interval size including size of sample
column24: level of confidence
column25: and population variability. A larger sample size normally will lead to a better estimate of the population parameter.Confidence intervals were introduced to statistics by Jerzy Neyman in a paper published in 1937.|

column2: a categorical variable is a variable that can take on one of a limited
column3: and usually fixed
column4: number of possible values
column5: assigning each individual or other unit of observation to a particular group or nominal category on the basis of some qualitative property. In computer science and some branches of mathematics
column6: categorical variables are referred to as enumerations or enumerated types. Commonly (though not in this article)
column7: each of the possible values of a categorical variable is referred to as a level. The probability distribution associated with a random categorical variable is called a categorical distribution.Categorical data is the statistical data type consisting of categorical variables or of data that has been converted into that form
column8: for example as grouped data. More specifically
column9: categorical data may derive from either or both of observations made of qualitative data
column10: where the observations are summarised as counts or cross tabulations
column11: or of quantitative data
column12: where observations might be directly observed counts of events happening or might be counts of values that occur within given intervals. Often
column13: purely categorical data are summarised in the form of a contingency table. However
column14: particularly when considering data analysis
column15: it is common to use the term "categorical data" to apply to data sets that
column16: while containing some categorical variables
column17: may also contain non-categorical variables.A categorical variable that can take on exactly two values is termed a binary variable or dichotomous variable; an important special case is the Bernoulli variable. Categorical variables with more than two possible values are called polytomous variables; categorical variables are often assumed to be polytomous unless otherwise specified. Discretization is treating continuous data as if it were categorical. Dichotomization is treating continuous data or polytomous variables as if they were binary variables. Regression analysis often treats category membership as a quantitative dummy variable.|

column2: the generalized linear model (GLM) is a flexible generalization of ordinary linear regression that allows for response variables that have error distribution models other than a normal distribution. The GLM generalizes linear regression by allowing the linear model to be related to the response variable via a link function and by allowing the magnitude of the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value.Generalized linear models were formulated by John Nelder and Robert Wedderburn as a way of unifying various other statistical models
column3: including linear regression
column4: logistic regression and Poisson regression. They proposed an iteratively reweighted least squares method for maximum likelihood estimation of the model parameters. Maximum-likelihood estimation remains popular and is the default method on many statistical computing packages. Other approaches
column5: including Bayesian approaches and least squares fits to variance stabilized responses
column6: have been developed.|

column1: data-visualization |Data visualization or data visualisation is viewed by many disciplines as a modern equivalent of visual communication. It involves the creation and study of the visual representation of data
column2: meaning "information that has been abstracted in some schematic form
column3: including attributes or variables for the units of information".A primary goal of data visualization is to communicate information clearly and efficiently via statistical graphics
column4: plots and information graphics. Numerical data may be encoded using dots
column5: lines
column6: or bars
column7: to visually communicate a quantitative message. Effective visualization helps users analyze and reason about data and evidence. It makes complex data more accessible
column8: understandable and usable. Users may have particular analytical tasks
column9: such as making comparisons or understanding causality
column10: and the design principle of the graphic (i.e.
column11: showing comparisons or showing causality) follows the task. Tables are generally used where users will look up a specific measurement
column12: while charts of various types are used to show patterns or relationships in the data for one or more variables.Data visualization is both an art and a science. It is viewed as a branch of descriptive statistics by some
column13: but also as a grounded theory development tool by others. The rate at which data is generated has increased. Data created by internet activity and an expanding number of sensors in the environment
column14: such as satellites
column15: are referred to as "Big Data". Processing
column16: analyzing and communicating this data present a variety of ethical and analytical challenges for data visualization. The field of data science and practitioners called data scientists have emerged to help address this challenge.|

column1: t-test |A t-test is any statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student's t-distribution under the null hypothesis. It can be used to determine if two sets of data are significantly different from each other.A t-test is most commonly applied when the test statistic would follow a normal distribution if the value of a scaling term in the test statistic were known. When the scaling term is unknown and is replaced by an estimate based on the data
column2: the test statistics (under certain conditions) follow a Student's t distribution.|

column1: spss |SPSS Statistics is a software package used for statistical analysis. Long produced by SPSS Inc.
column2: it was acquired by IBM in 2009. The current versions (2015) are officially named IBM SPSS Statistics. Companion products in the same family are used for survey authoring and deployment (IBM SPSS Data Collection)
column3: data mining (IBM SPSS Modeler)
column4: text analytics
column5: and collaboration and deployment (batch and automated scoring services).The software name originally stood for Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS)
column6: reflecting the original market
column7: although the software is now popular in other fields as well
column8: including the health sciences and marketing.|

column2: maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) is a method of estimating the parameters of a statistical model given observations
column3: by finding the parameter values that maximize the likelihood of making the observations given the parameters. MLE can be seen as a special case of the maximum a posteriori estimation (MAP) that assumes a uniform prior distribution of the parameters
column4: or as a variant of the MAP that ignores the prior and which therefore is unregularized.The method of maximum likelihood corresponds to many well-known estimation methods in statistics. For example
column5: one may be interested in the heights of adult female penguins
column6: but be unable to measure the height of every single penguin in a population due to cost or time constraints. Assuming that the heights are normally distributed with some unknown mean and variance
column7: the mean and variance can be estimated with MLE while only knowing the heights of some sample of the overall population. MLE would accomplish this by taking the mean and variance as parameters and finding particular parametric values that make the observed results the most probable given the model.In general
column8: for a fixed set of data and underlying statistical model
column9: the method of maximum likelihood selects the set of values of the model parameters that maximizes the likelihood function. Intuitively
column10: this maximizes the "agreement" of the selected model with the observed data
column11: and for discrete random variables it indeed maximizes the probability of the observed data under the resulting distribution. Maximum likelihood estimation gives a unified approach to estimation
column12: which is well-defined in the case of the normal distribution and many other problems.|

column1: predictive-models |Predictive modeling uses statistics to predict outcomes. Most often the event one wants to predict is in the future
column2: but predictive modelling can be applied to any type of unknown event
column3: regardless of when it occurred. For example
column4: predictive models are often used to detect crimes and identify suspects
column5: after the crime has taken place.In many cases the model is chosen on the basis of detection theory to try to guess the probability of an outcome given a set amount of input data
column6: for example given an email determining how likely that it is spam.Models can use one or more classifiers in trying to determine the probability of a set of data belonging to another set
column7: say spam or 'ham'.Depending on definitional boundaries
column8: predictive modelling is synonymous with
column9: or largely overlapping with
column10: the field of machine learning
column11: as it is more commonly referred to in academic or research and development contexts. When deployed commercially
column12: predictive modelling is often referred to as predictive analytics.|

column1: multivariate-analysis |Multivariate analysis (MVA) is based on the statistical principle of multivariate statistics
column2: which involves observation and analysis of more than one statistical outcome variable at a time. In design and analysis
column3: the technique is used to perform trade studies across multiple dimensions while taking into account the effects of all variables on the responses of interest.Uses for multivariate analysis include:design for capability (also known as capability-based design)inverse design
column4: where any variable can be treated as an independent variableAnalysis of Alternatives (AoA)
column5: the selection of concepts to fulfil a customer needanalysis of concepts with respect to changing scenariosidentification of critical design-drivers and correlations across hierarchical levels.Multivariate analysis can be complicated by the desire to include physics-based analysis to calculate the effects of variables for a hierarchical "system-of-systems". Often
column6: studies that wish to use multivariate analysis are stalled by the dimensionality of the problem. These concerns are often eased through the use of surrogate models
column7: highly accurate approximations of the physics-based code. Since surrogate models take the form of an equation
column8: they can be evaluated very quickly. This becomes an enabler for large-scale MVA studies: while a Monte Carlo simulation across the design space is difficult with physics-based codes
column9: it becomes trivial when evaluating surrogate models
column10: which often take the form of response-surface equations.|

column2: the p-value is the probability that
column3: using a given statistical model
column4: the statistical summary (such as the sample mean difference between two compared groups) would be the same as or more extreme than the actual observed results. Statistical hypothesis testing making use of p-values is commonly used in many fields of research such as economics
column5: political science
column6: psychology
column7: biology
column8: criminal justice
column9: criminology
column10: and sociology. Their misuse has been a matter of considerable controversy.|

column1: data-transformation |This article is about metadata transformation in computer science. For the statistical concept see data transformation (statistics).In computing
column2: a data transformation converts a set of data values from the data format of a source data system into the data format of a destination data system. It is often used in a data warehouse system.Data transformation can be divided into two steps:data mapping maps data elements from the source data system to the destination data system and captures any transformation that must occurcode generation that creates the actual transformation programData element to data element mapping is frequently complicated by complex transformations that require one-to-many and many-to-one transformation rules.The code generation step takes the data element mapping specification and creates an executable program that can be run on a computer system. Code generation can also create transformation in easy-to-maintain computer languages such as Java or XSLT.A master data recast is another form of data transformation where the entire database of data values is transformed or recast without extracting the data from the database. All data in a well designed database is directly or indirectly related to a limited set of master database tables by a network of foreign key constraints. Each foreign key constraint is dependent upon a unique database index from the parent database table. Therefore
column3: when the proper master database table is recast with a different unique index
column4: the directly and indirectly related data are also recast or restated. The directly and indirectly related data may also still be viewed in the original form since the original unique index still exists with the master data. Also
column5: the database recast must be done in such a way as to not impact the applications architecture software.When the data mapping is indirect via a mediating data model
column6: the process is also called data mediation.|

column2: feature selection
column3: also known as variable selection
column4: attribute selection or variable subset selection
column5: is the process of selecting a subset of relevant features (variables
column6: predictors) for use in model construction. Feature selection techniques are used for three reasons:simplification of models to make them easier to interpret by researchers/users
column7: shorter training times
column8: enhanced generalization by reducing overfitting(formally
column9: reduction of variance)The central premise when using a feature selection technique is that the data contains many features that are either redundant or irrelevant
column10: and can thus be removed without incurring much loss of information. Redundant or irrelevant features are two distinct notions
column11: since one relevant feature may be redundant in the presence of another relevant feature with which it is strongly correlated.Feature selection techniques should be distinguished from feature extraction. Feature extraction creates new features from functions of the original features
column12: whereas feature selection returns a subset of the features.Feature selection techniques are often used in domains where there are many features and comparatively few samples (or data points). Archetypal cases for the application of feature selection include the analysis of written texts and DNA microarray data
column13: where there are many thousands of features
column14: and a few tens to hundreds of samples.|

column1: matlab |MATLAB (matrix laboratory) is a multi-paradigm numerical computing environment and fourth-generation programming language. A proprietary programming language developed by MathWorks
column2: MATLAB allows matrix manipulations
column3: plotting of functions and data
column4: implementation of algorithms
column5: creation of user interfaces
column6: and interfacing with programs written in other languages
column7: including C
column9: C#
column10: Java
column11: Fortran and Python.Although MATLAB is intended primarily for numerical computing
column12: an optional toolbox uses the MuPAD symbolic engine
column13: allowing access to symbolic computing abilities. An additional package
column14: Simulink
column15: adds graphical multi-domain simulation and model-based design for dynamic and embedded systems.In 2004
column16: MATLAB had around one million users across industry and academia. MATLAB users come from various backgrounds of engineering
column17: science
column18: and economics.|

column2: the term linear model is used in different ways according to the context. The most common occurrence is in connection with regression models and the term is often taken as synonymous with linear regression model. However
column3: the term is also used in time series analysis with a different meaning. In each case
column4: the designation "linear" is used to identify a subclass of models for which substantial reduction in the complexity of the related statistical theory is possible.|

column1: random-forest |Random forests or random decision forests are an ensemble learning method for classification
column2: regression and other tasks
column3: that operate by constructing a multitude of decision trees at training time and outputting the class that is the mode of the classes (classification) or mean prediction (regression) of the individual trees. Random decision forests correct for decision trees' habit of overfitting to their training set.The first algorithm for random decision forests was created by Tin Kam Ho  using the random subspace method
column4: which
column5: in Ho's formulation
column6: is a way to implement the "stochastic discrimination" approach to classification proposed by Eugene Kleinberg.An extension of the algorithm was developed by Leo Breiman and Adele Cutler
column7: and "Random Forests" is their trademark. The extension combines Breiman's "bagging" idea and random selection of features
column8: introduced first by Ho and later independently by Amit and Geman in order to construct a collection of decision trees with controlled variance.|

column1: least-squares |The method of least squares is a standard approach in regression analysis to the approximate solution of overdetermined systems
column2: i.e.
column3: sets of equations in which there are more equations than unknowns. "Least squares" means that the overall solution minimizes the sum of the squares of the errors made in the results of every single equation.The most important application is in data fitting. The best fit in the least-squares sense minimizes the sum of squared residuals
column4: a residual being the difference between an observed value and the fitted value provided by a model. When the problem has substantial uncertainties in the independent variable (the x variable)
column5: then simple regression and least squares methods have problems; in such cases
column6: the methodology required for fitting errors-in-variables models may be considered instead of that for least squares.Least squares problems fall into two categories: linear or ordinary least squares and non-linear least squares
column7: depending on whether or not the residuals are linear in all unknowns. The linear least-squares problem occurs in statistical regression analysis; it has a closed-form solution. The non-linear problem is usually solved by iterative refinement; at each iteration the system is approximated by a linear one
column8: and thus the core calculation is similar in both cases.Polynomial least squares describes the variance in a prediction of the dependent variable as a function of the independent variable and the deviations from the fitted curve.When the observations come from an exponential family and mild conditions are satisfied
column9: least-squares estimates and maximum-likelihood estimates are identical. The method of least squares can also be derived as a method of moments estimator.The following discussion is mostly presented in terms of linear functions but the use of least-squares is valid and practical for more general families of functions. Also
column10: by iteratively applying local quadratic approximation to the likelihood (through the Fisher information)
column11: the least-squares method may be used to fit a generalized linear model.For the topic of approximating a function by a sum of others using an objective function based on squared distances
column12: see least squares (function approximation).The least-squares method is usually credited to Carl Friedrich Gauss (1795)
column13: but it was first published by Adrien-Marie Legendre.|

column2: the term panel data (or longitudinal data) refers to multi-dimensional data frequently involving measurements over time. Panel data contain observations of multiple phenomena obtained over multiple time periods for the same firms or individuals.Time series and cross-sectional data can be thought of as special cases of panel data that are in one dimension only (one panel member or individual for the former
column3: one time point for the latter).A study that uses panel data is called a longitudinal study or panel study.|

column1: nonparametric |Nonparametric statistics are statistics not based on parameterized families of probability distributions. They include both descriptive and inferential statistics. The typical parameters are the mean
column2: variance
column3: etc. Unlike parametric statistics
column4: nonparametric statistics make no assumptions about the probability distributions of the variables being assessed. The difference between parametric models and non-parametric models is that the former has a fixed number of parameters
column5: while the latter grows the number of parameters with the amount of training data. Note that the non-parametric model does
column6: counterintuitively
column7: contain parameters: the distinction is that parameters are determined by the training data in the case of non-parametric statistics
column8: not the model.|

column2: computer science and operations research
column3: mathematical optimization
column4: also spelled mathematical optimisation
column5: alternatively named mathematical programming or simply optimization or optimisation
column6: is the selection of a best element (with regard to some criterion) from some set of available alternatives.In the simplest case
column7: an optimization problem consists of maximizing or minimizing a real function by systematically choosing input values from within an allowed set and computing the value of the function. The generalization of optimization theory and techniques to other formulations comprises a large area of applied mathematics. More generally
column8: optimization includes finding "best available" values of some objective function given a defined domain (or input)
column9: including a variety of different types of objective functions and different types of domains.|

column2: although this spelling is not present in many contemporary dictionaries) is a collection of data.Most commonly a data set corresponds to the contents of a single database table
column3: or a single statistical data matrix
column4: where every column of the table represents a particular variable
column5: and each row corresponds to a given member of the data set in question. The data set lists values for each of the variables
column6: such as height and weight of an object
column7: for each member of the data set. Each value is known as a datum. The data set may comprise data for one or more members
column8: corresponding to the number of rows.The term data set may also be used more loosely
column9: to refer to the data in a collection of closely related tables
column10: corresponding to a particular experiment or event. An example of this type is the data sets collected by space agencies performing experiments with instruments aboard space probes.In the open data discipline
column11: dataset is the unit to measure the information released in a public open data repository. The European Open Data portal aggregates more than half a million datasets. In this field other definitions have been proposed  but currently there is not an official one. Some other issues (real-time data sources
column12: non-relational datasets
column13: etc.) increases the difficulty to reach a consensus about it.|

column1: model-selection |Model selection is the task of selecting a statistical model from a set of candidate models
column2: given data. In the simplest cases
column3: a pre-existing set of data is considered. However
column4: the task can also involve the design of experiments such that the data collected is well-suited to the problem of model selection. Given candidate models of similar predictive or explanatory power
column5: the simplest model is most likely to be the best choice.Konishi & Kitagawa (2008
column6: p. 75) state
column7: "The majority of the problems in statistical inference can be considered to be problems related to statistical modeling". Relatedly
column8: Sir David Cox (2006
column9: p. 197) has said
column10: "How [the] translation from subject-matter problem to statistical model is done is often the most critical part of an analysis".|

column1: stata |Stata is a general-purpose statistical software package created in 1985 by StataCorp. Most of its users work in research
column2: especially in the fields of economics
column3: sociology
column4: political science
column5: biomedicine and epidemiology.Stata's capabilities include data management
column6: statistical analysis
column7: graphics
column8: simulations
column9: regression
column10: and custom programming.The name Stata is a syllabic abbreviation of the words statistics and data. The FAQ for the official forum of Stata insists that the correct English pronunciation of Stata "must remain a mystery"; any of "Stay-ta"
column11: "Sta-ta" or "Stah-ta" are considered acceptable.There are four major builds of each version of Stata:Stata/MP for multiprocessor computers (including dual-core and multicore processors)Stata/SE for large databasesStata/IC
column12: which is the standard versionSmall Stata
column13: which is a smaller
column14: student version for educational purchase only|

column1: sample-size |Sample size determination is the act of choosing the number of observations or replicates to include in a statistical sample. The sample size is an important feature of any empirical study in which the goal is to make inferences about a population from a sample. In practice
column2: the sample size used in a study is determined based on the expense of data collection
column3: and the need to have sufficient statistical power. In complicated studies there may be several different sample sizes involved in the study: for example
column4: in a stratified survey there would be different sample sizes for each stratum. In a census
column5: data are collected on the entire population
column6: hence the sample size is equal to the population size. In experimental design
column7: where a study may be divided into different treatment groups
column8: there may be different sample sizes for each group.Sample sizes may be chosen in several different ways:experience - For example
column9: include those items readily available or convenient to collect. A choice of small sample sizes
column10: though sometimes necessary
column11: can result in wide confidence intervals or risks of errors in statistical hypothesis testing.using a target variance for an estimate to be derived from the sample eventually obtainedusing a target for the power of a statistical test to be applied once the sample is collected.using a confidence level determines how accurate a result will turn out with lower chances of error.|

column2: conditional probability is a measure of the probability of an event given that (by assumption
column3: presumption
column4: assertion or evidence) another event has occurred. If the event of interest is A and the event B is known or assumed to have occurred
column5: "the conditional probability of A given B"
column6: or "the probability of A under the condition B"
column7: is usually written as P(A||B)
column8: or sometimes PB(A). For example
column9: the probability that any given person has a cough on any given day may be only 5%. But if we know or assume that the person has a cold
column10: then they are much more likely to be coughing. The conditional probability of coughing given that you have a cold might be a much higher 75%.The concept of conditional probability is one of the most fundamental and one of the most important concepts in probability theory. But conditional probabilities can be quite slippery and require careful interpretation. For example
column11: there need not be a causal or temporal relationship between A and B.P(A||B) may or may not be equal to P(A) (the unconditional probability of A). If P(A||B) = P(A) and P(B||A) = P(B)
column12: then events A and B are said to be independent: in such a case
column13: having knowledge about either event does not change our knowledge about the other event. Also
column14: in general
column15: P(A||B) (the conditional probability of A given B) is not equal to P(B||A). For example
column16: if you have cancer you might have a 90% chance of testing positive for cancer. In this case what is being measured is that the if event B "having cancer" has occurred
column17: the probability A - test is positive given that B having cancer occurred is 90%
column18: P(A||B) = 90%. Alternatively
column19: you can test positive for cancer but you may have only a 10% chance of actually having cancer because cancer is very rare. In this case what is being measured is the probability of the event B - having cancer given that the event A - test is positive has occurred
column20: P(B||A) = 10%. Falsely equating the two probabilities causes various errors of reasoning such as the base rate fallacy. Conditional probabilities can be correctly reversed using Bayes' theorem.|

column2: the multiple comparisons
column3: multiplicity or multiple testing problem occurs when one considers a set of statistical inferences simultaneously or infers a subset of parameters selected based on the observed values. It is also known as the look-elsewhere effect.Errors in inference
column4: including confidence intervals that fail to include their corresponding population parameters or hypothesis tests that incorrectly reject the null hypothesis
column5: are more likely to occur when one considers the set as a whole. Several statistical techniques have been developed to prevent this from happening
column6: allowing significance levels for single and multiple comparisons to be directly compared. These techniques generally require a higher significance threshold for individual comparisons
column7: so as to compensate for the number of inferences being made.|

column2: a random variable
column3: random quantity
column4: aleatory variable
column5: or stochastic variable is a variable (i.e.
column6: not necessarily fixed) quantity whose possible values depend
column7: in some clearly-defined way
column8: on a set of random events. When the random variable is discrete
column9: it can take on a value from a discrete set of possible different values
column10: each with an associated probability. Like a traditional mathematical variable
column11: its value is thus unknown a priori (before the outcome of the events is known).In a more abstract sense
column12: a random variable is defined as a function that maps outcomes (that is
column13: points in a probability space) to mathematically convenient outcome labels
column14: usually real numbers. In this sense
column15: it is a procedure for assigning a number to an outcome
column16: and
column17: contrary to its name
column18: this procedure itself is neither random nor variable. The function which characterizes a random variable must also be measurable
column19: which rules out certain pathological cases such as those in which the random variable's quantity is infinitely sensitive to any small change in the outcome.A random variable's possible values might represent the possible outcomes of a yet-to-be-performed experiment
column20: or the possible outcomes of a past experiment whose already-existing value is uncertain (for example
column21: due to imprecise measurements or quantum uncertainty). They may also conceptually represent either the results of an "objectively" random process (such as rolling a die) or the "subjective" randomness that results from incomplete knowledge of a quantity. The meaning of the probabilities assigned to the potential values of a random variable is not part of probability theory itself but is instead related to philosophical arguments over the interpretation of probability. The mathematics works the same regardless of the particular interpretation in use.A random variable has a probability distribution
column22: which specifies the probability that its value falls in any given interval. Random variables can be discrete
column23: that is
column24: taking any of a specified finite or countable list of values
column25: endowed with a probability mass function characteristic of the random variable's probability distribution; or continuous
column26: taking any numerical value in an interval or collection of intervals
column27: via a probability density function that is characteristic of the random variable's probability distribution; or a mixture of both types. Two random variables with the same probability distribution can still differ in terms of their associations with
column29: other random variables. The realizations of a random variable
column31: the results of randomly choosing values according to the variable's probability distribution function
column32: are called random variates.The formal mathematical treatment of random variables is a topic in probability theory. In that context
column33: a random variable is understood as a function defined on a sample space whose outputs are numerical values.|

column2: covariance is a measure of how much two random variables change together. If the greater values of one variable mainly correspond with the greater values of the other variable
column3: and the same holds for the lesser values
column4: i.e.
column5: the variables tend to show similar behavior
column6: the covariance is positive. For example
column7: as a balloon is blown up it gets larger in all dimensions. In the opposite case
column8: when the greater values of one variable mainly correspond to the lesser values of the other
column9: i.e.
column10: the variables tend to show opposite behavior
column11: the covariance is negative. If a sealed balloon is squashed in one dimension then it will expand in the other two. The sign of the covariance therefore shows the tendency in the linear relationship between the variables. The magnitude of the covariance is not easy to interpret. The normalized version of the covariance
column12: the correlation coefficient
column13: however
column14: shows by its magnitude the strength of the linear relation.A distinction must be made between (1) the covariance of two random variables
column15: which is a population parameter that can be seen as a property of the joint probability distribution
column16: and (2) the sample covariance
column17: which serves as an estimated value of the parameter.|

column2: linear regression is an approach for modeling the relationship between a scalar dependent variable y and one or more explanatory variables (or independent variables) denoted X. The case of one explanatory variable is called simple linear regression. For more than one explanatory variable
column3: the process is called multiple linear regression. (This term should be distinguished from multivariate linear regression
column4: where multiple correlated dependent variables are predicted
column5: rather than a single scalar variable.)In linear regression
column6: the relationships are modeled using linear predictor functions whose unknown model parameters are estimated from the data. Such models are called linear models. Most commonly
column7: the conditional mean of y given the value of X is assumed to be an affine function of X; less commonly
column8: the median or some other quantile of the conditional distribution of y given X is expressed as a linear function of X. Like all forms of regression analysis
column9: linear regression focuses on the conditional probability distribution of y given X
column10: rather than on the joint probability distribution of y and X
column11: which is the domain of multivariate analysis.Linear regression was the first type of regression analysis to be studied rigorously
column12: and to be used extensively in practical applications. This is because models which depend linearly on their unknown parameters are easier to fit than models which are non-linearly related to their parameters and because the statistical properties of the resulting estimators are easier to determine.Linear regression has many practical uses. Most applications fall into one of the following two broad categories:If the goal is prediction
column13: or forecasting
column14: or error reduction
column15: linear regression can be used to fit a predictive model to an observed data set of y and X values. After developing such a model
column16: if an additional value of X is then given without its accompanying value of y
column17: the fitted model can be used to make a prediction of the value of y.Given a variable y and a number of variables X1
column19: Xp that may be related to y
column20: linear regression analysis can be applied to quantify the strength of the relationship between y and the Xj
column21: to assess which Xj may have no relationship with y at all
column22: and to identify which subsets of the Xj contain redundant information about y.Linear regression models are often fitted using the least squares approach
column23: but they may also be fitted in other ways
column24: such as by minimizing the "lack of fit" in some other norm (as with least absolute deviations regression)
column25: or by minimizing a penalized version of the least squares loss function as in ridge regression (L2-norm penalty) and lasso (L1-norm penalty). Conversely
column26: the least squares approach can be used to fit models that are not linear models. Thus
column27: although the terms "least squares" and "linear model" are closely linked

column1: multilevel-analysis |Multilevel models (also known as hierarchical linear models
column2: nested data models
column3: mixed models
column4: random coefficient
column5: random-effects models
column6: random parameter models
column7: or split-plot designs) are statistical models of parameters that vary at more than one level. An example could be a model of student performance that contains measures for individual students as well as measures for classrooms within which the students are grouped. These models can be seen as generalizations of linear models (in particular
column8: linear regression)
column9: although they can also extend to non-linear models. These models became much more popular after sufficient computing power and software became available.Multilevel models are particularly appropriate for research designs where data for participants are organized at more than one level (i.e.
column10: nested data). The units of analysis are usually individuals (at a lower level) who are nested within contextual/aggregate units (at a higher level). While the lowest level of data in multilevel models is usually an individual
column11: repeated measurements of individuals may also be examined. As such
column12: multilevel models provide an alternative type of analysis for univariate or multivariate analysis of repeated measures. Individual differences in growth curves may be examined (see growth model). Furthermore
column13: multilevel models can be used as an alternative to ANCOVA
column14: where scores on the dependent variable are adjusted for covariates (i.e.
column15: individual differences) before testing treatment differences. Multilevel models are able to analyze these experiments without the assumptions of homogeneity-of-regression slopes that is required by ANCOVA.Multilevel models can be used on data with many levels
column16: although 2-level models are the most common and the rest of this article deals only with these. The dependent variable must be examined at the lowest level of analysis.|

column1: factor-analysis |Factor analysis is a statistical method used to describe variability among observed
column2: correlated variables in terms of a potentially lower number of unobserved variables called factors. For example
column3: it is possible that variations in six observed variables mainly reflect the variations in two unobserved (underlying) variables. Factor analysis searches for such joint variations in response to unobserved latent variables. The observed variables are modelled as linear combinations of the potential factors
column4: plus "error" terms. Factor analysis looks for independent dimensions
column5: which limits its applicability in biological sciences. Followers of factor analytic methods believe that the information gained about the interdependencies between observed variables can be used later to reduce the set of variables in a dataset. Factor analysis is not used to any significant degree in physics
column6: biology and chemistry but is used very heavily in psychometrics personality theories
column7: marketing
column8: product management
column9: operations research. Users of factor analysis believe that it helps to deal with data sets where there are large numbers of observed variables that are thought to reflect a smaller number of underlying/latent variables.Factor analysis is related to principal component analysis (PCA)
column10: but the two are not identical. There has been significant controversy in the field over differences between the two techniques (see section on exploratory factor analysis versus principal components analysis below). Clearly though
column11: PCA is a more basic version of exploratory factor analysis (EFA) that was developed in the early days prior to the advent of high-speed computers. From the point of view of exploratory analysis
column12: the eigenvalues of PCA are inflated component loadings
column13: i.e.
column14: contaminated with error variance.|

column2: moving from premises to conclusions. Charles Sanders Peirce divided inference into three kinds: deduction
column3: induction
column4: and abduction. Deduction is inference deriving logical conclusions from premises known or assumed to be true
column5: with the laws of valid inference being studied in logic. Induction is inference from particular premises to a universal conclusion. Abduction is inference to the best explanation.Human inference (i.e. how humans draw conclusions) is traditionally studied within the field of cognitive psychology; artificial intelligence researchers develop automated inference systems to emulate human inference.Statistical inference uses mathematics to draw conclusions in the presence of uncertainty. This generalizes deterministic reasoning
column6: with the absence of uncertainty as a special case. Statistical inference uses quantitative or qualitative (categorical) data which may be subject to random variations.|

column1: standard-error |The standard error (SE) is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of a statistic
column2: most commonly of the mean.The standard error of the mean (SEM) can be seen to depict the relationship between the dispersion of individual observations around the population mean (the standard deviation)
column3: and the dispersion of sample means around the population mean (the standard error). Different samples drawn from that same population would in general have different values of the sample mean
column4: so there is a distribution of sampled means (with its own mean and variance). The relationship with the standard deviation is defined such that
column5: for a given sample size
column6: the standard error equals the standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size. As the sample size increases
column7: the dispersion of the sample means clusters more closely around the population mean and the standard error decreases.In regression analysis
column8: the term "standard error" is also used in the phrase standard error of the regression to mean the ordinary least squares estimate of the standard deviation of the underlying errors. The term may also be used to refer to an estimate of that standard deviation
column9: derived from a particular sample used to compute the estimate.|

column1: deep-learning |Deep learning (also known as deep structured learning
column2: hierarchical learning or deep machine learning) is a branch of machine learning based on a set of algorithms that attempt to model high level abstractions in data by using a deep graph with multiple processing layers
column3: composed of multiple linear and non-linear transformations.Deep learning is part of a broader family of machine learning methods based on learning representations of data. An observation (e.g.
column4: an image) can be represented in many ways such as a vector of intensity values per pixel
column5: or in a more abstract way as a set of edges
column6: regions of particular shape
column7: etc. Some representations are better than others at simplifying the learning task (e.g.
column8: face recognition or facial expression recognition). One of the promises of deep learning is replacing handcrafted features with efficient algorithms for unsupervised or semi-supervised feature learning and hierarchical feature extraction.Research in this area attempts to make better representations and create models to learn these representations from large-scale unlabeled data. Some of the representations are inspired by advances in neuroscience and are loosely based on interpretation of information processing and communication patterns in a nervous system
column9: such as neural coding which attempts to define a relationship between various stimuli and associated neuronal responses in the brain.Various deep learning architectures such as deep neural networks
column10: convolutional deep neural networks
column11: deep belief networks and recurrent neural networks have been applied to fields like computer vision
column12: automatic speech recognition
column13: natural language processing
column14: audio recognition and bioinformatics where they have been shown to produce state-of-the-art results on various tasks.Deep learning has been characterized as a buzzword
column15: or a rebranding of neural networks.|

column1: binary-data |Binary data is data whose unit can take on only two possible states
column2: traditionally termed 0 and +1 in accordance with the binary numeral system and Boolean algebra. Forms and interpretations of binary data come in different technical and scientific fields. Such two-valued unit can be termed:"bit" (binary digit) in computer science
column3: truth value in mathematical logic and related domains
column4: binary variable in statistics.|

column2: a random effects model
column3: also called a variance components model
column4: is a kind of hierarchical linear model. It assumes that the data being analysed is drawn from a hierarchy of different populations whose differences relate to that hierarchy. In econometrics
column5: random effects models are used in the analysis of hierarchical or panel data when one assumes no fixed effects (it allows for individual effects). The random effects model is a special case of the fixed effects model. Contrast this to the biostatistics definitions
column6: as biostatisticians use "fixed" and "random" effects to respectively refer to the population-average and subject-specific effects (and where the latter are generally assumed to be unknown
column7: latent variables).|

column2: nonlinear regression is a form of regression analysis in which observational data are modeled by a function which is a nonlinear combination of the model parameters and depends on one or more independent variables. The data are fitted by a method of successive approximations.|

column1: k-means |k-means clustering is a method of vector quantization
column2: originally from signal processing
column3: that is popular for cluster analysis in data mining. k-means clustering aims to partition n observations into k clusters in which each observation belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean
column4: serving as a prototype of the cluster. This results in a partitioning of the data space into Voronoi cells.The problem is computationally difficult (NP-hard); however
column5: there are efficient heuristic algorithms that are commonly employed and converge quickly to a local optimum. These are usually similar to the expectation-maximization algorithm for mixtures of Gaussian distributions via an iterative refinement approach employed by both algorithms. Additionally
column6: they both use cluster centers to model the data; however
column7: k-means clustering tends to find clusters of comparable spatial extent
column8: while the expectation-maximization mechanism allows clusters to have different shapes.The algorithm has a loose relationship to the k-nearest neighbor classifier
column9: a popular machine learning technique for classification that is often confused with k-means because of the k in the name. One can apply the 1-nearest neighbor classifier on the cluster centers obtained by k-means to classify new data into the existing clusters. This is known as nearest centroid classifier or Rocchio algorithm.|

column1: meta-analysis |A meta-analysis is a statistical analysis that combines the results of multiple scientific studies.The basic tenet behind meta-analyses is that there is a common truth behind all conceptually similar scientific studies
column2: but which has been measured with a certain error within individual studies. The aim then is to use approaches from statistics to derive a pooled estimate closest to the unknown common truth based on how this error is perceived. In essence
column3: all existing methods yield a weighted average from the results of the individual studies and what differs is the manner in which these weights are allocated and also the manner in which the uncertainty is computed around the point estimate thus generated. In addition to providing an estimate of the unknown common truth
column4: meta-analysis has the capacity to contrast results from different studies and identify patterns among study results
column5: sources of disagreement among those results
column6: or other interesting relationships that may come to light in the context of multiple studies. Meta-analysis can be thought of as "conducting research about previous research." Meta-analysis can only proceed if we are able to identify a common statistical measure that is shared among studies
column7: called the effect size
column8: which has a standard error so that we can proceed with computing a weighted average of that common measure. Such weighting usually takes into consideration the sample sizes of the individual studies
column9: although it can also include other factors
column10: such as study quality.A key benefit of this approach is the aggregation of information leading to a higher statistical power and more robust point estimate than is possible from the measure derived from any individual study. However
column11: in performing a meta-analysis
column12: an investigator must make choices which can affect the results
column13: including deciding how to search for studies
column14: selecting studies based on a set of objective criteria
column15: dealing with incomplete data
column16: analyzing the data
column17: and accounting for or choosing not to account for publication bias.Meta-analyses are often
column18: but not always
column19: important components of a systematic review procedure. For instance
column20: a meta-analysis may be conducted on several clinical trials of a medical treatment
column21: in an effort to obtain a better understanding of how well the treatment works. Here it is convenient to follow the terminology used by the Cochrane Collaboration
column22: and use "meta-analysis" to refer to statistical methods of combining evidence
column23: leaving other aspects of 'research synthesis' or 'evidence synthesis'
column24: such as combining information from qualitative studies
column25: for the more general context of systematic reviews.|

column1: descriptive-statistics |Descriptive statistics are statistics that quantitatively describe or summarise features of a collection of information. Descriptive statistics are distinguished from inferential statistics (or inductive statistics)
column2: in that descriptive statistics aim to summarize a sample
column3: rather than use the data to learn about the population that the sample of data is thought to represent. This generally means that descriptive statistics
column4: unlike inferential statistics
column5: are not developed on the basis of probability theory. Even when a data analysis draws its main conclusions using inferential statistics
column6: descriptive statistics are generally also presented. For example in papers reporting on human subjects
column7: typically a table is included giving the overall sample size
column8: sample sizes in important subgroups (e.g.
column9: for each treatment or exposure group)
column10: and demographic or clinical characteristics such as the average age
column11: the proportion of subjects of each sex
column12: the proportion of subjects with related comorbidities etc.Some measures that are commonly used to describe a data set are measures of central tendency and measures of variability or dispersion. Measures of central tendency include the mean
column13: median and mode
column14: while measures of variability include the standard deviation (or variance)
column15: the minimum and maximum values of the variables
column16: kurtosis and skewness.|

column2: a Markov chain or Markoff chain
column3: named after the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov
column4: is a stochastic process that satisfies the Markov property (usually characterized as "memorylessness"). Loosely speaking
column5: a process satisfies the Markov property if one can make predictions for the future of the process based solely on its present state just as well as one could knowing the process's full history. i.e.
column6: conditional on the present state of the system
column7: its future and past are independent.In discrete time
column8: the process is known as a discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC). It undergoes transitions from one state to another on a state space
column9: with the probability distribution of the next state depending only on the current state and not on the sequence of events that preceded it.In continuous time
column10: the process is known as a Continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC[1] or continuous-time Markov process[2]). It takes values in some state space and the time spent in each state takes non-negative real values and has an exponential distribution. Future behaviour of the model (both remaining time in current state and next state) depends only on the current state of the model and not on historical behaviour.Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes.|

column1: scikit-learn |Scikit-learn (formerly scikits.learn) is a free software machine learning library for the Python programming language. It features various classification
column2: regression and clustering algorithms including support vector machines
column3: random forests
column4: gradient boosting
column5: k-means and DBSCAN
column6: and is designed to interoperate with the Python numerical and scientific libraries NumPy and SciPy.|

column2: also referred to as text data mining
column3: roughly equivalent to text analytics
column4: is the process of deriving high-quality information from text. High-quality information is typically derived through the devising of patterns and trends through means such as statistical pattern learning. Text mining usually involves the process of structuring the input text (usually parsing
column5: along with the addition of some derived linguistic features and the removal of others
column6: and subsequent insertion into a database)
column7: deriving patterns within the structured data
column8: and finally evaluation and interpretation of the output. 'High quality' in text mining usually refers to some combination of relevance
column9: novelty
column10: and interestingness. Typical text mining tasks include text categorization
column11: text clustering
column12: concept/entity extraction
column13: production of granular taxonomies
column14: sentiment analysis
column15: document summarization
column16: and entity relation modeling (i.e.
column17: learning relations between named entities).Text analysis involves information retrieval
column18: lexical analysis to study word frequency distributions
column19: pattern recognition
column20: tagging/annotation
column21: information extraction
column22: data mining techniques including link and association analysis
column23: visualization
column24: and predictive analytics. The overarching goal is
column25: essentially
column26: to turn text into data for analysis
column27: via application of natural language processing (NLP) and analytical methods.A typical application is to scan a set of documents written in a natural language and either model the document set for predictive classification purposes or populate a database or search index with the information extracted.|

column2: dimensionality reduction or dimension reduction is the process of reducing the number of random variables under consideration
column3: via obtaining a set of principal variables. It can be divided into feature selection and feature extraction.|

column2: a likelihood function (often simply the likelihood) is a function of the parameters of a statistical model given data. Likelihood functions play a key role in statistical inference
column3: especially methods of estimating a parameter from a set of statistics. In informal contexts
column4: "likelihood" is often used as a synonym for "probability." In statistics
column5: a distinction is made depending on the roles of outcomes vs. parameters. Probability is used before data are available to describe possible future outcomes given a fixed value for the parameter (or parameter vector). Likelihood is used after data are available to describe a function of a parameter (or parameter vector) for a given outcome.|

column1: bias |Bias is an inclination or outlook to present or hold a partial perspective
column2: often accompanied by a refusal to consider the possible merits of alternative points of view. Biases can be learned implicitly within cultural contexts. People may develop biases toward or against an individual
column3: an ethnic group
column4: a nation
column5: a religion
column6: a social class
column7: a political party
column8: theoretical paradigms and ideologies within academic domains
column9: or a species. Biased means one-sided
column10: lacking a neutral viewpoint
column11: or not having an open mind. Bias can come in many forms and is related to prejudice and intuition.In science and engineering
column12: a bias is a systematic error. Statistical bias results from an unfair sampling of a population
column13: or from an estimation process that does not give accurate results on average.|

column2: a fixed effects model is a statistical model that represents the observed quantities in terms of explanatory variables that are treated as if the quantities were non-random. This is in contrast to random effects models and mixed models in which either all or some of the explanatory variables are treated as if they arise from random causes. Contrast this to the biostatistics definitions
column3: as biostatisticians use "fixed" and "random" effects to respectively refer to the population-average and subject-specific effects (and where the latter are generally assumed to be unknown
column4: latent variables). Often the same structure of model
column5: which is usually a linear regression model
column6: can be treated as any of the three types depending on the analyst's viewpoint
column7: although there may be a natural choice in any given situation.In panel data analysis
column8: the term fixed effects estimator (also known as the within estimator) is used to refer to an estimator for the coefficients in the regression model. If we assume fixed effects
column9: we impose time independent effects for each entity that are possibly correlated with the regressors.|

column2: the coefficient of determination
column3: denoted R2 or r2 and pronounced "R squared"
column4: is a number that indicates the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is predictable from the independent variable.It is a statistic used in the context of statistical models whose main purpose is either the prediction of future outcomes or the testing of hypotheses
column5: on the basis of other related information. It provides a measure of how well observed outcomes are replicated by the model
column6: based on the proportion of total variation of outcomes explained by the model.There are several definitions of R2 that are only sometimes equivalent. One class of such cases includes that of simple linear regression where r2 is used instead of R2. When an intercept is included
column7: then r2 is simply the square of the sample correlation coefficient (i.e.
column8: r) between the outcomes and their predicted values. If additional regressors are included
column9: R2 is the square of the coefficient of multiple correlation. In both such cases
column10: the coefficient of determination ranges from 0 to 1.Important cases where the computational definition of R2 can yield negative values
column11: depending on the definition used
column12: arise where the predictions that are being compared to the corresponding outcomes have not been derived from a model-fitting procedure using those data
column13: and where linear regression is conducted without including an intercept. Additionally
column14: negative values of R2 may occur when fitting non-linear functions to data. In cases where negative values arise
column15: the mean of the data provides a better fit to the outcomes than do the fitted function values
column16: according to this particular criterion.|

column1: computational-statistics |Computational Statistics is a quarterly peer-reviewed scientific journal that publishes applications and research in the field of computational statistics
column2: as well as reviews of hardware
column3: software
column4: and books. According to the Journal Citation Reports
column5: the journal has a 2012 impact factor of 0.482. It was established in 1986 as Computational Statistics Quarterly and obtained its current title in 1992. The journal is published by Springer Science+Business Media and the editor-in-chief is Yuichi Mori (Okayama University of Science).|

column2: an effect size is a quantitative measure of the strength of a phenomenon. Examples of effect sizes are the correlation between two variables
column3: the regression coefficient in a regression
column4: the mean difference
column5: or even the risk with which something happens
column6: such as how many people survive after a heart attack for every one person that does not survive. For each type of effect size
column7: a larger absolute value always indicates a stronger effect. Effect sizes complement statistical hypothesis testing
column8: and play an important role in power analyses
column9: sample size planning
column10: and in meta-analyses. They are the first item (magnitude) in the MAGIC criteria for evaluating the strength of a statistical claim.Especially in meta-analysis
column11: where the purpose is to combine multiple effect sizes
column12: the standard error (S.E.) of the effect size is of critical importance. The S.E. of the effect size is used to weight effect sizes when combining studies
column13: so that large studies are considered more important than small studies in the analysis. The S.E. of the effect size is calculated differently for each type of effect size
column14: but generally only requires knowing the study's sample size (N)
column15: or the number of observations in each group (n's).Reporting effect sizes is considered good practice when presenting empirical research findings in many fields. The reporting of effect sizes facilitates the interpretation of the substantive
column16: as opposed to the statistical
column17: significance of a research result. Effect sizes are particularly prominent in social and medical research. Relative and absolute measures of effect size convey different information
column18: and can be used complementarily. A prominent task force in the psychology research community made the following recommendation:Always present effect sizes for primary outcomes...If the units of measurement are meaningful on a practical level (e.g.
column19: number of cigarettes smoked per day)
column20: then we usually prefer an unstandardized measure (regression coefficient or mean difference) to a standardized measure (r or d).|

column2: procedural generation is a method of creating data algorithmically as opposed to manually. In computer graphics
column3: it is also called random generation and is commonly used to create textures and 3D models. In video games it is used to automatically create large amounts of content in a game. Advantages of procedural generation include smaller file sizes
column4: larger amounts of content
column5: and randomness for less predictable gameplay.|

column2: summary statistics are used to summarize a set of observations
column3: in order to communicate the largest amount of information as simply as possible. Statisticians commonly try to describe the observations ina measure of location
column4: or central tendency
column5: such as the arithmetic meana measure of statistical dispersion like the standard deviationa measure of the shape of the distribution like skewness or kurtosisif more than one variable is measured
column6: a measure of statistical dependence such as a correlation coefficientA common collection of order statistics used as summary statistics are the five-number summary
column7: sometimes extended to a seven-number summary
column8: and the associated box plot.Entries in an analysis of variance table can also be regarded as summary statistics.|

column2: linguistics and the philosophy of language
column3: a natural language or ordinary language is any language that has evolved naturally in humans through use and repetition without conscious planning or premeditation. Natural languages can take different forms
column4: such as speech
column5: signing
column6: or writing. They are distinguished from constructed and formal languages such as those used to program computers or to study logic.|

column2: count data is a statistical data type
column3: a type of data in which the observations can take only the non-negative integer values {0
column8: and where these integers arise from counting rather than ranking. The statistical treatment of count data is distinct from that of binary data
column9: in which the observations can take only two values
column10: usually represented by 0 and 1
column11: and from ordinal data
column12: which may also consist of integers but where the individual values fall on an arbitrary scale and only the relative ranking is important.Statistical analyses involving count data includes simple counts
column13: such as the number of occurrences of thunderstorms in a calendar year
column14: and categorical data in which the counts represent the numbers of items falling into each of several categories.|

column2: a stationary process (or strict(ly) stationary process or strong(ly) stationary process) is a stochastic process whose joint probability distribution does not change when shifted in time. Consequently
column3: parameters such as mean and variance
column4: if they are present
column5: also do not change over time.Since stationarity is an assumption underlying many statistical procedures used in time series analysis
column6: non-stationary data is often transformed to become stationary. The most common cause of violation of Stationarity are trends in mean
column7: which can be due either to the presence of a unit root or of a deterministic trend. In the latter case the process is called trend stationary process
column8: stochastic shocks have only transitory effects
column9: and the process is mean-reverting (on a mean which changes deterministically over time). On the contrary
column10: in the first case stochastic shocks have permanent effects and the process is not mean-reverting. A trend stationary process is not strictly stationary
column11: but can easily be made such by removing the underlying trend (function solely of time). Similarly
column12: processes with one or more unit roots can be made stationary through differencing. An important type of non-stationary process that does not include a trend-like behavior is the cyclostationary process.A "stationary process" is not the same thing as a "process with a stationary distribution". Indeed
column13: there are further possibilities for confusion with the use of "stationary" in the context of stochastic processes; for example a "time-homogeneous" Markov chain is sometimes said to have "stationary transition probabilities". Besides
