column14: all stationary Markov random processes are time-homogeneous.|

column2: a Gaussian process is a statistical model where observations occur in a continuous domain
column3: e.g. time or space. In a Gaussian process
column4: every point in some continuous input space is associated with a normally distributed random variable. Moreover
column5: every finite collection of those random variables has a multivariate normal distribution. The distribution of a Gaussian process is the joint distribution of all those (infinitely many) random variables
column6: and as such
column7: it is a distribution over functions with a continuous domain
column8: e.g. time or space.Viewed as a machine-learning algorithm
column9: a Gaussian process uses lazy learning and a measure of the similarity between points (this is the kernel function) to predict the value for an unseen point from training data. The prediction is not just an estimate for that point
column10: but also has uncertainty information -- it is a one-dimensional Gaussian distribution (which is the marginal distribution at that point).For some kernel functions
column11: matrix algebra can be used to calculate the predictions
column12: as described in the kriging article. When a parameterised kernel is used
column13: optimisation software is typically used to fit a Gaussian process model.The concept of Gaussian processes is named after Carl Friedrich Gauss because it is based on the notion of the Gaussian distribution (normal distribution). Gaussian processes can be seen as an infinite-dimensional generalization of multivariate normal distributions.Gaussian processes are useful in statistical modelling
column14: benefiting from properties inherited from the normal. For example
column15: if a random process is modelled as a Gaussian process
column16: the distributions of various derived quantities can be obtained explicitly. Such quantities include the average value of the process over a range of times and the error in estimating the average using sample values at a small set of times.|

column2: also called continuous backup or real-time backup
column3: refers to backup of computer data by automatically saving a copy of every change made to that data
column4: essentially capturing every version of the data that the user saves. It allows the user or administrator to restore data to any point in time. The technique was patented by British entrepreneur Pete Malcolm in 1989.CDP runs as a service that captures changes to data to a separate storage location. There are multiple methods for capturing the continuous changes involving different technologies that serve different needs. CDP-based solutions can provide fine granularities of restorable objects ranging from crash-consistent images to logical objects such as files
column5: mail boxes
column6: messages
column7: and database files and logs.|

column2: naive Bayes classifiers are a family of simple probabilistic classifiers based on applying Bayes' theorem with strong (naive) independence assumptions between the features.Naive Bayes has been studied extensively since the 1950s. It was introduced under a different name into the text retrieval community in the early 1960s
column3: and remains a popular (baseline) method for text categorization
column4: the problem of judging documents as belonging to one category or the other (such as spam or legitimate
column5: sports or politics
column6: etc.) with word frequencies as the features. With appropriate pre-processing
column7: it is competitive in this domain with more advanced methods including support vector machines. It also finds application in automatic medical diagnosis.Naive Bayes classifiers are highly scalable
column8: requiring a number of parameters linear in the number of variables (features/predictors) in a learning problem. Maximum-likelihood training can be done by evaluating a closed-form expression
column9: which takes linear time
column10: rather than by expensive iterative approximation as used for many other types of classifiers.In the statistics and computer science literature
column11: Naive Bayes models are known under a variety of names
column12: including simple Bayes and independence Bayes. All these names reference the use of Bayes' theorem in the classifier's decision rule
column13: but naive Bayes is not (necessarily) a Bayesian method.|

column2: an autoregressive (AR) model is a representation of a type of random process; as such
column3: it is used to describe certain time-varying processes in nature
column4: economics
column5: etc. The autoregressive model specifies that the output variable depends linearly on its own previous values and on a stochastic term (an imperfectly predictable term); thus the model is in the form of a stochastic difference equation.Together with the moving-average (MA) model
column6: it is a special case and key component of the more general ARMA and ARIMA models of time series
column7: which have a more complicated stochastic structure; it is also a special case of the vector autoregressive model (VAR)
column8: which consists of a system of more than one stochastic difference equation.Contrary to the MA model
column9: the AR model is not always stationary as it may contain a unit root.|

column1: biostatistics |Biostatistics is the application of statistics to a wide range of topics in biology. The science of biostatistics encompasses the design of biological experiments
column2: especially in medicine
column3: pharmacy
column4: agriculture and fishery; the collection
column5: summarization
column6: and analysis of data from those experiments; and the interpretation of
column7: and inference from
column8: the results. A major branch of this is medical biostatistics
column9: which is exclusively concerned with medicine and health.|

column1: hidden-markov-model |A hidden Markov model (HMM) is a statistical Markov model in which the system being modeled is assumed to be a Markov process with unobserved (hidden) states. An HMM can be presented as the simplest dynamic Bayesian network. The mathematics behind the HMM were developed by L. E. Baum and coworkers. It is closely related to an earlier work on the optimal nonlinear filtering problem by Ruslan L. Stratonovich
column2: who was the first to describe the forward-backward procedure.In simpler Markov models (like a Markov chain)
column3: the state is directly visible to the observer
column4: and therefore the state transition probabilities are the only parameters. In a hidden Markov model
column5: the state is not directly visible
column6: but the output
column7: dependent on the state
column8: is visible. Each state has a probability distribution over the possible output tokens. Therefore
column9: the sequence of tokens generated by an HMM gives some information about the sequence of states. The adjective 'hidden' refers to the state sequence through which the model passes
column10: not to the parameters of the model; the model is still referred to as a 'hidden' Markov model even if these parameters are known exactly.Hidden Markov models are especially known for their application in temporal pattern recognition such as speech
column11: handwriting
column12: gesture recognition
column13: part-of-speech tagging
column14: musical score following
column15: partial discharges and bioinformatics.A hidden Markov model can be considered a generalization of a mixture model where the hidden variables (or latent variables)
column16: which control the mixture component to be selected for each observation
column17: are related through a Markov process rather than independent of each other. Recently
column18: hidden Markov models have been generalized to pairwise Markov models and triplet Markov models which allow consideration of more complex data structures  and the modelling of nonstationary data.|

column1: standardization |Standardization or standardisation is the process of implementing and developing technical standards based on the consensus of different parties that include firms
column2: users
column3: interest groups
column4: standards organizations and governments Standardization can help to maximize compatibility
column5: interoperability
column6: safety
column7: repeatability
column8: or quality. It can also facilitate commoditization of formerly custom processes. In social sciences
column9: including economics
column10: the idea of standardization is close to the solution for a coordination problem
column11: a situation in which all parties can realize mutual gains
column12: but only by making mutually consistent decisions. This view includes the case of "spontaneous standardization processes"
column13: to produce de facto standards.|

column1: group-differences |Difference in differences (sometimes abbreviated DID or DD) is a statistical technique used in econometrics and quantitative research in the social sciences that attempts to mimic an experimental research design using observational study data
column2: by studying the differential effect of a treatment on a 'treatment group' versus a 'control group' in a natural experiment. It calculates the effect of a treatment (i.e.
column3: an explanatory variable or an independent variable) on an outcome (i.e.
column4: a response variable or dependent variable) by comparing the average change over time in the outcome variable for the treatment group
column5: compared to the average change over time for the control group. Although it is intended to mitigate the effects of extraneous factors and selection bias
column6: depending on how the treatment group is chosen
column7: this method may still be subject to certain biases (e.g. mean regression
column8: reverse causality and omitted variable bias).In contrast to a time-series estimate of the treatment effect on subjects (which analyzes differences over time) or a cross-section estimate of the treatment effect (which measures the difference between treatment and control groups)
column9: difference in differences uses panel data to measure the differences
column10: between the treatment and control group
column11: of the changes in the outcome variable that occur over time.|

column1: curve-fitting |Curve fitting is the process of constructing a curve
column2: or mathematical function
column3: that has the best fit to a series of data points
column4: possibly subject to constraints. Curve fitting can involve either interpolation
column5: where an exact fit to the data is required
column6: or smoothing
column7: in which a "smooth" function is constructed that approximately fits the data. A related topic is regression analysis
column8: which focuses more on questions of statistical inference such as how much uncertainty is present in a curve that is fit to data observed with random errors. Fitted curves can be used as an aid for data visualization
column9: to infer values of a function where no data are available
column10: and to summarize the relationships among two or more variables. Extrapolation refers to the use of a fitted curve beyond the range of the observed data
column11: and is subject to a degree of uncertainty since it may reflect the method used to construct the curve as much as it reflects the observed data.|

column2: time series data is data collected at regular intervals. When there are patterns that repeat over known
column3: fixed periods of time within the data set
column4: such patterns are known as seasonality
column5: seasonal variation
column6: periodic variation
column7: or periodic fluctuations. This variation can be either regular or semi-regular.Seasonality may be caused by various factors
column8: such as weather
column9: vacation
column10: and holidays and usually consists of periodic
column11: repetitive
column12: and generally regular and predictable patterns in the levels of a time series. Seasonality can repeat on a weekly
column13: monthly or quarterly basis
column14: these periods of time are structured and occur in a length of time less than a year. Seasonal fluctuations in a time series can be contrasted with cyclical patterns. The latter occurs when the data exhibits rises and falls that are not of a fixed period. These fluctuations are usually due to economic conditions and are often related to the "business cycle." The fixed period of time usually extends beyond a single year and the fluctuations are usually of at least two year and do not repeat over fixed periods of time.Organizations facing seasonal variations
column15: such as ice-cream vendors
column16: are often interested in knowing their performance relative to the normal seasonal variation. Seasonal variations in the labor market can be attributed to the entrance of school leavers into the job market; as they aim to contribute to the workforce during their vacations
column17: or upon the completion of their schooling. These regular changes are of less interest to those who study employment data than the variations that occur due to the underlying state of the economy. Where their focus is on how unemployment in the workforce has changed
column18: despite the impact of the regular seasonal variations.It is necessary for organizations to identify and measure seasonal variations within their market to help them plan for the future. This can prepare them for the temporary increases or decreases in labor requirements and inventory as demand for their product or service fluctuates over certain periods. This may require training
column19: periodic maintenance
column20: and so forth that can be organized in advance. Apart from these considerations
column21: the organizations need to know if variation they have experienced have been more or less than the expected amount
column22: beyond what the usual seasonal variations account for.|

column2: an average is the sum of a list of numbers divided by the number of numbers in the list. In mathematics and statistics
column3: this would be called the arithmetic mean. In statistics
column4: mean
column5: median
column6: and mode are all known as measures of central tendency.|

column1: gradient-descent |Gradient descent is a first-order iterative optimization algorithm. To find a local minimum of a function using gradient descent
column2: one takes steps proportional to the negative of the gradient (or of the approximate gradient) of the function at the current point. If instead one takes steps proportional to the positive of the gradient
column3: one approaches a local maximum of that function; the procedure is then known as gradient ascent.Gradient descent is also known as steepest descent
column4: or the method of steepest descent. Gradient descent should not be confused with the method of steepest descent for approximating integrals.|

column2: the odds ratio (OR) is one of three main ways to quantify how strongly the presence or absence of property A is associated with the presence or absence of property B in a given population. If each individual in a population either does or does not have a property "A"
column3: (e.g. "high blood pressure")
column4: and also either does or does not have a property "B" (e.g. "moderate alcohol consumption") where both properties are appropriately defined
column5: then a ratio can be formed which quantitatively describes the association between the presence/absence of "A" (high blood pressure) and the presence/absence of "B" (moderate alcohol consumption) for individuals in the population. This ratio is the odds ratio (OR) and can be computed following these steps:For a given individual that has "B" compute the odds that the same individual has "A"For a given individual that does not have "B" compute the odds that the same individual has "A"Divide the odds from step 1 by the odds from step 2 to obtain the odds ratio (OR).The term "individual" in this usage does not have to refer to a human being
column6: as a statistical population can measure any set of entities
column7: whether living or inanimate.If the OR is greater than 1
column8: then having "A" is considered to be "associated" with having "B" in the sense that the having of "B" raises (relative to not-having "B") the odds of having "A". Note that this does not establish that B is a contributing cause of "A": it could be that the association is due to a third property
column10: which is a contributing cause of both "A" and "B" (confounding).The two other major ways of quantifying association are the risk ratio ("RR") and the absolute risk reduction ("ARR"). In clinical studies and many other settings
column11: the parameter of greatest interest is often actually the RR
column12: which is determined in a way that is similar to the one just described for the OR
column13: except using probabilities instead of odds. Frequently
column14: however
column15: the available data only allows the computation of the OR; notably
column16: this is so in the case of case-control studies
column17: as explained below. On the other hand
column18: if one of the properties (say
column19: A) is sufficiently rare (the "rare disease assumption")
column20: then the OR of having A given that the individual has B is a good approximation to the corresponding RR (the specification "A given B" is needed because
column21: while the OR treats the two properties symmetrically
column22: the RR and other measures do not).In a more technical language
column23: the OR is a measure of effect size
column24: describing the strength of association or non-independence between two binary data values. It is used as a descriptive statistic
column25: and plays an important role in logistic regression.|

column1: median |The median is the value separating the higher half of a data sample
column2: a population
column3: or a probability distribution
column4: from the lower half. In simple terms
column5: it may be thought of as the "middle" value of a data set. For example
column6: in the data set {1
column13: the median is 6
column14: the fourth number in the sample. The median is a commonly used measure of the properties of a data set in statistics and probability theory.The basic advantage of the median in describing data compared to the mean (often simply described as the "average") is that it is not skewed so much by extremely large or small values
column15: and so it may give a better idea of a 'typical' value. For example
column16: in understanding statistics like household income or assets which vary greatly
column17: a mean may be skewed by a small number of extremely high or low values. Median income
column18: for example
column19: may be a better way to suggest what a 'typical' income is.Because of this
column20: the median is of central importance in robust statistics
column21: as it is the most resistant statistic
column22: having a breakdown point of 50%: so long as no more than half the data are contaminated
column23: the median will not give an arbitrarily large or small result.|

column1: linear |Linearity is the property of a mathematical relationship or function which means that it can be graphically represented as a straight line
column2: that is
column3: that one quantity is simply proportional to another. Examples are the relationship of voltage and current across a resistor (Ohm's law)
column4: or the mass and weight of an object.|

column2: a mixture model is a probabilistic model for representing the presence of subpopulations within an overall population
column3: without requiring that an observed data set should identify the sub-population to which an individual observation belongs. Formally a mixture model corresponds to the mixture distribution that represents the probability distribution of observations in the overall population. However
column4: while problems associated with "mixture distributions" relate to deriving the properties of the overall population from those of the sub-populations
column5: "mixture models" are used to make statistical inferences about the properties of the sub-populations given only observations on the pooled population
column6: without sub-population identity information.Some ways of implementing mixture models involve steps that attribute postulated sub-population-identities to individual observations (or weights towards such sub-populations)
column7: in which case these can be regarded as types of unsupervised learning or clustering procedures. However
column8: not all inference procedures involve such steps.Mixture models should not be confused with models for compositional data
column9: i.e.
column10: data whose components are constrained to sum to a constant value (1
column12: etc.). However
column13: compositional models can be thought of as mixture models
column14: where members of the population are sampled at random. Conversely
column15: mixture models can be thought of as compositional models
column16: where the total size of the population has been normalized to 1.|

column1: pattern-recognition |Pattern recognition is a branch of machine learning that focuses on the recognition of patterns and regularities in data
column2: although it is in some cases considered to be nearly synonymous with machine learning. Pattern recognition systems are in many cases trained from labeled "training" data (supervised learning)
column3: but when no labeled data are available other algorithms can be used to discover previously unknown patterns (unsupervised learning).The terms pattern recognition
column4: machine learning
column5: data mining and knowledge discovery in databases (KDD) are hard to separate
column6: as they largely overlap in their scope. Machine learning is the common term for supervised learning methods and originates from artificial intelligence
column7: whereas KDD and data mining have a larger focus on unsupervised methods and stronger connection to business use. Pattern recognition has its origins in engineering
column8: and the term is popular in the context of computer vision: a leading computer vision conference is named Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition. In pattern recognition
column9: there may be a higher interest to formalize
column10: explain and visualize the pattern
column11: while machine learning traditionally focuses on maximizing the recognition rates. Yet
column12: all of these domains have evolved substantially from their roots in artificial intelligence
column13: engineering and statistics
column14: and they've become increasingly similar by integrating developments and ideas from each other.In machine learning
column15: pattern recognition is the assignment of a label to a given input value. In statistics
column16: discriminant analysis was introduced for this same purpose in 1936. An example of pattern recognition is classification
column17: which attempts to assign each input value to one of a given set of classes (for example
column18: determine whether a given email is "spam" or "non-spam"). However
column19: pattern recognition is a more general problem that encompasses other types of output as well. Other examples are regression
column20: which assigns a real-valued output to each input; sequence labeling
column21: which assigns a class to each member of a sequence of values (for example
column22: part of speech tagging
column23: which assigns a part of speech to each word in an input sentence); and parsing
column24: which assigns a parse tree to an input sentence
column25: describing the syntactic structure of the sentence.Pattern recognition algorithms generally aim to provide a reasonable answer for all possible inputs and to perform "most likely" matching of the inputs
column26: taking into account their statistical variation. This is opposed to pattern matching algorithms
column27: which look for exact matches in the input with pre-existing patterns. A common example of a pattern-matching algorithm is regular expression matching
column28: which looks for patterns of a given sort in textual data and is included in the search capabilities of many text editors and word processors. In contrast to pattern recognition
column29: pattern matching is generally not considered a type of machine learning
column30: although pattern-matching algorithms (especially with fairly general
column31: carefully tailored patterns) can sometimes succeed in providing similar-quality output of the sort provided by pattern-recognition algorithms.|

column2: given at least two random variables X
column3: Y
column5: that are defined on a probability space
column6: the joint probability distribution for X
column7: Y
column8: ... is a probability distribution that gives the probability that each of X
column9: Y
column10: ... falls in any particular range or discrete set of values specified for that variable. In the case of only two random variables
column11: this is called a bivariate distribution
column12: but the concept generalizes to any number of random variables
column13: giving a multivariate distribution.The joint probability distribution can be expressed either in terms of a joint cumulative distribution function or in terms of a joint probability density function (in the case of continuous variables) or joint probability mass function (in the case of discrete variables). These in turn can be used to find two other types of distributions: the marginal distribution giving the probabilities for any one of the variables with no reference to any specific ranges of values for the other variables
column14: and the conditional probability distribution giving the probabilities for any subset of the variables conditional on particular values of the remaining variables.|

column2: a contingency table (also known as a cross tabulation or crosstab) is a type of table in a matrix format that displays the (multivariate) frequency distribution of the variables. They are heavily used in survey research
column3: business intelligence
column4: engineering and scientific research. They provide a basic picture of the interrelation between two variables and can help find interactions between them. The term contingency table was first used by Karl Pearson in "On the Theory of Contingency and Its Relation to Association and Normal Correlation"
column5: part of the Drapers' Company Research Memoirs Biometric Series I published in 1904.A crucial problem of multivariate statistics is finding (direct-)dependence structure underlying the variables contained in high-dimensional contingency tables. If some of the conditional independences are revealed
column6: then even the storage of the data can be done in a smarter way (see Lauritzen (2002)). In order to do this one can use information theory concepts
column7: which gain the information only from the distribution of probability
column8: which can be expressed easily from the contingency table by the relative frequencies.|

column2: the bias (or bias function) of an estimator is the difference between this estimator's expected value and the true value of the parameter being estimated. An estimator or decision rule with zero bias is called unbiased. Otherwise the estimator is said to be biased. In statistics
column3: "bias" is an objective statement about a function
column4: and while not a desired property
column5: it is not pejorative
column6: unlike the ordinary English use of the term "bias".Bias can also be measured with respect to the median
column7: rather than the mean (expected value)
column8: in which case one distinguishes median-unbiased from the usual mean-unbiasedness property. Bias is related to consistency in that consistent estimators are convergent and asymptotically unbiased (hence converge to the correct value)
column9: though individual estimators in a consistent sequence may be biased (so long as the bias converges to zero); see bias versus consistency.All else equal
column10: an unbiased estimator is preferable to a biased estimator
column11: but in practice all else is not equal
column12: and biased estimators are frequently used
column13: generally with small bias. When a biased estimator is used
column14: the bias is also estimated. A biased estimator may be used for various reasons: because an unbiased estimator does not exist without further assumptions about a population or is difficult to compute (as in unbiased estimation of standard deviation); because an estimator is median-unbiased but not mean-unbiased (or the reverse); because a biased estimator reduces some loss function (particularly mean squared error) compared with unbiased estimators (notably in shrinkage estimators); or because in some cases being unbiased is too strong a condition
column15: and the only unbiased estimators are not useful. Further
column16: mean-unbiasedness is not preserved under non-linear transformations
column17: though median-unbiasedness is (see effect of transformations); for example
column18: the sample variance is an unbiased estimator for the population variance
column19: but its square root
column20: the sample standard deviation
column21: is a biased estimator for the population standard deviation. These are all illustrated below.|

column2: the conditional expectation of a random variable is another random variable equal to the average of the former over each possible "condition". In the case when the random variable is defined over a discrete probability space
column3: the "conditions" are a partition of this probability space. This definition is then generalized to any probability space using measure theory.Conditional expectation is also known as conditional expected value or conditional mean.In modern probability theory the concept of conditional probability is defined in terms of conditional expectation.|

column2: imputation is the process of replacing missing data with substituted values. When substituting for a data point
column3: it is known as "unit imputation"; when substituting for a component of a data point
column4: it is known as "item imputation". There are three main problems that missing data causes: missing data can introduce a substantial amount of bias
column5: make the handling and analysis of the data more arduous
column6: and create reductions in efficiency. Because missing data can create problems for analyzing data
column7: imputation is seen as a way to avoid pitfalls involved with listwise deletion of cases that have missing values. That is to say
column8: when one or more values are missing for a case
column9: most statistical packages default to discarding any case that has a missing value
column10: which may introduce bias or affect the representativeness of the results. Imputation preserves all cases by replacing missing data with an estimated value based on other available information. Once all missing values have been imputed
column11: the data set can then be analysed using standard techniques for complete data. Imputation theory is constantly developing and thus requires consistent attention to new information regarding the subject. There have been many theories embraced by scientists to account for missing data but the majority of them introduce large amounts of bias. A few of the well known attempts to deal with missing data include: hot deck and cold deck imputation; listwise and pairwise deletion; mean imputation; regression imputation; last observation carried forward; stochastic imputation; and multiple imputation.|

column2: Poisson regression is a generalized linear model form of regression analysis used to model count data and contingency tables. Poisson regression assumes the response variable Y has a Poisson distribution
column3: and assumes the logarithm of its expected value can be modeled by a linear combination of unknown parameters. A Poisson regression model is sometimes known as a log-linear model
column4: especially when used to model contingency tables.Negative binomial regression is a popular generalization of Poisson regression because it loosens the highly restrictive assumption that the variance is equal to the mean made by the Poisson model. The traditional negative binomial regression model
column5: commonly known as NB2
column6: is based on the Poisson-gamma mixture distribution. This model is popular because it models the Poisson heterogeneity with a gamma distribution.Poisson regression models are generalized linear models with the logarithm as the (canonical) link function
column7: and the Poisson distribution function as the assumed probability distribution of the response.|

column2: the k-Nearest Neighbors algorithm (or k-NN for short) is a non-parametric method used for classification and regression. In both cases
column3: the input consists of the k closest training examples in the feature space. The output depends on whether k-NN is used for classification or regression:In k-NN classification
column4: the output is a class membership. An object is classified by a majority vote of its neighbors
column5: with the object being assigned to the class most common among its k nearest neighbors (k is a positive integer
column6: typically small). If k = 1
column7: then the object is simply assigned to the class of that single nearest neighbor.In k-NN regression
column8: the output is the property value for the object. This value is the average of the values of its k nearest neighbors.k-NN is a type of instance-based learning
column9: or lazy learning
column10: where the function is only approximated locally and all computation is deferred until classification. The k-NN algorithm is among the simplest of all machine learning algorithms.Both for classification and regression
column11: it can be useful to assign weight to the contributions of the neighbors
column12: so that the nearer neighbors contribute more to the average than the more distant ones. For example
column13: a common weighting scheme consists in giving each neighbor a weight of 1/d
column14: where d is the distance to the neighbor.The neighbors are taken from a set of objects for which the class (for k-NN classification) or the object property value (for k-NN regression) is known. This can be thought of as the training set for the algorithm
column15: though no explicit training step is required.A shortcoming of the k-NN algorithm is that it is sensitive to the local structure of the data. The algorithm is not to be confused with k-means
column16: another popular machine learning technique.|

column1: discriminant-analysis |Linear discriminant analysis (LDA) is a generalization of Fisher's linear discriminant
column2: a method used in statistics
column3: pattern recognition and machine learning to find a linear combination of features that characterizes or separates two or more classes of objects or events. The resulting combination may be used as a linear classifier
column4: or
column5: more commonly
column6: for dimensionality reduction before later classification.LDA is closely related to analysis of variance (ANOVA) and regression analysis
column7: which also attempt to express one dependent variable as a linear combination of other features or measurements. However
column8: ANOVA uses categorical independent variables and a continuous dependent variable
column9: whereas discriminant analysis has continuous independent variables and a categorical dependent variable (i.e. the class label). Logistic regression and probit regression are more similar to LDA than ANOVA is
column10: as they also explain a categorical variable by the values of continuous independent variables. These other methods are preferable in applications where it is not reasonable to assume that the independent variables are normally distributed
column11: which is a fundamental assumption of the LDA method.LDA is also closely related to principal component analysis (PCA) and factor analysis in that they both look for linear combinations of variables which best explain the data. LDA explicitly attempts to model the difference between the classes of data. PCA on the other hand does not take into account any difference in class
column12: and factor analysis builds the feature combinations based on differences rather than similarities. Discriminant analysis is also different from factor analysis in that it is not an interdependence technique: a distinction between independent variables and dependent variables (also called criterion variables) must be made.LDA works when the measurements made on independent variables for each observation are continuous quantities. When dealing with categorical independent variables
column13: the equivalent technique is discriminant correspondence analysis.|

column2: Bayes network
column3: belief network
column4: Bayes(ian) model or probabilistic directed acyclic graphical model is a probabilistic graphical model (a type of statistical model) that represents a set of random variables and their conditional dependencies via a directed acyclic graph (DAG). For example
column5: a Bayesian network could represent the probabilistic relationships between diseases and symptoms. Given symptoms
column6: the network can be used to compute the probabilities of the presence of various diseases.Formally
column7: Bayesian networks are DAGs whose nodes represent random variables in the Bayesian sense: they may be observable quantities
column8: latent variables
column9: unknown parameters or hypotheses. Edges represent conditional dependencies; nodes that are not connected (there is no path from one of the variables to the other in the Bayesian network) represent variables that are conditionally independent of each other. Each node is associated with a probability function that takes
column10: as input
column11: a particular set of values for the node's parent variables
column12: and gives (as output) the probability (or probability distribution
column13: if applicable) of the variable represented by the node. For example
column14: possible combinations of its parents being true or false. Similar ideas may be applied to undirected
column15: and possibly cyclic
column16: graphs; such are called Markov networks.Efficient algorithms exist that perform inference and learning in Bayesian networks. Bayesian networks that model sequences of variables (e.g. speech signals or protein sequences) are called dynamic Bayesian networks. Generalizations of Bayesian networks that can represent and solve decision problems under uncertainty are called influence diagrams.|

column1: accuracy |Precision is a description of random errors
column2: a measure of statistical variability.Accuracy has two definitions:more commonly
column3: it is a description of systematic errors
column4: a measure of statistical bias;alternatively
column5: ISO defines accuracy as describing both types of observational error above (preferring the term trueness for the common definition of accuracy).|

column1: basic-concepts |Basic Concepts in Sociology is a book written by Maximilian Weber
column2: a German economist and sociologist. The original edition was published in 1922 in German as Soziologische Grundbegriffe
column3: but various translations to English exist. The first known of these was written in 1962.This is part of a monumental work that was interrupted by Weber's death. He attempted to summarize all important concepts of sociology in that part.|

column1: psychometrics |Psychometrics is a field of study concerned with the theory and technique of psychological measurement. As defined by National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME)
column2: psychometrics refers to psychological measurement. Generally
column3: it refers to the field in psychology and education that is devoted to testing
column4: measurement
column5: assessment
column6: and related activities. One part of the field is concerned with the objective measurement of skills and knowledge
column7: abilities
column8: attitudes
column9: personality traits
column10: and educational achievement. For example
column11: some psychometric researchers have
column12: thus far
column13: concerned themselves with the construction and validation of assessment instruments such as questionnaires
column14: tests
column15: raters' judgments
column16: and personality tests. Another part of the field is concerned with statistical research bearing on measurement theory (e.g.
column17: item response theory; intraclass correlation).As a result of these focuses
column18: psychometric research involves two major tasks: (i) the construction of instruments; and (ii) the development of procedures for measurement. Practitioners are described as psychometricians. Psychometricians usually possess a specific qualification
column19: and most are psychologists with advanced graduate training. In addition to traditional academic institutions
column20: many psychometricians work for the government or in human resources departments. Others specialize as learning and development professionals.|

column2: a metric or distance function is a function that defines a distance between each pair of elements of a set. A set with a metric is called a metric space. A metric induces a topology on a set
column3: but not all topologies can be generated by a metric. A topological space whose topology can be described by a metric is called metrizable.An important source of metrics in differential geometry are metric tensors
column4: bilinear forms that may be defined from the tangent vectors of a differentiable manifold onto a scalar. A metric tensor allows distances along curves to be determined through integration
column5: and thus determines a metric. However
column6: not every metric comes from a metric tensor in this way.|

column2: econometrics
column3: epidemiology and related disciplines
column4: the method of instrumental variables (IV) is used to estimate causal relationships when controlled experiments are not feasible or when a treatment is not successfully delivered to every unit in a randomized experiment. Intuitively
column5: IV is used when the correlation between the explanatory variable and the dependent variable does not plausibly reflect the causal relationship between the two. A valid instrument induces changes in the explanatory variable but has no independent effect on the dependent variable
column6: allowing a researcher to uncover the causal effect of the explanatory variable on the dependent variable.Instrumental variable methods allow for consistent estimation when the explanatory variables (covariates) are correlated with the error terms in a regression model. Such correlation may occur when changes in the dependent variable change the value of at least one of the covariates ("reverse" causation)
column7: when there are omitted variables that affect both the dependent and independent variables
column8: or when the covariates are subject to measurement error. Explanatory variables which suffer from one or more of these issues in the context of a regression are sometimes referred to as endogenous. In this situation
column9: ordinary least squares produces biased and inconsistent estimates. However
column10: if an instrument is available
column11: consistent estimates may still be obtained. An instrument is a variable that does not itself belong in the explanatory equation but is correlated with the endogenous explanatory variables
column12: conditional on the value of other covariates. In linear models
column13: there are two main requirements for using IV:The instrument must be correlated with the endogenous explanatory variables
column14: conditional on the other covariates. If this correlation is highly statistically significant
column15: then the instrument is said to have a strong first stage. A weak correlation may provide misleading inferences about parameter estimates and standard errors.The instrument cannot be correlated with the error term in the explanatory equation
column16: conditional on the other covariates. In other words
column17: the instrument cannot suffer from the same problem as the original predicting variable. If this condition is met
column18: then the instrument is said to satisfy the exclusion restriction.|

column2: imputation is the process of replacing missing data with substituted values. When substituting for a data point
column3: it is known as "unit imputation"; when substituting for a component of a data point
column4: it is known as "item imputation". There are three main problems that missing data causes: missing data can introduce a substantial amount of bias
column5: make the handling and analysis of the data more arduous
column6: and create reductions in efficiency. Because missing data can create problems for analyzing data
column7: imputation is seen as a way to avoid pitfalls involved with listwise deletion of cases that have missing values. That is to say
column8: when one or more values are missing for a case
column9: most statistical packages default to discarding any case that has a missing value
column10: which may introduce bias or affect the representativeness of the results. Imputation preserves all cases by replacing missing data with an estimated value based on other available information. Once all missing values have been imputed
column11: the data set can then be analysed using standard techniques for complete data. Imputation theory is constantly developing and thus requires consistent attention to new information regarding the subject. There have been many theories embraced by scientists to account for missing data but the majority of them introduce large amounts of bias. A few of the well known attempts to deal with missing data include: hot deck and cold deck imputation; listwise and pairwise deletion; mean imputation; regression imputation; last observation carried forward; stochastic imputation; and multiple imputation.|

column2: one of the most common tasks is to fit a "model" to a set of training data
column3: so as to be able to make reliable predictions on general untrained data. In overfitting
column4: a statistical model describes random error or noise instead of the underlying relationship. Overfitting occurs when a model is excessively complex
column5: such as having too many parameters relative to the number of observations. A model that has been overfit has poor predictive performance
column6: as it overreacts to minor fluctuations in the training data.The possibility of overfitting exists because the criterion used for training the model is not the same as the criterion used to judge the efficacy of a model. In particular
column7: a model is typically trained by maximizing its performance on some set of training data. However
column8: its efficacy is determined not by its performance on the training data but by its ability to perform well on unseen data. Overfitting occurs when a model begins to "memorize" training data rather than "learning" to generalize from trend. As an extreme example
column9: if the number of parameters is the same as or greater than the number of observations
column10: a simple model or learning process can perfectly predict the training data simply by memorizing the training data in its entirety
column11: but such a model will typically fail drastically when making predictions about new or unseen data
column12: since the simple model has not learned to generalize at all.The potential for overfitting depends not only on the number of parameters and data but also the conformability of the model structure with the data shape
column13: and the magnitude of model error compared to the expected level of noise or error in the data.Even when the fitted model does not have an excessive number of parameters
column14: it is to be expected that the fitted relationship will appear to perform less well on a new data set than on the data set used for fitting. In particular
column15: the value of the coefficient of determination will shrink relative to the original training data.In order to avoid overfitting
column16: it is necessary to use additional techniques (e.g. cross-validation
column17: regularization
column18: early stopping
column19: pruning
column20: Bayesian priors on parameters or model comparison)
column21: that can indicate when further training is not resulting in better generalization. The basis of some techniques is either (1) to explicitly penalize overly complex models
column22: or (2) to test the model's ability to generalize by evaluating its performance on a set of data not used for training
column23: which is assumed to approximate the typical unseen data that a model will encounter.A good analogy for the overfitting problem is imagine a baby trying to learn what is a window or what is not a window
column24: we start to show him windows and he detects at a initial phase that all windows have glasses
column25: and a frame and you can look outside
column26: some of them may be opened. If we keep showing the same windows the baby may also falsely deduce that all windows are green
column27: and that all green frames are windows. Thus overfitting the problem.|

column2: the degrees of freedom of a system is the number of parameters of the system that may vary independently. For example
column3: a point in the plane has two degrees of freedom for translation: its two coordinates; a non-infinitesimal object on the plane might have additional degrees of freedoms related to its orientation.In mathematics
column4: this notion is formalized as the dimension of a manifold or an algebraic variety. When degrees of freedom is used instead of dimension
column5: this usually means that the manifold or variety that models the system is only implicitly defined. See:Degrees of freedom (mechanics)
column6: number of independent motions that are allowed to the body or
column7: in case of a mechanism made of several bodies
column8: number of possible independent relative motions between the pieces of the mechanismDegrees of freedom (physics and chemistry)
column9: a term used in explaining dependence on parameters
column10: or the dimensions of a phase spaceDegrees of freedom (statistics)
column11: the number of values in the final calculation of a statistic that are free to varyDegrees of freedom problem
column12: the problem of controlling motor movement given abundant degrees of freedom|

column1: recommender-system |Recommender systems or recommendation systems (sometimes replacing "system" with a synonym such as platform or engine) are a subclass of information filtering system that seek to predict the "rating" or "preference" that a user would give to an item.Recommender systems have become extremely common in recent years
column2: and are utilized in a variety of areas: some popular applications include movies
column3: music
column4: news
column5: books
column6: research articles
column7: search queries
column8: social tags
column9: and products in general. There are also recommender systems for experts
column10: collaborators
column11: jokes
column12: restaurants
column13: garments
column14: financial services
column15: life insurance
column16: romantic partners (online dating)
column17: and Twitter pages.|

column1: linear-algebra |Linear algebra is the branch of mathematics concerning vector spaces and linear mappings between such spaces. It includes the study of lines
column2: planes
column3: and subspaces
column4: but is also concerned with properties common to all vector spaces.The set of points with coordinates that satisfy a linear equation forms a hyperplane in an n-dimensional space. The conditions under which a set of n hyperplanes intersect in a single point is an important focus of study in linear algebra. Such an investigation is initially motivated by a system of linear equations containing several unknowns. Such equations are naturally represented using the formalism of matrices and vectors.Linear algebra is central to both pure and applied mathematics. For instance
column5: abstract algebra arises by relaxing the axioms of a vector space
column6: leading to a number of generalizations. Functional analysis studies the infinite-dimensional version of the theory of vector spaces. Combined with calculus
column7: linear algebra facilitates the solution of linear systems of differential equations.Techniques from linear algebra are also used in analytic geometry
column8: engineering
column9: physics
column10: natural sciences
column11: computer science
column12: computer animation
column13: advanced facial recognition algorithms and the social sciences (particularly in economics). Because linear algebra is such a well-developed theory
column14: nonlinear mathematical models are sometimes approximated by linear models.|

column2: an estimator is a rule for calculating an estimate of a given quantity based on observed data: thus the rule (the estimator)
column3: the quantity of interest (the estimand) and its result (the estimate) are distinguished.There are point and interval estimators. The point estimators yield single-valued results
column4: although this includes the possibility of single vector-valued results and results that can be expressed as a single function. This is in contrast to an interval estimator
column5: where the result would be a range of plausible values (or vectors or functions).Estimation theory is concerned with the properties of estimators; that is
column6: with defining properties that can be used to compare different estimators (different rules for creating estimates) for the same quantity
column7: based on the same data. Such properties can be used to determine the best rules to use under given circumstances. However
column8: in robust statistics
column9: statistical theory goes on to consider the balance between having good properties
column10: if tightly defined assumptions hold
column11: and having less good properties that hold under wider conditions.|

column1: supervised-learning |Supervised learning is the machine learning task of inferring a function from labeled training data. The training data consist of a set of training examples. In supervised learning
column2: each example is a pair consisting of an input object (typically a vector) and a desired output value (also called the supervisory signal). A supervised learning algorithm analyzes the training data and produces an inferred function
column3: which can be used for mapping new examples. An optimal scenario will allow for the algorithm to correctly determine the class labels for unseen instances. This requires the learning algorithm to generalize from the training data to unseen situations in a "reasonable" way (see inductive bias).The parallel task in human and animal psychology is often referred to as concept learning.|

column2: the notion of permutation relates to the act of arranging all the members of a set into some sequence or order
column3: or if the set is already ordered
column4: rearranging (reordering) its elements
column5: a process called permuting. These differ from combinations
column6: which are selections of some members of a set where order is disregarded. For example
column7: written as tuples
column8: there are six permutations of the set {1
column11: namely: (1
column26: and (3
column28: 1). These are all the possible orderings of this three element set. As another example
column30: all of whose letters are different
column31: is a permutation of its letters. In this example
column32: the letters are already ordered in the original word and the anagram is a reordering of the letters. The study of permutations of finite sets is a topic in the field of combinatorics.Permutations occur
column33: in more or less prominent ways
column34: in almost every area of mathematics. They often arise when different orderings on certain finite sets are considered
column35: possibly only because one wants to ignore such orderings and needs to know how many configurations are thus identified. For similar reasons permutations arise in the study of sorting algorithms in computer science.The number of permutations of n distinct objects is n factorial
column37: which means the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n.In algebra and particularly in group theory
column38: a permutation of a set S is defined as a bijection from S to itself. That is
column39: it is a function from S to S for which every element occurs exactly once as an image value. This is related to the rearrangement of the elements of S in which each element s is replaced by the corresponding f(s). The collection of such permutations form a group called the symmetric group of S. The key to this group's structure is the fact that the composition of two permutations (performing two given rearrangements in succession) results in another rearrangement. Permutations may act on structured objects by rearranging their components
column40: or by certain replacements (substitutions) of symbols.In elementary combinatorics
column43: are the ordered arrangements of k distinct elements selected from a set. When k is equal to the size of the set
column44: these are the permutations of the set.|

column1: epidemiology |Epidemiology is the study and analysis of the patterns
column2: causes
column3: and effects of health and disease conditions in defined populations. It is the cornerstone of public health
column4: and shapes policy decisions and evidence-based practice by identifying risk factors for disease and targets for preventive healthcare. Epidemiologists help with study design
column5: collection
column6: and statistical analysis of data
column7: amend interpretation and dissemination of results (including peer review and occasional systematic review). Epidemiology has helped develop methodology used in clinical research
column8: public health studies
column9: and
column10: to a lesser extent
column11: basic research in the biological sciences.Major areas of epidemiological study include disease etiology
column12: transmission
column13: outbreak investigation
column14: disease surveillance
column15: forensic epidemiology and screening
column16: biomonitoring
column17: and comparisons of treatment effects such as in clinical trials. Epidemiologists rely on other scientific disciplines like biology to better understand disease processes
column18: statistics to make efficient use of the data and draw appropriate conclusions
column19: social sciences to better understand proximate and distal causes
column20: and engineering for exposure assessment.|

column2: to smooth a data set is to create an approximating function that attempts to capture important patterns in the data
column3: while leaving out noise or other fine-scale structures/rapid phenomena. In smoothing
column4: the data points of a signal are modified so individual points (presumably because of noise) are reduced
column5: and points that are lower than the adjacent points are increased leading to a smoother signal. Smoothing may be used in two important ways that can aid in data analysis (1) by being able to extract more information from the data as long as the assumption of smoothing is reasonable and (2) by being able to provide analyses that are both flexible and robust. Many different algorithms are used in smoothing.Smoothing may be distinguished from the related and partially overlapping concept of curve fitting in the following ways:curve fitting often involves the use of an explicit function form for the result
column6: whereas the immediate results from smoothing are the "smoothed" values with no later use made of a functional form if there is one;the aim of smoothing is to give a general idea of relatively slow changes of value with little attention paid to the close matching of data values
column7: while curve fitting concentrates on achieving as close a match as possible.smoothing methods often have an associated tuning parameter which is used to control the extent of smoothing. Curve fitting will adjust any number of parameters of the function to obtain the 'best' fit.However
column8: the terminology used across applications is mixed. For example
column9: use of an interpolating spline fits a smooth curve exactly through the given data points and is sometimes called "smoothing".|

column2: Bayes network
column3: belief network
column4: Bayes(ian) model or probabilistic directed acyclic graphical model is a probabilistic graphical model (a type of statistical model) that represents a set of random variables and their conditional dependencies via a directed acyclic graph (DAG). For example
column5: a Bayesian network could represent the probabilistic relationships between diseases and symptoms. Given symptoms
column6: the network can be used to compute the probabilities of the presence of various diseases.Formally
column7: Bayesian networks are DAGs whose nodes represent random variables in the Bayesian sense: they may be observable quantities
column8: latent variables
column9: unknown parameters or hypotheses. Edges represent conditional dependencies; nodes that are not connected (there is no path from one of the variables to the other in the Bayesian network) represent variables that are conditionally independent of each other. Each node is associated with a probability function that takes
column10: as input
column11: a particular set of values for the node's parent variables
column12: and gives (as output) the probability (or probability distribution
column13: if applicable) of the variable represented by the node. For example
column14: if                     m              {\displaystyle m}   parent nodes represent                     m              {\displaystyle m}   Boolean variables then the probability function could be represented by a table of                               2                      m                                {\displaystyle 2^{m}}   entries
column15: one entry for each of the                               2                      m                                {\displaystyle 2^{m}}   possible combinations of its parents being true or false. Similar ideas may be applied to undirected
column16: and possibly cyclic
column17: graphs; such are called Markov networks.Efficient algorithms exist that perform inference and learning in Bayesian networks. Bayesian networks that model sequences of variables (e.g. speech signals or protein sequences) are called dynamic Bayesian networks. Generalizations of Bayesian networks that can represent and solve decision problems under uncertainty are called influence diagrams.|

column2: a nonlinear system is a system in which the output is not directly proportional to the input. Nonlinear problems are of interest to engineers
column3: physicists and mathematicians and many other scientists because most systems are inherently nonlinear in nature. Nonlinear systems may appear chaotic
column4: unpredictable or counterintuitive
column5: contrasting with the much simpler linear systems.Typically
column6: the behavior of a nonlinear system is described in mathematics by a nonlinear system of equations
column7: which is a set of simultaneous equations in which the unknowns (or the unknown functions in the case of differential equations) appear as variables of a polynomial of degree higher than one or in the argument of a function which is not a polynomial of degree one. In other words
column8: in a nonlinear system of equations
column9: the equation(s) to be solved cannot be written as a linear combination of the unknown variables or functions that appear in them. It does not matter if nonlinear known functions appear in the equations. In particular
column10: a differential equation is linear if it is linear in terms of the unknown function and its derivatives
column11: even if nonlinear in terms of the other variables appearing in it.As nonlinear equations are difficult to solve
column12: nonlinear systems are commonly approximated by linear equations (linearization). This works well up to some accuracy and some range for the input values
column13: but some interesting phenomena such as solitons
column14: chaos and singularities are hidden by linearization. It follows that some aspects of the behavior of a nonlinear system appear commonly to be counterintuitive
column15: unpredictable or even chaotic. Although such chaotic behavior may resemble random behavior
column16: it is absolutely not random.For example
column17: some aspects of the weather are seen to be chaotic
column18: where simple changes in one part of the system produce complex effects throughout. This nonlinearity is one of the reasons why accurate long-term forecasts are impossible with current technology.Some authors use the term nonlinear science for the study of nonlinear systems. This is disputed by others:Using a term like nonlinear science is like referring to the bulk of zoology as the study of non-elephant animals.|

column1: model-comparison |Model selection is the task of selecting a statistical model from a set of candidate models
column2: given data. In the simplest cases
column3: a pre-existing set of data is considered. However
column4: the task can also involve the design of experiments such that the data collected is well-suited to the problem of model selection. Given candidate models of similar predictive or explanatory power
column5: the simplest model is most likely to be the best choice.Konishi & Kitagawa (2008
column6: p. 75) state
column7: "The majority of the problems in statistical inference can be considered to be problems related to statistical modeling". Relatedly
column8: Sir David Cox (2006
column9: p. 197) has said
column10: "How [the] translation from subject-matter problem to statistical model is done is often the most critical part of an analysis".|

column1: approximation |An approximation is anything that is similar but not exactly equal to something else.|

combinatorics |Combinatorics is a branch of mathematics concerning the study of finite or countable discrete structures. Aspects of combinatorics include counting the structures of a given kind and size (enumerative combinatorics)
column2: deciding when certain criteria can be met
column3: and constructing and analyzing objects meeting the criteria (as in combinatorial designs and matroid theory)
column4: finding "largest"
column5: "smallest"
column6: or "optimal" objects (extremal combinatorics and combinatorial optimization)
column7: and studying combinatorial structures arising in an algebraic context
column8: or applying algebraic techniques to combinatorial problems (algebraic combinatorics).Combinatorial problems arise in many areas of pure mathematics
column9: notably in algebra
column10: probability theory
column11: topology
column12: and geometry
column13: and combinatorics also has many applications in mathematical optimization
column14: computer science
column15: ergodic theory and statistical physics. Many combinatorial questions have historically been considered in isolation
column16: giving an ad hoc solution to a problem arising in some mathematical context. In the later twentieth century
column17: however
column18: powerful and general theoretical methods were developed
column19: making combinatorics into an independent branch of mathematics in its own right. One of the oldest and most accessible parts of combinatorics is graph theory
column20: which also has numerous natural connections to other areas. Combinatorics is used frequently in computer science to obtain formulas and estimates in the analysis of algorithms.A mathematician who studies combinatorics is called a combinatorialist or a combinatorist.|

column2: specifically predictive inference
column3: a prediction interval is an estimate of an interval in which future observations will fall
column4: with a certain probability
column5: given what has already been observed. Prediction intervals are often used in regression analysis.Prediction intervals are used in both frequentist statistics and Bayesian statistics: a prediction interval bears the same relationship to a future observation that a frequentist confidence interval or Bayesian credible interval bears to an unobservable population parameter: prediction intervals predict the distribution of individual future points
column6: whereas confidence intervals and credible intervals of parameters predict the distribution of estimates of the true population mean or other quantity of interest that cannot be observed.|

column1: measurement |Measurement is the assignment of a number to a characteristic of an object or event
column2: which can be compared with other objects or events. The scope and application of a measurement is dependent on the context and discipline. In the natural sciences and engineering
column3: measurements do not apply to nominal properties of objects or events
column4: which is consistent with the guidelines of the International vocabulary of metrology published by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures. However
column5: in other fields such as statistics as well as the social and behavioral sciences
column6: measurements can have multiple levels
column7: which would include nominal
column8: ordinal
column9: interval
column10: and ratio scales.Measurement is a cornerstone of trade
column11: science
column12: technology
column13: and quantitative research in many disciplines. Historically
column14: many measurement systems existed for the varied fields of human existence to facilitate comparisons in these fields. Often these were achieved by local agreements between trading partners or collaborators. Since the 18th century
column15: developments progressed towards unifying
column16: widely accepted standards that resulted in the modern International System of Units (SI). This system reduces all physical measurements to a mathematical combination of seven base units. The science of measurement is pursued in the field of metrology.|

column1: f-test |An F-test is any statistical test in which the test statistic has an F-distribution under the null hypothesis. It is most often used when comparing statistical models that have been fitted to a data set
column2: in order to identify the model that best fits the population from which the data were sampled. Exact "F-tests" mainly arise when the models have been fitted to the data using least squares. The name was coined by George W. Snedecor
column3: in honour of Sir Ronald A. Fisher. Fisher initially developed the statistic as the variance ratio in the 1920s.|

column1: graph-theory |In mathematics graph theory is the study of graphs
column2: which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects. A graph in this context is made up of vertices
column3: nodes
column4: or points which are connected by edges
column5: arcs
column6: or lines. A graph may be undirected
column7: meaning that there is no distinction between the two vertices associated with each edge
column8: or its edges may be directed from one vertex to another; see Graph (discrete mathematics) for more detailed definitions and for other variations in the types of graph that are commonly considered. Graphs are one of the prime objects of study in discrete mathematics.Refer to the glossary of graph theory for basic definitions in graph theory.|

column2: the kth order statistic of a statistical sample is equal to its kth-smallest value. Together with rank statistics
column3: order statistics are among the most fundamental tools in non-parametric statistics and inference.Important special cases of the order statistics are the minimum and maximum value of a sample
column4: and (with some qualifications discussed below) the sample median and other sample quantiles.When using probability theory to analyze order statistics of random samples from a continuous distribution
column5: the cumulative distribution function is used to reduce the analysis to the case of order statistics of the uniform distribution.|

column2: structured
column3: interactive process where a neutral third party assists disputing parties in resolving conflict through the use of specialized communication and negotiation techniques. All participants in mediation are encouraged to actively participate in the process. Mediation is a "party-centered" process in that it is focused primarily upon the needs
column4: rights
column5: and interests of the parties. The mediator uses a wide variety of techniques to guide the process in a constructive direction and to help the parties find their optimal solution. A mediator is facilitative in that s/he manages the interaction between parties and facilitates open communication. Mediation is also evaluative in that the mediator analyzes issues and relevant norms ("reality-testing)
column6: while refraining from providing prescriptive advice to the parties (e.g.
column7: "You should do... ."). In some countries like Germany mediators have to act purely facilitative. They are not supposed to evaluative the conflict with regard to the law and are not allowed to give legal advice. Further
column8: mediators are not even allowed to suggest a solution with regard to the content of the conflict
column9: but have to support the parties to find their solution only by "mediative interventions".[1]Mediation
column10: as used in law
column11: is a form of alternative dispute resolution (ADR)
column12: a way of resolving disputes between two or more parties with concrete effects. Typically
column13: a third party
column14: the mediator
column15: assists the parties to negotiate a settlement. Disputants may mediate disputes in a variety of domains
column16: such as commercial
column17: legal
column18: diplomatic
column19: workplace
column20: community and family matters.The term "mediation" broadly refers to any instance in which a third party helps others reach agreement. More specifically
column21: mediation has a structure
column22: timetable and dynamics that "ordinary" negotiation lacks. The process is private and confidential
column23: possibly enforced by law. Participation is typically voluntary. The mediator acts as a neutral third party and facilitates rather than directs the process. Mediation is becoming a more peaceful and internationally accepted solution in order to end conflict. Mediation can be used to resolve disputes of any magnitude.Mediators use various techniques to open
column24: or improve
column25: dialogue and empathy between disputants
column26: aiming to help the parties reach an agreement. Much depends on the mediator's skill and training. As the practice gained popularity
column27: training programs
column30: professional mediators committed to the discipline.The benefits of mediation include:Cost While a mediator may charge a fee comparable to that of an attorney
column31: the mediation process generally takes much less time than moving a case through standard legal channels. While a case in the hands of a lawyer or a court may take months or years to resolve
column32: mediation usually achieves a resolution in a matter of hours. Taking less time means expending less money on hourly fees and costs.Confidentiality While court hearings are public
column33: mediation remains strictly confidential. No one but the parties to the dispute and the mediator or mediators know what happened. Confidentiality in mediation has such importance that in most cases the legal system cannot force a mediator to testify in court as to the content or progress of mediation. Many mediators destroy their notes taken during a mediation once that mediation has finished. The only exceptions to such strict confidentiality usually involve child abuse or actual or threatened criminal acts.Control Mediation increases the control the parties have over the resolution. In a court case
column35: but control resides with the judge or jury. Often
column36: a judge or jury cannot legally provide solutions that emerge in mediation. Thus
column37: mediation is more likely to produce a result that is mutually agreeable for the parties.Compliance Because the result is attained by the parties working together and is mutually agreeable
column38: compliance with the mediated agreement is usually high. This further reduces costs
column39: because the parties do not have to employ an attorney to force compliance with the agreement. The mediated agreement is
column41: fully enforceable in a court of law.Mutuality Parties to a mediation are typically ready to work mutually toward a resolution. In most circumstances the mere fact that parties are willing to mediate means that they are ready to "move" their position. The parties thus are more amenable to understanding the other party's side and work on underlying issues to the dispute. This has the added benefit of often preserving the relationship the parties had before the dispute.Support Mediators are trained in working with difficult situations. The mediator acts as a neutral facilitator and guides the parties through the process. The mediator helps the parties think "outside of the box" for possible solutions to the dispute
column42: broadening the range of possible solutions.|

column1: uncertainty |Uncertainty is a situation which involves imperfect and/or unknown information. However
column2: "uncertainty is an unintelligible expression without a straightforward description". It arises in subtly different ways in a number of fields
column3: including insurance
column4: philosophy
column5: physics
column6: statistics
column7: economics
column8: finance
column9: psychology
column10: sociology
column11: engineering
column12: metrology
column13: and information science. It applies to predictions of future events
column14: to physical measurements that are already made
column15: or to the unknown. Uncertainty arises in partially observable and/or stochastic environments
column16: as well as due to ignorance and/or indolence.|

column1: regression-strategies |Regression testing is a type of software testing that verifies that software previously developed and tested still performs correctly even after it was changed or interfaced with other software. Changes may include software enhancements
column2: patches
column3: configuration changes
column4: etc. During regression testing
column5: new software bugs or regressions may be uncovered. Sometimes a software change impact analysis is performed to determine what areas could be affected by the proposed changes. These areas may include functional and non-functional areas of the system.The purpose of regression testing is to ensure that changes such as those mentioned above have not introduced new faults. One of the main reasons for regression testing is to determine whether a change in one part of the software affects other parts of the software.Common methods of regression testing include re-running previously completed tests and checking whether program behavior has changed and whether previously fixed faults have re-emerged. Regression testing can be performed to test a system efficiently by systematically selecting the appropriate minimum set of tests needed to adequately cover a particular change.Contrast with non-regression testing (usually validation-test for a new issue)
column6: which aims to verify whether
column7: after introducing or updating a given software application
column8: the change has had the intended effect.|

column1: frequentist |Frequentist inference is a type of statistical inference that draws conclusions from sample data by emphasizing the frequency or proportion of the data. An alternative name is frequentist statistics. This is the inference framework in which the well-established methodologies of statistical hypothesis testing and confidence intervals are based. Other than frequentistic inference
column2: the main alternative approach to statistical inference is Bayesian inference
