column3: while another is fiducial inference.While "Bayesian inference" is sometimes held to include the approach to inference leading to optimal decisions
column4: a more restricted view is taken here for simplicity.|

column1: weighted-regression |LOESS and LOWESS (locally weighted scatterplot smoothing) are two strongly related non-parametric regression methods that combine multiple regression models in a k-nearest-neighbor-based meta-model. "LOESS" is a later generalization of LOWESS; although it is not a true initialism
column2: it may be understood as standing for "LOcal regrESSion".LOESS and LOWESS thus build on "classical" methods
column3: such as linear and nonlinear least squares regression. They address situations in which the classical procedures do not perform well or cannot be effectively applied without undue labor. LOESS combines much of the simplicity of linear least squares regression with the flexibility of nonlinear regression. It does this by fitting simple models to localized subsets of the data to build up a function that describes the deterministic part of the variation in the data
column4: point by point. In fact
column5: one of the chief attractions of this method is that the data analyst is not required to specify a global function of any form to fit a model to the data
column6: only to fit segments of the data.The trade-off for these features is increased computation. Because it is so computationally intensive
column7: LOESS would have been practically impossible to use in the era when least squares regression was being developed. Most other modern methods for process modeling are similar to LOESS in this respect. These methods have been consciously designed to use our current computational ability to the fullest possible advantage to achieve goals not easily achieved by traditional approaches.A smooth curve through a set of data points obtained with this statistical technique is called a Loess Curve
column8: particularly when each smoothed value is given by a weighted quadratic least squares regression over the span of values of the y-axis scattergram criterion variable. When each smoothed value is given by a weighted linear least squares regression over the span
column9: this is known as a Lowess curve; however
column10: some authorities treat Lowess and Loess as synonyms.|

column1: reinforcement-learning |Reinforcement learning is an area of machine learning inspired by behaviorist psychology
column2: concerned with how software agents ought to take actions in an environment so as to maximize some notion of cumulative reward. The problem
column3: due to its generality
column4: is studied in many other disciplines
column5: such as game theory
column6: control theory
column7: operations research
column8: information theory
column9: simulation-based optimization
column10: multi-agent systems
column11: swarm intelligence
column12: statistics
column13: and genetic algorithms. In the operations research and control literature
column14: the field where reinforcement learning methods are studied is called approximate dynamic programming. The problem has been studied in the theory of optimal control
column15: though most studies are concerned with the existence of optimal solutions and their characterization
column16: and not with the learning or approximation aspects. In economics and game theory
column17: reinforcement learning may be used to explain how equilibrium may arise under bounded rationality.In machine learning
column18: the environment is typically formulated as a Markov decision process (MDP) as many reinforcement learning algorithms for this context utilize dynamic programming techniques. The main difference between the classical techniques and reinforcement learning algorithms is that the latter do not need knowledge about the MDP and they target large MDPs where exact methods become infeasible.Reinforcement learning differs from standard supervised learning in that correct input/output pairs are never presented
column19: nor sub-optimal actions explicitly corrected. Further
column20: there is a focus on on-line performance
column21: which involves finding a balance between exploration (of uncharted territory) and exploitation (of current knowledge). The exploration vs. exploitation trade-off in reinforcement learning has been most thoroughly studied through the multi-armed bandit problem and in finite MDPs.|

column1: mutual-information |In probability theory and information theory
column2: the mutual information (MI) of two random variables is a measure of the mutual dependence between the two variables. More specifically
column3: it quantifies the "amount of information" (in units such as bits) obtained about one random variable
column4: through the other random variable. The concept of mutual information is intricately linked to that of entropy of a random variable
column5: a fundamental notion in information theory
column6: that defines the "amount of information" held in a random variable.Not limited to real-valued random variables like the correlation coefficient
column7: MI is more general and determines how similar the joint distribution p(X
column8: Y) is to the products of factored marginal distribution p(X)p(Y). MI is the expected value of the pointwise mutual information (PMI). The most common unit of measurement of mutual information is the bit.|

column2: a stationary process (or strict(ly) stationary process or strong(ly) stationary process) is a stochastic process whose joint probability distribution does not change when shifted in time. Consequently
column3: parameters such as mean and variance
column4: if they are present
column5: also do not change over time.Since stationarity is an assumption underlying many statistical procedures used in time series analysis
column6: non-stationary data is often transformed to become stationary. The most common cause of violation of Stationarity are trends in mean
column7: which can be due either to the presence of a unit root or of a deterministic trend. In the latter case the process is called trend stationary process
column8: stochastic shocks have only transitory effects
column9: and the process is mean-reverting (on a mean which changes deterministically over time). On the contrary
column10: in the first case stochastic shocks have permanent effects and the process is not mean-reverting. A trend stationary process is not strictly stationary
column11: but can easily be made such by removing the underlying trend (function solely of time). Similarly
column12: processes with one or more unit roots can be made stationary through differencing. An important type of non-stationary process that does not include a trend-like behavior is the cyclostationary process.A "stationary process" is not the same thing as a "process with a stationary distribution". Indeed
column13: there are further possibilities for confusion with the use of "stationary" in the context of stochastic processes; for example a "time-homogeneous" Markov chain is sometimes said to have "stationary transition probabilities". Besides
column14: all stationary Markov random processes are time-homogeneous.|

column2: stepwise regression includes regression models in which the choice of predictive variables is carried out by an automatic procedure.  Usually
column3: this takes the form of a sequence of F-tests or t-tests
column4: but other techniques are possible
column5: such as adjusted R2
column6: Akaike information criterion
column7: Bayesian information criterion
column8: Mallows's Cp
column9: PRESS
column10: or false discovery rate.The frequent practice of fitting the final selected model followed by reporting estimates and confidence intervals without adjusting them to take the model building process into account has led to calls to stop using stepwise model building altogether or to at least make sure model uncertainty is correctly reflected.|

column1: multivariate-regression |The general linear model is a statistical linear model. It may be written as  {\displaystyle \mathbf {Y} =\mathbf {X} \mathbf {B} +\mathbf {U}
column2: }  where Y is a matrix with series of multivariate measurements
column3: X is a matrix that might be a design matrix
column4: B is a matrix containing parameters that are usually to be estimated and U is a matrix containing errors or noise. The errors are usually assumed to be uncorrelated across measurements
column5: and follow a multivariate normal distribution. If the errors do not follow a multivariate normal distribution
column6: generalized linear models may be used to relax assumptions about Y and U.The general linear model incorporates a number of different statistical models: ANOVA
column7: ANCOVA
column8: MANOVA
column9: MANCOVA
column10: ordinary linear regression
column11: t-test and F-test. The general linear model is a generalization of multiple linear regression model to the case of more than one dependent variable. If Y
column12: B
column13: and U were column vectors
column14: the matrix equation above would represent multiple linear regression.Hypothesis tests with the general linear model can be made in two ways: multivariate or as several independent univariate tests. In multivariate tests the columns of Y are tested together
column15: whereas in univariate tests the columns of Y are tested independently
column16: i.e.
column17: as multiple univariate tests with the same design matrix.|

column2: the multivariate normal distribution or multivariate Gaussian distribution
column3: is a generalization of the one-dimensional (univariate) normal distribution to higher dimensions. One possible definition is that a random vector is said to be k-variate normally distributed if every linear combination of its k components has a univariate normal distribution. Its importance derives mainly from the multivariate central limit theorem. The multivariate normal distribution is often used to describe
column4: at least approximately
column5: any set of (possibly) correlated real-valued random variables each of which clusters around a mean value.|

column1: topic-models |In machine learning and natural language processing
column2: a topic model is a type of statistical model for discovering the abstract "topics" that occur in a collection of documents. Topic modeling is a frequently used text-mining tool for discovery of hidden semantic structures in a text body. Intuitively
column3: given that a document is about a particular topic
column4: one would expect particular words to appear in the document more or less frequently: "dog" and "bone" will appear more often in documents about dogs
column5: "cat" and "meow" will appear in documents about cats
column6: and "the" and "is" will appear equally in both. A document typically concerns multiple topics in different proportions; thus
column7: in a document that is 10% about cats and 90% about dogs
column8: there would probably be about 9 times more dog words than cat words. The "topics" produced by topic modeling techniques are clusters of similar words. A topic model captures this intuition in a mathematical framework
column9: which allows examining a set of documents and discovering
column10: based on the statistics of the words in each
column11: what the topics might be and what each document's balance of topics is.Topic models are also referred to as probabilistic topic models
column12: which refers to statistic algorithms for discovering the latent semantic structures of an extensive text body. In the age of information
column13: the amount of the written material we encounter each day is simply beyond our processing capacity. Topic models can help to organize and offer insights for us to understand large collections of unstructured text bodies. Originally developed as a text-mining tool
column14: topic models have been used to detect instructive structures in data such as genetic information
column15: images
column16: and networks. They also have applications in other fields such as bioinformatics.|

column1: difference-in-difference |Difference in differences (sometimes abbreviated DID or DD) is a statistical technique used in econometrics and quantitative research in the social sciences that attempts to mimic an experimental research design using observational study data
column2: by studying the differential effect of a treatment on a 'treatment group' versus a 'control group' in a natural experiment. It calculates the effect of a treatment (i.e.
column3: an explanatory variable or an independent variable) on an outcome (i.e.
column4: a response variable or dependent variable) by comparing the average change over time in the outcome variable for the treatment group
column5: compared to the average change over time for the control group. Although it is intended to mitigate the effects of extraneous factors and selection bias
column6: depending on how the treatment group is chosen
column7: this method may still be subject to certain biases (e.g. mean regression
column8: reverse causality and omitted variable bias).In contrast to a time-series estimate of the treatment effect on subjects (which analyzes differences over time) or a cross-section estimate of the treatment effect (which measures the difference between treatment and control groups)
column9: difference in differences uses panel data to measure the differences
column10: between the treatment and control group
column11: of the changes in the outcome variable that occur over time.|

column2: inter-rater reliability
column3: inter-rater agreement
column4: or concordance is the degree of agreement among raters. It gives a score of how much homogeneity
column5: or consensus
column6: there is in the ratings given by judges. It is useful in refining the tools given to human judges
column7: for example by determining if a particular scale is appropriate for measuring a particular variable. If various raters do not agree
column8: either the scale is defective or the raters need to be re-trained.There are a number of statistics which can be used to determine inter-rater reliability. Different statistics are appropriate for different types of measurement. Some options are: joint-probability of agreement
column9: Cohen's kappa and the related Fleiss' kappa
column10: inter-rater correlation
column11: concordance correlation coefficient and intra-class correlation.|

column2: the intraclass correlation (or the intraclass correlation coefficient
column3: abbreviated ICC) is an inferential statistic that can be used when quantitative measurements are made on units that are organized into groups. It describes how strongly units in the same group resemble each other. While it is viewed as a type of correlation
column4: unlike most other correlation measures it operates on data structured as groups
column5: rather than data structured as paired observations.The intraclass correlation is commonly used to quantify the degree to which individuals with a fixed degree of relatedness (e.g. full siblings) resemble each other in terms of a quantitative trait (see heritability). Another prominent application is the assessment of consistency or reproducibility of quantitative measurements made by different observers measuring the same quantity.|

column1: multidimensional-scaling |Multidimensional scaling (MDS) is a means of visualizing the level of similarity of individual cases of a dataset. It refers to a set of related ordination techniques used in information visualization
column2: in particular to display the information contained in a distance matrix. An MDS algorithm aims to place each object in N-dimensional space such that the between-object distances are preserved as well as possible. Each object is then assigned coordinates in each of the N dimensions. The number of dimensions of an MDS plot N can exceed 2 and is specified a priori. Choosing N=2 optimizes the object locations for a two-dimensional scatterplot.|

column1: decision-theory |Decision theory (or the theory of choice) is the study of the reasoning underlying an agent's choices. Decision theory can be broken into two branches: normative decision theory
column2: which gives advice on how to make the best decisions
column3: given a set of uncertain beliefs and a set of values; and descriptive decision theory
column4: which analyzes how existing
column5: possibly irrational agents actually make decisions.Closely related to the field of game theory
column6: decision theory is concerned with the choices of individual agents whereas game theory is concerned with interactions of agents whose decisions affect each other. Decision theory is an interdisciplinary topic
column7: studied by economists
column8: statisticians
column9: psychologists
column10: political and social scientists
column11: and philosophers.|

column1: quantile-regression |Quantile regression is a type of regression analysis used in statistics and econometrics. Whereas the method of least squares results in estimates that approximate the conditional mean of the response variable given certain values of the predictor variables
column2: quantile regression aims at estimating either the conditional median or other quantiles of the response variable.|

column1: matrix-decomposition |In the mathematical discipline of linear algebra
column2: a matrix decomposition or matrix factorization is a factorization of a matrix into a product of matrices. There are many different matrix decompositions; each finds use among a particular class of problems.|
in particular
column3: functional analysis) convolution is a mathematical operation on two functions (f and g); it produces a third function
column4: that is typically viewed as a modified version of one of the original functions
column5: giving the integral of the pointwise multiplication of the two functions as a function of the amount that one of the original functions is translated. Convolution is similar to cross-correlation. It has applications that include probability
column6: statistics
column7: computer vision
column8: natural language processing
column9: image and signal processing
column10: engineering
column11: and differential equations.The convolution can be defined for functions on groups other than Euclidean space. For example
column12: periodic functions
column13: such as the discrete-time Fourier transform
column14: can be defined on a circle and convolved by periodic convolution. (See row 10 at DTFT#Properties.)  A discrete convolution can be defined for functions on the set of integers. Generalizations of convolution have applications in the field of numerical analysis and numerical linear algebra
column15: and in the design and implementation of finite impulse response filters in signal processing.Computing the inverse of the convolution operation is known as deconvolution.|

column2: a box plot or boxplot is a convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. Box plots may also have lines extending vertically from the boxes (whiskers) indicating variability outside the upper and lower quartiles
column3: hence the terms box-and-whisker plot and box-and-whisker diagram. Outliers may be plotted as individual points. Box plots are non-parametric: they display variation in samples of a statistical population without making any assumptions of the underlying statistical distribution. The spacings between the different parts of the box indicate the degree of dispersion (spread) and skewness in the data
column4: and show outliers. In addition to the points themselves
column5: they allow one to visually estimate various L-estimators
column6: notably the interquartile range
column7: midhinge
column8: range
column9: mid-range
column10: and trimean. Box plots can be drawn either horizontally or vertically.|

column2: autoassociator or Diabolo network is an artificial neural network used for unsupervised learning of efficient codings. The aim of an autoencoder is to learn a representation (encoding) for a set of data
column3: typically for the purpose of dimensionality reduction. Recently
column4: the autoencoder concept has become more widely used for learning generative models of data.|

column1: randomization |Randomization is the process of making something random; in various contexts this involves
column2: for example:generating a random permutation of a sequence (such as when shuffling cards);selecting a random sample of a population (important in statistical sampling);allocating experimental units via random assignment to a treatment or control condition;generating random numbers (see Random number generation); ortransforming a data stream (such as when using a scrambler in telecommunications).Randomization is not haphazard. Instead
column3: a random process is a sequence of random variables describing a process whose outcomes do not follow a deterministic pattern
column4: but follow an evolution described by probability distributions. For example
column5: a random sample of individuals from a population refers to a sample where every individual has a known probability of being sampled. This would be contrasted with nonprobability sampling where arbitrary individuals are selected.|

column1: weighted-mean |The weighted arithmetic mean is similar to an ordinary arithmetic mean (the most common type of average)
column2: except that instead of each of the data points contributing equally to the final average
column3: some data points contribute more than others. The notion of weighted mean plays a role in descriptive statistics and also occurs in a more general form in several other areas of mathematics.If all the weights are equal
column4: then the weighted mean is the same as the arithmetic mean. While weighted means generally behave in a similar fashion to arithmetic means
column5: they do have a few counterintuitive properties
column6: as captured for instance in Simpson's paradox.|

column2: a percentage is a number or ratio expressed as a fraction of 100. It is often denoted using the percent sign
column4: or the abbreviations "pct."
column5: "pct"; sometimes the abbreviation "pc" is also used. A percentage is a dimensionless number (pure number).|

column2: statistics and elsewhere
column3: sums of squares occur in a number of contexts:|

column2: a ratio is a relationship between two numbers indicating how many times the first number contains the second. For example
column3: if a bowl of fruit contains eight oranges and six lemons
column4: then the ratio of oranges to lemons is eight to six (that is
column6: which is equivalent to the ratio 4:3). Thus
column7: a ratio can be a fraction as opposed to a whole number. Also
column8: in this example the ratio of lemons to oranges is 6:8 (or 3:4)
column9: and the ratio of oranges to the total amount of fruit is 8:14 (or 4:7).The numbers compared in a ratio can be any quantities of a comparable kind
column10: such as objects
column11: persons
column12: lengths
column13: or spoonfuls. A ratio is written "a to b" or a:b
column14: or sometimes expressed arithmetically as a quotient of the two. When the two quantities have the same units
column15: as is often the case
column16: their ratio is a dimensionless number. A rate is a quotient of variables having different units. But in many applications
column17: the word ratio is often used instead for this more general notion as well.|

column1: false-discovery-rate |The false discovery rate (FDR) is one way of conceptualizing the rate of type I errors in null hypothesis testing when conducting multiple comparisons. FDR-controlling procedures are designed to control the expected proportion of "discoveries" (rejected null hypotheses) that are false (incorrect rejections). FDR-controlling procedures provide less stringent control of Type I errors compared to familywise error rate (FWER) controlling procedures (such as the Bonferroni correction)
column2: which control the probability of at least one Type I error. Thus
column3: FDR-controlling procedures have greater power
column4: at the cost of increased rates of Type I errors.|

column1: extreme-value |Extreme value theory or extreme value analysis (EVA) is a branch of statistics dealing with the extreme deviations from the median of probability distributions. It seeks to assess
column2: from a given ordered sample of a given random variable
column3: the probability of events that are more extreme than any previously observed. Extreme value analysis is widely used in many disciplines
column4: such as structural engineering
column5: finance
column6: earth sciences
column7: traffic prediction
column8: and geological engineering. For example
column9: EVA might be used in the field of hydrology to estimate the probability of an unusually large flooding event
column10: such as the 100-year flood. Similarly
column11: for the design of a breakwater
column12: a coastal engineer would seek to estimate the 50-year wave and design the structure accordingly.|

column2: a Markov chain or Markoff chain
column3: named after the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov
column4: is a stochastic process that satisfies the Markov property (usually characterized as "memorylessness"). Loosely speaking
column5: a process satisfies the Markov property if one can make predictions for the future of the process based solely on its present state just as well as one could knowing the process's full history. i.e.
column6: conditional on the present state of the system
column7: its future and past are independent.In discrete time
column8: the process is known as a discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC). It undergoes transitions from one state to another on a state space
column9: with the probability distribution of the next state depending only on the current state and not on the sequence of events that preceded it.In continuous time
column10: the process is known as a Continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC[1] or continuous-time Markov process[2]). It takes values in some state space and the time spent in each state takes non-negative real values and has an exponential distribution. Future behaviour of the model (both remaining time in current state and next state) depends only on the current state of the model and not on historical behaviour.Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes.|

column2: generalized least squares (GLS) is a technique for estimating the unknown parameters in a linear regression model. GLS can be used to perform linear regression when there is a certain degree of correlation between the residuals in a regression model. In these cases
column3: ordinary least squares and weighted least squares can be statistically inefficient
column4: or even give misleading inferences. GLS was first described by Alexander Aitken in 1934.|

column2: a covariate is a variable that is possibly predictive of the outcome under study. A covariate may be of direct interest or it may be a confounding or interacting variable.The alternative terms explanatory variable
column3: independent variable
column4: or predictor
column5: are used in a regression analysis. In econometrics
column6: the term "control variable" is usually used instead of "covariate". An example is provided by the analysis of trend in sea level by Woodworth (1987). Here the dependent variable (and variable of most interest) was the annual mean sea level at a given location for which a series of yearly values were available. The primary independent variable was time. Use was made of a covariate consisting of yearly values of annual mean atmospheric pressure at sea level. The results showed that inclusion of the covariate allowed improved estimates of the trend against time to be obtained
column7: compared to analyses which omitted the covariate.|

column1: randomness |Randomness is the lack of pattern or predictability in events. A random sequence of events
column2: symbols or steps has no order and does not follow an intelligible pattern or combination. Individual random events are by definition unpredictable
column3: but in many cases the frequency of different outcomes over a large number of events (or "trials") is predictable. For example
column4: when throwing two dice
column5: the outcome of any particular roll is unpredictable
column6: but a sum of 7 will occur twice as often as 4. In this view
column7: randomness is a measure of uncertainty of an outcome
column8: rather than haphazardness
column9: and applies to concepts of chance
column10: probability
column11: and information entropy.The fields of mathematics
column12: probability
column13: and statistics use formal definitions of randomness. In statistics
column14: a random variable is an assignment of a numerical value to each possible outcome of an event space. This association facilitates the identification and the calculation of probabilities of the events. Random variables can appear in random sequences. A random process is a sequence of random variables whose outcomes do not follow a deterministic pattern
column15: but follow an evolution described by probability distributions. These and other constructs are extremely useful in probability theory and the various applications of randomness.Randomness is most often used in statistics to signify well-defined statistical properties. Monte Carlo methods
column16: which rely on random input (such as from random number generators or pseudorandom number generators)
column17: are important techniques in science
column18: as
column19: for instance
column20: in computational science. By analogy
column21: quasi-Monte Carlo methods use quasirandom number generators.Random selection is a method of selecting items (often called units) from a population where the probability of choosing a specific item is the proportion of those items in the population. For example
column22: with a bowl containing just 10 red marbles and 90 blue marbles
column23: a random selection mechanism would choose a red marble with probability 1/10. Note that a random selection mechanism that selected 10 marbles from this bowl would not necessarily result in 1 red and 9 blue. In situations where a population consists of items that are distinguishable
column24: a random selection mechanism requires equal probabilities for any item to be chosen. That is
column25: if the selection process is such that each member of a population
column26: of say research subjects
column27: has the same probability of being chosen then we can say the selection process is random.|

column1: granger-causality |The Granger causality test is a statistical hypothesis test for determining whether one time series is useful in forecasting another
column2: first proposed in 1969. Ordinarily
column3: regressions reflect "mere" correlations
column4: but Clive Granger argued that causality in economics could be tested for by measuring the ability to predict the future values of a time series using prior values of another time series. Since the question of "true causality" is deeply philosophical
column5: and because of the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy of assuming that one thing preceding another can be used as a proof of causation
column6: econometricians assert that the Granger test finds only "predictive causality".A time series X is said to Granger-cause Y if it can be shown
column7: usually through a series of t-tests and F-tests on lagged values of X (and with lagged values of Y also included)
column8: that those X values provide statistically significant information about future values of Y.Granger also stressed that some studies using "Granger causality" testing in areas outside economics reached "ridiculous" conclusions. "Of course
column9: many ridiculous papers appeared"
column10: he said in his Nobel lecture. However
column11: it remains a popular method for causality analysis in time series due to its computational simplicity. The original definition of Granger causality does not account for latent confounding effects and does not capture instantaneous and non-linear causal relationships
column12: though several extensions have been proposed to address these issues.|

column1: weighted-sampling |The weighted arithmetic mean is similar to an ordinary arithmetic mean (the most common type of average)
column2: except that instead of each of the data points contributing equally to the final average
column3: some data points contribute more than others. The notion of weighted mean plays a role in descriptive statistics and also occurs in a more general form in several other areas of mathematics.If all the weights are equal
column4: then the weighted mean is the same as the arithmetic mean. While weighted means generally behave in a similar fashion to arithmetic means
column5: they do have a few counterintuitive properties
column6: as captured for instance in Simpson's paradox.|

column2: a moving average (rolling average or running average) is a calculation to analyze data points by creating series of averages of different subsets of the full data set. It is also called a moving mean (MM) or rolling mean and is a type of finite impulse response filter. Variations include: simple
column3: and cumulative
column4: or weighted forms (described below).Given a series of numbers and a fixed subset size
column5: the first element of the moving average is obtained by taking the average of the initial fixed subset of the number series. Then the subset is modified by "shifting forward"; that is
column6: excluding the first number of the series and including the next number following the original subset in the series. This creates a new subset of numbers
column7: which is averaged. This process is repeated over the entire data series. The plot line connecting all the (fixed) averages is the moving average. A moving average is a set of numbers
column8: each of which is the average of the corresponding subset of a larger set of datum points. A moving average may also use unequal weights for each datum value in the subset to emphasize particular values in the subset.A moving average is commonly used with time series data to smooth out short-term fluctuations and highlight longer-term trends or cycles. The threshold between short-term and long-term depends on the application
column9: and the parameters of the moving average will be set accordingly. For example
column10: it is often used in technical analysis of financial data
column11: like stock prices
column12: returns or trading volumes. It is also used in economics to examine gross domestic product
column13: employment or other macroeconomic time series. Mathematically
column14: a moving average is a type of convolution and so it can be viewed as an example of a low-pass filter used in signal processing. When used with non-time series data
column15: a moving average filters higher frequency components without any specific connection to time
column16: although typically some kind of ordering is implied. Viewed simplistically it can be regarded as smoothing the data.|

column6: adequality
column7: for finding the maxima and minima of functions.As defined in set theory
column8: the maximum and minimum of a set are the greatest and least elements in the set

column1: scipy |SciPy (pronounced "Sigh Pie") is an open source Python library used for scientific computing and technical computing.SciPy contains modules for optimization
column2: linear algebra
column3: integration
column4: interpolation
column5: special functions
column6: FFT
column7: signal and image processing
column8: ODE solvers and other tasks common in science and engineering.SciPy builds on the NumPy array object and is part of the NumPy stack which includes tools like Matplotlib
column9: pandas and SymPy. There is an expanding set of scientific computing libraries that are being added to the NumPy stack every day. This NumPy stack has similar users to other applications such as MATLAB
column10: GNU Octave
column11: and Scilab. The NumPy stack is also sometimes referred to as the SciPy stack.SciPy is also a family of conferences for users and developers of these tools: SciPy (in the United States)
column12: EuroSciPy (in Europe) and SciPy.in (in India). Enthought originated the SciPy conference in the United States and continues to sponsor many of the international conferences as well as host the SciPy website.The SciPy library is currently distributed under the BSD license
column13: and its development is sponsored and supported by an open community of developers. It is also supported by Numfocus which is a community foundation for supporting reproducible and accessible science.|

column2: in particular
column3: in the fitting of linear or logistic regression models
column4: the elastic net is a regularized regression method that linearly combines the L1 and L2 penalties of the lasso and ridge methods.|

column2: the standard score is the signed number of standard deviations by which an observation or data is above the mean. A standard score is a derived score
column3: used for making norm-referenced interpretations
column4: for which the mean and standard deviation are selected to simplify interpretations. Some common standard scores and their corresponding mean and standard deviation are: ACT scores (18 and 5)
column5: SAT scores (500 and 100)
column6: T-scores (50 and 10)
column7: and z-scores (0.0 and 1.0). A positive standard score indicates a datum above the mean
column8: while a negative standard score indicates a datum below the mean. It is a dimensionless quantity obtained by subtracting the population mean from an individual raw score and then dividing the difference by the population standard deviation. This conversion process is called standardizing or normalizing (however
column9: "normalizing" can refer to many types of ratios; see normalization for more).Standard scores are also called z-values
column10: z-scores
column11: normal scores
column12: and standardized variables; the use of "Z" is because the normal distribution is also known as the "Z distribution". They are most frequently used to compare a sample to a standard normal deviate
column13: though they can be defined without assumptions of normality.The z-score is only defined if one knows the population parameters; if one only has a sample set
column14: then the analogous computation with sample mean and sample standard deviation yields the Student's t-statistic.|

column2: overdispersion is the presence of greater variability (statistical dispersion) in a data set than would be expected based on a given statistical model.A common task in applied statistics is choosing a parametric model to fit a given set of empirical observations. This necessitates an assessment of the fit of the chosen model. It is usually possible to choose the model parameters in such a way that the theoretical population mean of the model is approximately equal to the sample mean. However
column3: especially for simple models with few parameters
column4: theoretical predictions may not match empirical observations for higher moments. When the observed variance is higher than the variance of a theoretical model
column5: overdispersion has occurred. Conversely
column6: underdispersion means that there was less variation in the data than predicted. Overdispersion is a very common feature in applied data analysis because in practice
column7: populations are frequently heterogeneous (non-uniform) contrary to the assumptions implicit within widely used simple parametric models.|

column2: a type I error is the incorrect rejection of a true null hypothesis (a "false positive")
column3: while a type II error is incorrectly retaining a false null hypothesis (a "false negative"). More simply stated
column4: a type I error is detecting an effect that is not present
column5: while a type II error is failing to detect an effect that is present.|

column2: a power law is a functional relationship between two quantities
column3: where a relative change in one quantity results in a proportional relative change in the other quantity
column4: independent of the initial size of those quantities: one quantity varies as a power of another. For instance
column5: considering the area of a square in terms of the length of its side
column6: if the length is doubled
column7: the area is multiplied by a factor of four.|

column1: model-evaluation |Evaluation is a systematic determination of a subject's merit
column2: worth and significance
column3: using criteria governed by a set of standards. It can assist an organization
column4: program
column5: project or any other intervention or initiative to assess any aim
column6: realisable concept/proposal
column7: or any alternative
column8: to help in decision-making; or to ascertain the degree of achievement or value in regard to the aim and objectives and results of any such action that has been completed. The primary purpose of evaluation
column9: in addition to gaining insight into prior or existing initiatives
column10: is to enable reflection and assist in the identification of future change.Evaluation is often used to characterize and appraise subjects of interest in a wide range of human enterprises
column11: including the arts
column12: criminal justice
column13: foundations
column14: non-profit organizations
column15: government
column16: health care
column17: and other human services. It is long term and done at the end of a period of time.|

column1: weighted-data |The weighted arithmetic mean is similar to an ordinary arithmetic mean (the most common type of average)
column2: except that instead of each of the data points contributing equally to the final average
column3: some data points contribute more than others. The notion of weighted mean plays a role in descriptive statistics and also occurs in a more general form in several other areas of mathematics.If all the weights are equal
column4: then the weighted mean is the same as the arithmetic mean. While weighted means generally behave in a similar fashion to arithmetic means
column5: they do have a few counterintuitive properties
column6: as captured for instance in Simpson's paradox.|

column1: parameter-optimization |In the context of machine learning
column2: hyperparameter optimization or model selection is the problem of choosing a set of hyperparameters for a learning algorithm
column3: usually with the goal of optimizing a measure of the algorithm's performance on an independent data set. Often cross-validation is used to estimate this generalization performance. Hyperparameter optimization contrasts with actual learning problems
column4: which are also often cast as optimization problems
column5: but optimize a loss function on the training set alone. In effect
column6: learning algorithms learn parameters that model/reconstruct their inputs well
column7: while hyperparameter optimization is to ensure the model does not overfit its data by tuning
column8: e.g.
column9: regularization.|

column2: partial correlation measures the degree of association between two random variables
column3: with the effect of a set of controlling random variables removed.|

column2: generalized functions
column3: or distributions
column4: are objects extending the notion of functions. There is more than one recognized theory. Generalized functions are especially useful in making discontinuous functions more like smooth functions
column5: and describing discrete physical phenomena such as point charges. They are applied extensively
column6: especially in physics and engineering.A common feature of some of the approaches is that they build on operator aspects of everyday
column7: numerical functions. The early history is connected with some ideas on operational calculus
column8: and more contemporary developments in certain directions are closely related to ideas of Mikio Sato
column9: on what he calls algebraic analysis. Important influences on the subject have been the technical requirements of theories of partial differential equations
column10: and group representation theory.|

column1: rare-events |Rare events are events that occur with low frequency
column2: and the term is often used in particular reference to infrequent or hypothetical events that have potentially widespread impact and which might destabilize society. Rare events encompass natural phenomena (major earthquakes
column3: tsunamis
column4: hurricanes
column5: floods
column6: asteroid impacts
column7: solar flares
column8: etc.)
column9: anthropogenic hazards (warfare and related forms of violent conflict
column10: acts of terrorism
column11: industrial accidents
column12: financial and commodity market crashes
column13: etc.)
column14: as well as phenomena for which natural and anthropogenic factors interact in complex ways (epidemic disease spread
column15: global warming-related changes in climate and weather
column16: etc.).|

column2: the generalized linear model (GLM) is a flexible generalization of ordinary linear regression that allows for response variables that have error distribution models other than a normal distribution. The GLM generalizes linear regression by allowing the linear model to be related to the response variable via a link function and by allowing the magnitude of the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value.Generalized linear models were formulated by John Nelder and Robert Wedderburn as a way of unifying various other statistical models
column3: including linear regression
column4: logistic regression and Poisson regression. They proposed an iteratively reweighted least squares method for maximum likelihood estimation of the model parameters. Maximum-likelihood estimation remains popular and is the default method on many statistical computing packages. Other approaches
column5: including Bayesian approaches and least squares fits to variance stabilized responses
column6: have been developed.|

column1: association-measure |Measure for Measure is a play by William Shakespeare
column2: believed to have been written in 1603 or 1604. Originally published in the First Folio of 1623
column3: where it was listed as a comedy
column4: the play's first recorded performance occurred in 1604. The play's main themes include justice
column5: "mortality and mercy in Vienna
column6: and the dichotomy between corruption and purity: some rise by sin
column7: and some by virtue fall." Mercy and virtue predominate
column8: since the play does not end tragically.Measure for Measure is often called one of Shakespeare's problem plays. It was
column9: and continues to be
column10: classified as comedy
column11: though its tone may defy those expectations.|

column2: point estimation involves the use of sample data to calculate a single value (known as a statistic) which is to serve as a "best guess" or "best estimate" of an unknown (fixed or random) population parameter.More formally
column3: it is the application of a point estimator to the data.In general
column4: point estimation should be contrasted with interval estimation: such interval estimates are typically either confidence intervals in the case of frequentist inference
column5: or credible intervals in the case of Bayesian inference.|

column2: usually expressed as a pair of numbers
column3: used in both gambling and statistics. In statistics
column4: the odds for or odds of some event reflect the likelihood that the event will take place
column5: while odds against reflect the likelihood that it will not. In gambling
column6: the odds are the ratio of payoff to stake
column7: and do not necessarily reflect exactly the probabilities. Odds are expressed in several ways (see below)
column8: and sometimes the term is used incorrectly to mean simply the probability of an event. Conventionally
column9: gambling odds are expressed in the form "X to Y"
column10: where X and Y are numbers
column11: and it is implied that the odds are odds against the event on which the gambler is considering wagering. In both gambling and statistics
column12: the 'odds' are a numerical expression of the likelihood of some possible event.In gambling
column13: odds represent the ratio between the amounts staked by parties to a wager or bet. Thus
column14: odds of 6 to 1 mean the first party (normally a bookmaker) stakes six times the amount staked by the second party.In statistics
column15: the odds for an event E are defined as a simple function of the probability of that possible event E. One drawback of expressing the uncertainty of this possible event as odds for is that to regain the probability requires a calculation. The natural way to interpret odds for (without calculating anything) is as the ratio of events to non-events in the long run. A simple example is that the (statistical) odds for rolling six with a fair die (one of a pair of dice) are 1 to 5. This is because
column16: if one rolls the die many times
column17: and keeps a tally of the results
column18: one expects 1 six event for every 5 times the die does not show six. For example
column19: if we roll the fair die 600 times
column20: we would very much expect something in the neighborhood of 100 sixes
column21: and 500 of the other five possible outcomes. That is a ratio of 100 to 500
column22: or simply 1 to 5. To express the (statistical) odds against
column23: the order of the pair is reversed. Hence the odds against rolling a six with a fair die are 5 to 1. The probability of rolling a six with a fair die is the single number 1/6
column24: roughly 0.17.The gambling and statistical uses of odds are closely interlinked. If a bet is a fair one
column25: then the odds offered to the gamblers will perfectly reflect relative probabilities. A fair bet that a fair die will roll a six will pay the gambler 1 wager (and return the bettor his or her wager) in the case of a six and nothing in any other case. The terms of the bet are fair
column26: because on average
column27: five rolls result in something other than a six
column28: at a cost of 5. The profit and the expense exactly offset one another and so there is no disadvantage to gambling over the long run. If the odds being offered to the gamblers do not correspond to probability in this way then one of the parties to the bet has an advantage over the other. Casinos
column30: offer odds that place themselves at an advantage
column31: which is how they guarantee themselves a profit and survive as businesses. The fairness of a particular gamble is more clear in a game involving relatively pure chance
column32: such as the ping-pong ball method used in state lotteries in the United States. It is much harder to judge the fairness of the odds offered in a wager on a sporting event such as a football match.|

column2: a point process is a type of random process for which any one realisation consists of a set of isolated points either in time or geographical space
column3: or in even more general spaces. For example
column4: the occurrence of lightning strikes might be considered as a point process in both time and geographical space if each is recorded according to its location in time and space.Point processes are well studied objects in probability theory and the subject of powerful tools in statistics for modeling and analyzing spatial data
column5: which is of interest in such diverse disciplines as forestry
column6: plant ecology
column7: epidemiology
column8: geography
column9: seismology
column10: materials science
column11: astronomy
column12: telecommunications
column13: computational neuroscience
column14: economics and others.Point processes on the real line form an important special case that is particularly amenable to study
column15: because the points are ordered in a natural way
column16: and the whole point process can be described completely by the (random) intervals between the points. These point processes are frequently used as models for random events in time
column17: such as the arrival of customers in a queue (queueing theory)
column18: of impulses in a neuron (computational neuroscience)
column19: particles in a Geiger counter
column20: location of radio stations in a telecommunication network or of searches on the world-wide web.|

column1: confusion-matrix |In the field of machine learning and specifically the problem of statistical classification
column2: a confusion matrix
column3: also known as an error matrix
column4: is a specific table layout that allows visualization of the performance of an algorithm
column5: typically a supervised learning one (in unsupervised learning it is usually called a matching matrix). Each column of the matrix represents the instances in a predicted class while each row represents the instances in an actual class (or vice versa). The name stems from the fact that it makes it easy to see if the system is confusing two classes (i.e. commonly mislabelling one as another).It is a special kind of contingency table
column6: with two dimensions ("actual" and "predicted")
column7: and identical sets of "classes" in both dimensions (each combination of dimension and class is a variable in the contingency table).|

column2: sequence analysis is the process of subjecting a DNA
column3: RNA or peptide sequence to any of a wide range of analytical methods to understand its features
column4: function
column5: structure
column6: or evolution. Methodologies used include sequence alignment
column7: searches against biological databases
column8: and others. Since the development of methods of high-throughput production of gene and protein sequences
column9: the rate of addition of new sequences to the databases increased exponentially. Such a collection of sequences does not
column10: by itself
column11: increase the scientist's understanding of the biology of organisms. However
column12: comparing these new sequences to those with known functions is a key way of understanding the biology of an organism from which the new sequence comes. Thus
column13: sequence analysis can be used to assign function to genes and proteins by the study of the similarities between the compared sequences. Nowadays
column14: there are many tools and techniques that provide the sequence comparisons (sequence alignment) and analyze the alignment product to understand its biology.Sequence analysis in molecular biology includes a very wide range of relevant topics:The comparison of sequences in order to find similarity
column15: often to infer if they are related (homologous)Identification of intrinsic features of the sequence such as active sites
column16: post translational modification sites
column17: gene-structures
column18: reading frames
column19: distributions of introns and exons and regulatory elementsIdentification of sequence differences and variations such as point mutations and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in order to get the genetic marker.Revealing the evolution and genetic diversity of sequences and organismsIdentification of molecular structure from sequence aloneIn chemistry
column20: sequence analysis comprises techniques used to determine the sequence of a polymer formed of several monomers. In molecular biology and genetics
column21: the same process is called simply "sequencing".In marketing
column22: sequence analysis is often used in analytical customer relationship management applications
column23: such as NPTB models (Next Product to Buy).In sociology
column24: sequence methods are increasingly used to study life-course and career trajectories
column25: patterns of organizational and national development
column26: conversation and interaction structure
column27: and the problem of work/family synchrony. This body of research has given rise to the emerging subfield of social sequence analysis.|

column2: an effect size is a quantitative measure of the strength of a phenomenon. Examples of effect sizes are the correlation between two variables
column3: the regression coefficient in a regression
column4: the mean difference
column5: or even the risk with which something happens
column6: such as how many people survive after a heart attack for every one person that does not survive. For each type of effect size
column7: a larger absolute value always indicates a stronger effect. Effect sizes complement statistical hypothesis testing
column8: and play an important role in power analyses
column9: sample size planning
column10: and in meta-analyses. They are the first item (magnitude) in the MAGIC criteria for evaluating the strength of a statistical claim.Especially in meta-analysis
column11: where the purpose is to combine multiple effect sizes
column12: the standard error (S.E.) of the effect size is of critical importance. The S.E. of the effect size is used to weight effect sizes when combining studies
column13: so that large studies are considered more important than small studies in the analysis. The S.E. of the effect size is calculated differently for each type of effect size
column14: but generally only requires knowing the study's sample size (N)
column15: or the number of observations in each group (n's).Reporting effect sizes is considered good practice when presenting empirical research findings in many fields. The reporting of effect sizes facilitates the interpretation of the substantive
column16: as opposed to the statistical
column17: significance of a research result. Effect sizes are particularly prominent in social and medical research. Relative and absolute measures of effect size convey different information
column18: and can be used complementarily. A prominent task force in the psychology research community made the following recommendation:Always present effect sizes for primary outcomes...If the units of measurement are meaningful on a practical level (e.g.
column19: number of cigarettes smoked per day)
column20: then we usually prefer an unstandardized measure (regression coefficient or mean difference) to a standardized measure (r or d).|

column1: maximum-entropy |The principle of maximum entropy states that
column2: subject to precisely stated prior data (such as a proposition that expresses testable information)
column3: the probability distribution which best represents the current state of knowledge is the one with largest entropy.Another way of stating this: Take precisely stated prior data or testable information about a probability distribution function. Consider the set of all trial probability distributions that would encode the prior data. According to this principle
column4: the distribution with maximal information entropy is the proper one.|

column1: meta-regression |Meta-regression is a tool used in meta-analysis to examine the impact of moderator variables on study effect size using regression-based techniques. Meta-regression is more effective at this task than are standard meta-analytic techniques.|
circular-statistics |Directional statistics (also circular statistics or spherical statistics) is the subdiscipline of statistics that deals with directions (unit vectors in Rn)
column2: axes (lines through the origin in Rn) or rotations in Rn. More generally
column3: directional statistics deals with observations on compact Riemannian manifolds.The fact that 0 degrees and 360 degrees are identical angles
column4: so that for example 180 degrees is not a sensible mean of 2 degrees and 358 degrees
column5: provides one illustration that special statistical methods are required for the analysis of some types of data (in this case
column6: angular data). Other examples of data that may be regarded as directional include statistics involving temporal periods (e.g. time of day
column7: week
column8: month
column9: year
column10: etc.)
column11: compass directions
column12: dihedral angles in molecules
column13: orientations
column14: rotations and so on.|

column2: social sciences
column3: psychology and statistics
column4: an observational study draws inferences from a sample to a population where the independent variable is not under the control of the researcher because of ethical concerns or logistical constraints. One common observational study is about the possible effect of a treatment on subjects
column5: where the assignment of subjects into a treated group versus a control group is outside the control of the investigator. This is in contrast with experiments
column6: such as randomized controlled trials
column7: where each subject is randomly assigned to a treated group or a control group.|

column1: case-control-study |A case-control study is a type of observational study in which two existing groups differing in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute. Case-control studies are often used to identify factors that may contribute to a medical condition by comparing subjects who have that condition/disease (the "cases") with patients who do not have the condition/disease but are otherwise similar (the "controls"). They require fewer resources but provide less evidence for causal inference than a randomized controlled trial.|

inferential-statistics |Statistical inference is the process of deducing properties of an underlying distribution by analysis of data. Inferential statistical analysis infers properties about a population: this includes testing hypotheses and deriving estimates. The population is assumed to be larger than the observed data set; in other words
column2: the observed data is assumed to be sampled from a larger population.Inferential statistics can be contrasted with descriptive statistics. Descriptive statistics is solely concerned with properties of the observed data
column3: and does not assume that the data came from a larger population.|

column1: cluster-sample |Cluster sampling is a sampling technique used when "natural" but relatively heterogeneous groupings are evident in a statistical population. It is often used in marketing research. In this technique
column2: the total population is divided into these groups (or clusters) and a simple random sample of the groups is selected. The elements in each cluster are then sampled. If all elements in each sampled cluster are sampled
column3: then this is referred to as a "one-stage" cluster design. If a simple random subsample of elements is selected within each of these groups
column4: this is referred to as a "two-stage" design. A common motivation for cluster sampling is to reduce the total number of interviews and costs given the desired accuracy. Assuming a fixed sample size
column5: the technique gives more accurate results when most of the variation in the population is within the groups
column6: not between them.|

column2: a sequence or other collection of random variables is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) if each random variable has the same probability distribution as the others and all are mutually independent.The abbreviation i.i.d. is particularly common in statistics (often as iid
column3: sometimes written IID)
column4: where observations in a sample are often assumed to be effectively i.i.d. for the purposes of statistical inference. The assumption (or requirement) that observations be i.i.d. tends to simplify the underlying mathematics of many statistical methods (see mathematical statistics and statistical theory). However
column5: in practical applications of statistical modeling the assumption may or may not be realistic. To test how realistic the assumption is on a given data set
column6: the autocorrelation can be computed
column7: lag plots drawn or turning point test performed. The generalization of exchangeable random variables is often sufficient and more easily met.The assumption is important in the classical form of the central limit theorem
column8: which states that the probability distribution of the sum (or average) of i.i.d. variables with finite variance approaches a normal distribution.Note that IID refers to sequences of random variables. "Independent and identically distributed" implies an element in the sequence is independent of the random variables that came before it. In this way
column9: an IID sequence is different from a Markov sequence
column10: where the probability distribution for the nth random variable is a function of the previous random variable in the sequence (for a first order Markov sequence). An IID sequence does not imply the probabilities for all elements of the sample space or event space must be the same. For example
column11: repeated throws of loaded dice will produce a sequence that is IID
column12: despite the outcomes being biased.|

column2: sequential analysis or sequential hypothesis testing is statistical analysis where the sample size is not fixed in advance. Instead data is evaluated as it is collected
column3: and further sampling is stopped in accordance with a pre-defined stopping rule as soon as significant results are observed. Thus a conclusion may sometimes be reached at a much earlier stage than would be possible with more classical hypothesis testing or estimation
column4: at consequently lower financial and/or human cost.|

column1: tensorflow |TensorFlow is an open source software library for machine learning in various kinds of perceptual and language understanding tasks. It is currently used for both research and production by 50 different teams in dozens of commercial Google products
column2: such as speech recognition
column3: Gmail
column4: Google Photos
column5: and search
column6: many of which had previously used its predecessor DistBelief. TensorFlow was originally developed by the Google Brain team for Google's research and production purposes and later released under the Apache 2.0 open source license on November 9

column2: the delta method is a result concerning the approximate probability distribution for a function of an asymptotically normal statistical estimator from knowledge of the limiting variance of that estimator.|
the maxima and minima (the respective plurals of maximum and minimum) of a function
column3: known collectively as extrema (the plural of extremum)
column4: are the largest and smallest value of the function
column5: either within a given range (the local or relative extrema) or on the entire domain of a function (the global or absolute extrema). Pierre de Fermat was one of the first mathematicians to propose a general technique
column6: adequality
column7: for finding the maxima and minima of functions.As defined in set theory
column8: the maximum and minimum of a set are the greatest and least elements in the set
column9: respectively. Unbounded infinite sets
column10: such as the set of real numbers
column11: have no minimum or maximum.|

column2: nonlinear regression is a form of regression analysis in which observational data are modeled by a function which is a nonlinear combination of the model parameters and depends on one or more independent variables. The data are fitted by a method of successive approximations.|

column1: derivative |The derivative of a function of a real variable measures the sensitivity to change of a quantity (a function value or dependent variable) which is determined by another quantity (the independent variable). Derivatives are a fundamental tool of calculus. For example
column2: the derivative of the position of a moving object with respect to time is the object's velocity: this measures how quickly the position of the object changes when time is advanced.The derivative of a function of a single variable at a chosen input value
column3: when it exists
column4: is the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function at that point. The tangent line is the best linear approximation of the function near that input value. For this reason
column5: the derivative is often described as the "instantaneous rate of change"
column6: the ratio of the instantaneous change in the dependent variable to that of the independent variable.Derivatives may be generalized to functions of several real variables. In this generalization
column7: the derivative is reinterpreted as a linear transformation whose graph is (after an appropriate translation) the best linear approximation to the graph of the original function. The Jacobian matrix is the matrix that represents this linear transformation with respect to the basis given by the choice of independent and dependent variables. It can be calculated in terms of the partial derivatives with respect to the independent variables. For a real-valued function of several variables
column8: the Jacobian matrix reduces to the gradient vector.The process of finding a derivative is called differentiation. The reverse process is called antidifferentiation. The fundamental theorem of calculus states that antidifferentiation is the same as integration. Differentiation and integration constitute the two fundamental operations in single-variable calculus.|

column2: canonical-correlation analysis (CCA) is a way of making sense of cross-covariance matrices. If we have two vectors X = (X1
column4: Xn) and Y = (Y1
column6: Ym) of random variables
column7: and there are correlations among the variables
column8: then canonical-correlation analysis will find linear combinations of the Xi and Yj which have maximum correlation with each other. T. R. Knapp notes "virtually all of the commonly encountered parametric tests of significance can be treated as special cases of canonical-correlation analysis
column9: which is the general procedure for investigating the relationships between two sets of variables." The method was first introduced by Harold Hotelling in 1936.|

column2: white noise is a random signal having equal intensity at different frequencies
column3: giving it a constant power spectral density. The term is used
column4: with this or similar meanings
column5: in many scientific and technical disciplines
column6: including physics
column7: acoustic engineering
column8: telecommunications
column9: statistical forecasting
column10: and many more. White noise refers to a statistical model for signals and signal sources
column11: rather than to any specific signal.In discrete time
column12: white noise is a discrete signal whose samples are regarded as a sequence of serially uncorrelated random variables with zero mean and finite variance; a single realization of white noise is a random shock. Depending on the context
column13: one may also require that the samples be independent and have identical probability distribution (in other words i.i.d. is a simplest representative of the white noise). In particular
column14: if each sample has a normal distribution with zero mean
column15: the signal is said to be Gaussian white noise.The samples of a white noise signal may be sequential in time
column16: or arranged along one or more spatial dimensions. In digital image processing
column17: the pixels of a white noise image are typically arranged in a rectangular grid
column18: and are assumed to be independent random variables with uniform probability distribution over some interval. The concept can be defined also for signals spread over more complicated domains
column19: such as a sphere or a torus.An infinite-bandwidth white noise signal is a purely theoretical construction. The bandwidth of white noise is limited in practice by the mechanism of noise generation
column20: by the transmission medium and by finite observation capabilities. Thus
column21: a random signal is considered "white noise" if it is observed to have a flat spectrum over the range of frequencies that is relevant to the context. For an audio signal
column22: for example
column23: the relevant range is the band of audible sound frequencies
column24: between 20 and 20
column25: 000 Hz. Such a signal is heard as a hissing sound
column26: resembling the /sh/ sound in "ash". In music and acoustics
column27: the term "white noise" may be used for any signal that has a similar hissing sound.White noise draws its name from white light
column28: although light that appears white generally does not have a flat spectral power density over the visible band.The term white noise is sometimes used in the context of phylogenetically based statistical methods to refer to a lack of phylogenetic pattern in comparative data. It is sometimes used in non technical contexts
column29: in the metaphoric sense of "random talk without meaningful contents".|

column2: especially in set theory
column3: a set A is a subset of a set B
column4: or equivalently B is a superset of A
column5: if A is "contained" inside B
column6: that is
column7: all elements of A are also elements of B. A and B may coincide. The relationship of one set being a subset of another is called inclusion or sometimes containment.The subset relation defines a partial order on sets.The algebra of subsets forms a Boolean algebra in which the subset relation is called inclusion.|

column1: geostatistics |Geostatistics is a branch of statistics focusing on spatial or spatiotemporal datasets. Developed originally to predict probability distributions of ore grades for mining operations
column2: it is currently applied in diverse disciplines including petroleum geology
column3: hydrogeology
column4: hydrology
column5: meteorology
column6: oceanography
column7: geochemistry
column8: geometallurgy
column9: geography
column10: forestry
column11: environmental control
column12: landscape ecology
column13: soil science
column14: and agriculture (esp. in precision farming). Geostatistics is applied in varied branches of geography
column15: particularly those involving the spread of diseases (epidemiology)
column16: the practice of commerce and military planning (logistics)
column17: and the development of efficient spatial networks. Geostatistical algorithms are incorporated in many places
column18: including geographic information systems (GIS) and the R statistical environment.|

column1: statsmodels |Statsmodels is a Python module that allows users to explore data
column2: estimate statistical models
column3: and perform statistical tests. An extensive list of descriptive statistics
column4: statistical tests
column5: plotting functions
column6: and result statistics are available for different types of data and each estimator. It complements SciPy's stats module.Statsmodels is part of the scientific Python stack that is oriented towards data analysis
column7: datascience and statistics. Statsmodels is built on top of the numerical libraries NumPy and SciPy
column8: integrates with Pandas for data handling and uses Patsy for an R-like formula interface. Graphical functions are based on the Matplotlib library. Statsmodels provides the statistical backend for other Python libraries.|

column2: a latent class model (LCM) relates a set of observed (usually discrete) multivariate variables to a set of latent variables. It is a type of latent variable model. It is called a latent class model because the latent variable is discrete. A class is characterized by a pattern of conditional probabilities that indicate the chance that variables take on certain values.Latent class analysis (LCA) is a subset of structural equation modeling
column3: used to find groups or subtypes of cases in multivariate categorical data. These subtypes are called "latent classes".Confronted with a situation as follows
column4: a researcher might choose to use LCA to understand the data: Imagine that symptoms a-d have been measured in a range of patients with diseases X Y and Z
column5: and that disease X is associated with the presence of symptoms a
column6: b
column7: and c
column8: disease Y with symptoms b
column9: c
column10: d
column11: and disease Z with symptoms a
column12: c and d.The LCA will attempt to detect the presence of latent classes (the disease entities)
column13: creating patterns of association in the symptoms. As in factor analysis
column14: the LCA can also be used to classify case according to their maximum likelihood class membership.Because the criterion for solving the LCA is to achieve latent classes within which there is no longer any association of one symptom with another (because the class is the disease which causes their association
column15: and the set of diseases a patient has (or class a case is a member of) causes the symptom association
column16: the symptoms will be "conditionally independent"
column17: i.e.
column18: conditional on class membership
column19: they are no longer related.|

column1: finite-population |The finite element method (FEM) is a numerical technique for finding approximate solutions to boundary value problems for partial differential equations. It is also referred to as finite element analysis (FEA). It subdivides a large problem into smaller
column2: simpler parts that are called finite elements. The simple equations that model these finite elements are then assembled into a larger system of equations that models the entire problem. FEM then uses variational methods from the calculus of variations to approximate a solution by minimizing an associated error function.|

column1: minitab |Minitab is a statistics package developed at the Pennsylvania State University by researchers Barbara F. Ryan
column2: Thomas A. Ryan
column3: Jr.
column4: and Brian L. Joiner in 1972. It began as a light version of OMNITAB
column5: a statistical analysis program by NIST; the documentation for OMNITAB was published 1986
column6: and there has been no significant development since then.Minitab is distributed by Minitab Inc
column7: a privately owned company headquartered in State College
column8: Pennsylvania. Minitab Inc. also produces Quality Trainer and Quality Companion
column9: which can be used in conjunction with Minitab: the first being an eLearning package that teaches statistical tools and concepts in the context of quality improvement
column10: while the second is a tool for managing Six Sigma and Lean Manufacturing.|

column2: Levene's test is an inferential statistic used to assess the equality of variances for a variable calculated for two or more groups. Some common statistical procedures assume that variances of the populations from which different samples are drawn are equal. Levene's test assesses this assumption. It tests the null hypothesis that the population variances are equal (called homogeneity of variance or homoscedasticity). If the resulting p-value of Levene's test is less than some significance level (typically 0.05)
column3: the obtained differences in sample variances are unlikely to have occurred based on random sampling from a population with equal variances. Thus
column4: the null hypothesis of equal variances is rejected and it is concluded that there is a difference between the variances in the population.Some of the procedures typically assuming homoscedasticity
column5: for which one can use Levene's tests
column6: include analysis of variance and t-tests.Levene's test is often used before a comparison of means. When Levene's test shows significance
column7: one should switch to more generalized tests that is free from homoscedasticity assumptions (sometimes even non-parametric tests).Levene's test may also be used as a main test for answering a stand-alone question of whether two sub-samples in a given population have equal or different variances.|

column1: word2vec |Word2vec is a group of related models that are used to produce word embeddings. These models are shallow
column2: two-layer neural networks that are trained to reconstruct linguistic contexts of words. Word2vec takes as its input a large corpus of text and produces a vector space
column3: typically of several hundred dimensions
column4: with each unique word in the corpus being assigned a corresponding vector in the space.
