Word vectors are positioned in the vector space such that words that share common contexts in the corpus are located in close proximity to one another in the space.Word2vec was created by a team of researchers led by Tomas Mikolov at Google. The algorithm has been subsequently analysed and explained by other researchers. Embedding vectors created using the Word2vec algorithm have many advantages compared to earlier algorithms like Latent Semantic Analysis.|

column2: the perceptron is an algorithm for supervised learning of binary classifiers (functions that can decide whether an input
column3: represented by a vector of numbers
column4: belongs to some specific class or not). It is a type of linear classifier
column5: i.e. a classification algorithm that makes its predictions based on a linear predictor function combining a set of weights with the feature vector. The algorithm allows for online learning
column6: in that it processes elements in the training set one at a time.The perceptron algorithm dates back to the late 1950s; its first implementation
column7: in custom hardware
column8: was one of the first artificial neural networks to be produced.|

column2: importance sampling is a general technique for estimating properties of a particular distribution
column3: while only having samples generated from a different distribution than the distribution of interest. It is related to umbrella sampling in computational physics. Depending on the application
column4: the term may refer to the process of sampling from this alternative distribution
column5: the process of inference
column6: or both.|

column2: the p-value is the probability that
column3: using a given statistical model
column4: the statistical summary (such as the sample mean difference between two compared groups) would be the same as or more extreme than the actual observed results. Statistical hypothesis testing making use of p-values is commonly used in many fields of research such as economics
column5: political science
column6: psychology
column7: biology
column8: criminal justice
column9: criminology
column10: and sociology. Their misuse has been a matter of considerable controversy.|

column2: a type I error is the incorrect rejection of a true null hypothesis (a "false positive")
column3: while a type II error is incorrectly retaining a false null hypothesis (a "false negative"). More simply stated
column4: a type I error is detecting an effect that is not present
column5: while a type II error is failing to detect an effect that is present.|

column2: density estimation is the construction of an estimate
column3: based on observed data
column4: of an unobservable underlying probability density function. The unobservable density function is thought of as the density according to which a large population is distributed; the data are usually thought of as a random sample from that population.A variety of approaches to density estimation are used
column5: including Parzen windows and a range of data clustering techniques
column6: including vector quantization. The most basic form of density estimation is a rescaled histogram.|

column2: data cleaning
column3: or data scrubbing is the process of detecting and correcting (or removing) corrupt or inaccurate records from a record set
column4: table
column5: or database and refers to identifying incomplete
column6: incorrect
column7: inaccurate or irrelevant parts of the data and then replacing
column8: modifying
column9: or deleting the dirty or coarse data. Data cleansing may be performed interactively with data wrangling tools
column10: or as batch processing through scripting.After cleansing
column11: a data set should be consistent with other similar data sets in the system. The inconsistencies detected or removed may have been originally caused by user entry errors
column12: by corruption in transmission or storage
column13: or by different data dictionary definitions of similar entities in different stores. Data cleansing differs from data validation in that validation almost invariably means data is rejected from the system at entry and is performed at the time of entry
column14: rather than on batches of data.The actual process of data cleansing may involve removing typographical errors or validating and correcting values against a known list of entities. The validation may be strict (such as rejecting any address that does not have a valid postal code) or fuzzy (such as correcting records that partially match existing
column15: known records). Some data cleansing solutions will clean data by cross checking with a validated data set. A common data cleansing practice is data enhancement
column16: where data is made more complete by adding related information. For example
column17: appending addresses with any phone numbers related to that address. Data cleansing may also involve activities like
column18: harmonization of data
column19: and standardization of data. For example
column20: harmonization of short codes (st
column21: rd
column22: etc.) to actual words (street
column23: road
column24: etcetera). Standardization of data is a means of changing a reference data set to a new standard
column25: ex
column26: use of standard codes.|

column1: eviews |EViews (Econometric Views) is a statistical package for Windows
column2: used mainly for time-series oriented econometric analysis. It is developed by Quantitative Micro Software (QMS)
column3: now a part of IHS. Version 1.0 was released in March 1994
column4: and replaced MicroTSP. The TSP software and programming language had been originally developed by Robert Hall in 1965. The current version of EViews is 9.5
column5: released in March 2016.|

column2: restricted randomization occurs in the design of experiments and in particular in the context of randomized experiments and randomized controlled trials. Restricted randomization allows intuitively poor allocations of treatments to experimental units to be avoided
column3: while retaining the theoretical benefits of randomization. For example
column4: in a clinical trial of a new proposed treatment of obesity compared to a control
column5: an experimenter would want to avoid outcomes of the randomization in which the new treatment was allocated only to the heaviest patients.The concept was introduced by Frank Yates (1948) and William J. Youden (1972) "as a way of avoiding bad spatial patterns of treatments in designed experiments."|

column2: a likelihood function (often simply the likelihood) is a function of the parameters of a statistical model given data. Likelihood functions play a key role in statistical inference
column3: especially methods of estimating a parameter from a set of statistics. In informal contexts
column4: "likelihood" is often used as a synonym for "probability." In statistics
column5: a distinction is made depending on the roles of outcomes vs. parameters. Probability is used before data are available to describe possible future outcomes given a fixed value for the parameter (or parameter vector). Likelihood is used after data are available to describe a function of a parameter (or parameter vector) for a given outcome.|

column2: linear least squares is an approach fitting a mathematical or statistical model to data in cases where the idealized value provided by the model for any data point is expressed linearly in terms of the unknown parameters of the model. The resulting fitted model can be used to summarize the data
column3: to predict unobserved values from the same system
column4: and to understand the mechanisms that may underlie the system.Mathematically
column5: linear least squares is the problem of approximately solving an overdetermined system of linear equations
column6: where the best approximation is defined as that which minimizes the sum of squared differences between the data values and their corresponding modeled values. The approach is called linear least squares since the assumed function is linear in the parameters to be estimated. Linear least squares problems are convex and have a closed-form solution that is unique
column7: provided that the number of data points used for fitting equals or exceeds the number of unknown parameters
column8: except in special degenerate situations. In contrast
column9: non-linear least squares problems generally must be solved by an iterative procedure
column10: and the problems can be non-convex with multiple optima for the objective function. If prior distributions are available
column11: then even an underdetermined system can be solved using the Bayesian MMSE estimator.In statistics
column12: linear least squares problems correspond to a particularly important type of statistical model called linear regression which arises as a particular form of regression analysis. One basic form of such a model is an ordinary least squares model. The present article concentrates on the mathematical aspects of linear least squares problems
column13: with discussion of the formulation and interpretation of statistical regression models and statistical inferences related to these being dealt with in the articles just mentioned. See outline of regression analysis for an outline of the topic.|

column2: Conjoint analysis (in healthcare)
column3: IDDEA
column4: Rule Developing Experimentation
column5: Value based pricing.Conjoint analysis
column6: also called multi-attribute compositional models or stated preference analysis
column7: is a statistical technique that originated in mathematical psychology. It is used in surveys developed in applied sciences
column8: often on behalf of marketing
column9: product management
column10: and operations research. It is not to be confused with the theory of conjoint measurement.Conjoint analysis is a particular application of regression analysis. There is no precise statistical definition of it. Usually two or three of the following properties are applicable:data are collected among multiple individuals (respondents) whereas there are multiple data points for each individual
column11: which makes it a layered modelthe dependent variable reflects a choice or trade-off situationthe independent variables are categorical
column12: thus coded as binary numbers (0

column2: a mixed-design analysis of variance model (also known as a split-plot ANOVA) is used to test for differences between two or more independent groups whilst subjecting participants to repeated measures. Thus
column3: in a mixed-design ANOVA model
column4: one factor (a fixed effects factor) is a between-subjects variable and the other (a random effects factor) is a within-subjects variable. Thus
column5: overall
column6: the model is a type of mixed effect model.A repeated measures design is used when multiple independent variables or measures exist in a data set
column7: but all participants have been measured on each variable.|

column2: the standard score is the signed number of standard deviations by which an observation or data is above the mean. A standard score is a derived score
column3: used for making norm-referenced interpretations
column4: for which the mean and standard deviation are selected to simplify interpretations. Some common standard scores and their corresponding mean and standard deviation are: ACT scores (18 and 5)
column5: SAT scores (500 and 100)
column6: T-scores (50 and 10)
column7: and z-scores (0.0 and 1.0). A positive standard score indicates a datum above the mean
column8: while a negative standard score indicates a datum below the mean. It is a dimensionless quantity obtained by subtracting the population mean from an individual raw score and then dividing the difference by the population standard deviation. This conversion process is called standardizing or normalizing (however
column9: "normalizing" can refer to many types of ratios; see normalization for more).Standard scores are also called z-values
column10: z-scores
column11: normal scores
column12: and standardized variables; the use of "Z" is because the normal distribution is also known as the "Z distribution". They are most frequently used to compare a sample to a standard normal deviate
column13: though they can be defined without assumptions of normality.The z-score is only defined if one knows the population parameters; if one only has a sample set
column14: then the analogous computation with sample mean and sample standard deviation yields the Student's t-statistic.|

column2: the multi-armed bandit problem (sometimes called the K- or N-armed bandit problem) is a problem in which a gambler at a row of slot machines (sometimes known as "one-armed bandits") has to decide which machines to play
column3: how many times to play each machine and in which order to play them. When played
column4: each machine provides a random reward from a probability distribution specific to that machine. The objective of the gambler is to maximize the sum of rewards earned through a sequence of lever pulls.Herbert Robbins in 1952
column5: realizing the importance of the problem
column6: constructed convergent population selection strategies in "some aspects of the sequential design of experiments".A theorem
column7: the Gittins index
column8: first published by John C. Gittins
column9: gives an optimal policy for maximizing the expected discounted reward.In practice
column10: multi-armed bandits have been used to model the problem of managing research projects in a large organization
column11: like a science foundation or a pharmaceutical company. Given a fixed budget
column12: the problem is to allocate resources among the competing projects
column13: whose properties are only partially known at the time of allocation
column14: but which may become better understood as time passes.In early versions of the multi-armed bandit problem
column15: the gambler has no initial knowledge about the machines. The crucial tradeoff the gambler faces at each trial is between "exploitation" of the machine that has the highest expected payoff and "exploration" to get more information about the expected payoffs of the other machines. The trade-off between exploration and exploitation is also faced in reinforcement learning.|

column2: the law of large numbers (LLN) is a theorem that describes the result of performing the same experiment a large number of times. According to the law
column3: the average of the results obtained from a large number of trials should be close to the expected value
column4: and will tend to become closer as more trials are performed.The LLN is important because it "guarantees" stable long-term results for the averages of some random events. For example
column5: while a casino may lose money in a single spin of the roulette wheel
column6: its earnings will tend towards a predictable percentage over a large number of spins. Any winning streak by a player will eventually be overcome by the parameters of the game. It is important to remember that the LLN only applies (as the name indicates) when a large number of observations are considered. There is no principle that a small number of observations will coincide with the expected value or that a streak of one value will immediately be "balanced" by the others (see the gambler's fallacy).|

column1: functional-data-analysis |Functional data analysis (FDA) is a branch of statistics that analyses data providing information about curves
column2: surfaces or anything else varying over a continuum. In its most general form
column3: under an FDA framework each sample element is considered to be a function. The physical continuum over which these functions are defined is often time
column4: but may also be spatial location
column5: wavelength
column6: probability
column7: etc.|

column2: a generative model is a model for randomly generating observable data values
column3: typically given some hidden parameters. It specifies a joint probability distribution over observation and label sequences. Generative models are used in machine learning for either modeling data directly (i.e.
column4: modeling observations drawn from a probability density function)
column5: or as an intermediate step to forming a conditional probability density function. A conditional distribution can be formed from a generative model through Bayes' rule.Shannon (1948) gives an example in which a table of frequencies of English word pairs is used to generate a sentence beginning with "representing and speedily is an good"; which is not proper English but which will increasingly approximate it as the table is moved from word pairs to word triplets etc.Generative models contrast with discriminative models
column6: in that a generative model is a full probabilistic model of all variables
column7: whereas a discriminative model provides a model only for the target variable(s) conditional on the observed variables. Thus a generative model can be used
column8: for example
column9: to simulate (i.e. generate) values of any variable in the model
column10: whereas a discriminative model allows only sampling of the target variables conditional on the observed quantities. Despite the fact that discriminative models do not need to model the distribution of the observed variables
column11: they cannot generally express more complex relationships between the observed and target variables. They don't necessarily perform better than generative models at classification and regression tasks. In modern applications the two classes are seen as complementary or as different views of the same procedure.Examples of generative models include:Gaussian mixture model and other types of mixture modelHidden Markov modelProbabilistic context-free grammarNaive BayesAveraged one-dependence estimatorsLatent Dirichlet allocationRestricted Boltzmann machineGenerative adversarial networksIf the observed data are truly sampled from the generative model
column12: then fitting the parameters of the generative model to maximize the data likelihood is a common method. However
column13: since most statistical models are only approximations to the true distribution
column14: if the model's application is to infer about a subset of variables conditional on known values of others
column15: then it can be argued that the approximation makes more assumptions than are necessary to solve the problem at hand. In such cases
column16: it can be more accurate to model the conditional density functions directly using a discriminative model (see above)
column17: although application-specific details will ultimately dictate which approach is most suitable in any particular case.|

column1: sentiment-analysis |Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining) refers to the use of natural language processing
column2: text analysis and computational linguistics to identify and extract subjective information in source materials. Sentiment analysis is widely applied to reviews and social media for a variety of applications
column3: ranging from marketing to customer service.Generally speaking
column4: sentiment analysis aims to determine the attitude of a speaker or a writer with respect to some topic or the overall contextual polarity of a document. The attitude may be his or her judgment or evaluation (see appraisal theory)
column5: affective state (that is to say
column6: the emotional state of the author when writing)
column7: or the intended emotional communication (that is to say
column8: the emotional effect the author wishes to have on the reader).|

column2: fractional factorial designs are experimental designs consisting of a carefully chosen subset (fraction) of the experimental runs of a full factorial design. The subset is chosen so as to exploit the sparsity-of-effects principle to expose information about the most important features of the problem studied
column3: while using a fraction of the effort of a full factorial design in terms of experimental runs and resources.|

column1: fat-tails |A fat-tailed distribution is a probability distribution that has the property
column2: along with the other heavy-tailed distributions
column3: that it exhibits large skewness or kurtosis. This comparison is often made relative to the normal distribution
column4: or to the exponential distribution. Fat-tailed distributions have been empirically encountered in a variety of areas: economics
column5: physics
column6: and earth sciences. Some fat-tailed distributions have power law decay in the tail of the distribution
column7: but they generally do not follow a power law everywhere.|

column1: biplot |Biplots are a type of exploratory graph used in statistics
column2: a generalization of the simple two-variable scatterplot. A biplot allows information on both samples and variables of a data matrix to be displayed graphically. Samples are displayed as points while variables are displayed either as vectors
column3: linear axes or nonlinear trajectories. In the case of categorical variables
column4: category level points may be used to represent the levels of a categorical variable. A generalised biplot displays information on both continuous and categorical variables.|

column1: signed-rank-test |The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is a non-parametric statistical hypothesis test used when comparing two related samples
column2: matched samples
column3: or repeated measurements on a single sample to assess whether their population mean ranks differ (i.e. it is a paired difference test). It can be used as an alternative to the paired Student's t-test
column4: t-test for matched pairs
column5: or the t-test for dependent samples when the population cannot be assumed to be normally distributed.|

column1: heterogeneity |Homogeneity and heterogeneity are concepts often used in the sciences and statistics relating to the uniformity in a substance or organism. A material or image that is homogeneous is uniform in composition or character (i.e. color
column2: shape
column3: size
column4: weight
column5: height
column6: distribution
column7: texture
column8: language
column9: income
column10: disease
column11: temperature
column12: radioactivity
column13: architectural design
column14: etc.); one that is heterogeneous is distinctly nonuniform in one of these qualities.|

column2: time series data is data collected at regular intervals. When there are patterns that repeat over known
column3: fixed periods of time within the data set
column4: such patterns are known as seasonality
column5: seasonal variation
column6: periodic variation
column7: or periodic fluctuations. This variation can be either regular or semi-regular.Seasonality may be caused by various factors
column8: such as weather
column9: vacation
column10: and holidays and usually consists of periodic
column11: repetitive
column12: and generally regular and predictable patterns in the levels of a time series. Seasonality can repeat on a weekly
column13: monthly or quarterly basis
column14: these periods of time are structured and occur in a length of time less than a year. Seasonal fluctuations in a time series can be contrasted with cyclical patterns. The latter occurs when the data exhibits rises and falls that are not of a fixed period. These fluctuations are usually due to economic conditions and are often related to the "business cycle." The fixed period of time usually extends beyond a single year and the fluctuations are usually of at least two year and do not repeat over fixed periods of time.Organizations facing seasonal variations
column15: such as ice-cream vendors
column16: are often interested in knowing their performance relative to the normal seasonal variation. Seasonal variations in the labor market can be attributed to the entrance of school leavers into the job market; as they aim to contribute to the workforce during their vacations
column17: or upon the completion of their schooling. These regular changes are of less interest to those who study employment data than the variations that occur due to the underlying state of the economy. Where their focus is on how unemployment in the workforce has changed
column18: despite the impact of the regular seasonal variations.It is necessary for organizations to identify and measure seasonal variations within their market to help them plan for the future. This can prepare them for the temporary increases or decreases in labor requirements and inventory as demand for their product or service fluctuates over certain periods. This may require training
column19: periodic maintenance
column20: and so forth that can be organized in advance. Apart from these considerations
column21: the organizations need to know if variation they have experienced have been more or less than the expected amount
column22: beyond what the usual seasonal variations account for.|

column2: the inverse gamma distribution is a two-parameter family of continuous probability distributions on the positive real line
column3: which is the distribution of the reciprocal of a variable distributed according to the gamma distribution. Perhaps the chief use of the inverse gamma distribution is in Bayesian statistics
column4: where the distribution arises as the marginal posterior distribution for the unknown variance of a normal distribution if an uninformative prior is used; and as an analytically tractable conjugate prior if an informative prior is required.However
column5: it is common among Bayesians to consider an alternative parametrization of the normal distribution in terms of the precision
column6: defined as the reciprocal of the variance
column7: which allows the gamma distribution to be used directly as a conjugate prior. Other Bayesians prefer to parametrize the inverse gamma distribution differently
column8: as a scaled inverse chi-squared distribution.|

column1: f-statistic |An F-test is any statistical test in which the test statistic has an F-distribution under the null hypothesis. It is most often used when comparing statistical models that have been fitted to a data set
column2: in order to identify the model that best fits the population from which the data were sampled. Exact "F-tests" mainly arise when the models have been fitted to the data using least squares. The name was coined by George W. Snedecor
column3: in honour of Sir Ronald A. Fisher. Fisher initially developed the statistic as the variance ratio in the 1920s.|

column1: rotation |A rotation is a circular movement of an object around a center (or point) of rotation . A three-dimensional object always rotates around an imaginary line called a rotation axis. If the axis passes through the body's center of mass
column2: the body is said to rotate upon itself
column3: or spin. A rotation about an external point
column4: e.g. the Earth about the Sun
column5: is called a revolution or orbital revolution
column6: typically when it is produced by gravity. The axis is called a pole.|

column1: conditional-random-field |Conditional random fields (CRFs) are a class of statistical modelling method often applied in pattern recognition and machine learning
column2: where they are used for structured prediction. Whereas an ordinary classifier predicts a label for a single sample without regard to "neighboring" samples
column3: a CRF can take context into account; e.g.
column4: the linear chain CRF popular in natural language processing predicts sequences of labels for sequences of input samples.CRFs are a type of discriminative undirected probabilistic graphical model. It is used to encode known relationships between observations and construct consistent interpretations. It is often used for labeling or parsing of sequential data
column5: such as natural language text or biological sequences and in computer vision. Specifically
column6: CRFs find applications in shallow parsing
column7: named entity recognition
column8: gene finding and peptide critical functional region finding
column9: among other tasks
column10: being an alternative to the related hidden Markov models (HMMs). In computer vision
column11: CRFs are often used for object recognition and image segmentation.|

column2: the use of Bayes factors is a Bayesian alternative to classical hypothesis testing. Bayesian model comparison is a method of model selection based on Bayes factors.|
errors-in-variables models or measurement error models are regression models that account for measurement errors in the independent variables. In contrast
column3: standard regression models assume that those regressors have been measured exactly
column4: or observed without error; as such
column5: those models account only for errors in the dependent variables
column6: or responses.In the case when some regressors have been measured with errors
column7: estimation based on the standard assumption leads to inconsistent estimates
column8: meaning that the parameter estimates do not tend to the true values even in very large samples. For simple linear regression the effect is an underestimate of the coefficient
column9: known as the attenuation bias. In non-linear models the direction of the bias is likely to be more complicated.|

column1: incidence-rate-ratio |A rate ratio (sometimes called an incidence density ratio) in epidemiology
column2: is a relative difference measure used to compare the incidence rates of events occurring at any given point in time. A common application for this measure in analytic epidemiologic studies is in the search for a causal association between a certain risk factor and an outcome.                              Rate Ratio                =                              Incidence Rate 1            Incidence Rate 2                                {\displaystyle {\text{Rate Ratio}}={\frac {\text{Incidence Rate 1}}{\text{Incidence Rate 2}}}}   Where incidence rate is the occurrence of an event over person-time
column3: for example person-years.                              Incidence Rate                =                              events            person time                                {\displaystyle {\text{Incidence Rate}}={\frac {\text{events}}{\text{person time}}}}  Note: the same time intervals must be used for both incidence rates.|

column2: heavy-tailed distributions are probability distributions whose tails are not exponentially bounded: that is
column3: they have heavier tails than the exponential distribution. In many applications it is the right tail of the distribution that is of interest
column4: but a distribution may have a heavy left tail
column5: or both tails may be heavy.There are three important subclasses of heavy-tailed distributions: the fat-tailed distributions
column6: the long-tailed distributions and the subexponential distributions. In practice
column7: all commonly used heavy-tailed distributions belong to the subexponential class.There is still some discrepancy over the use of the term heavy-tailed. There are two other definitions in use. Some authors use the term to refer to those distributions which do not have all their power moments finite; and some others to those distributions that do not have a finite variance. The definition given in this article is the most general in use
column8: and includes all distributions encompassed by the alternative definitions
column9: as well as those distributions such as log-normal that possess all their power moments
column10: yet which are generally acknowledged to be heavy-tailed. (Occasionally
column11: heavy-tailed is used for any distribution that has heavier tails than the normal distribution.)|

column1: transition-matrix |For a matrix whose elements are stochastic
column2: see Random matrixIn mathematics
column3: a stochastic matrix (also termed probability matrix
column4: transition matrix
column5: substitution matrix
column6: or Markov matrix) is a matrix used to describe the transitions of a Markov chain. Each of its entries is a nonnegative real number representing a probability. It has found use in probability theory
column7: statistics
column8: mathematical finance and linear algebra
column9: as well as computer science and population genetics. There are several different definitions and types of stochastic matrices:A right stochastic matrix is a real square matrix
column10: with each row summing to 1.A left stochastic matrix is a real square matrix
column11: with each column summing to 1.A doubly stochastic matrix is a square matrix of nonnegative real numbers with each row and column summing to 1.In the same vein
column12: one may define stochastic vector (also called probability vector) as a vector whose elements are nonnegative real numbers which sum to 1. Thus
column13: each row of a right stochastic matrix (or column of a left stochastic matrix) is a stochastic vector.A common convention in English language mathematics literature is to use row vectors of probabilities and right stochastic matrices rather than column vectors of probabilities and left stochastic matrices; this article follows that convention.|

column2: the Laplace distribution is a continuous probability distribution named after Pierre-Simon Laplace. It is also sometimes called the double exponential distribution
column3: because it can be thought of as two exponential distributions (with an additional location parameter) spliced together back-to-back
column4: although the term 'double exponential distribution' is also sometimes used to refer to the Gumbel distribution. The difference between two independent identically distributed exponential random variables is governed by a Laplace distribution
column5: as is a Brownian motion evaluated at an exponentially distributed random time. Increments of Laplace motion or a variance gamma process evaluated over the time scale also have a Laplace distribution.|

column2: survey sampling describes the process of selecting a sample of elements from a target population to conduct a survey. The term "survey" may refer to many different types or techniques of observation. In survey sampling it most often involves a questionnaire used to measure the characteristics and/or attitudes of people. Different ways of contacting members of a sample once they have been selected is the subject of survey data collection. The purpose of sampling is to reduce the cost and/or the amount of work that it would take to survey the entire target population. A survey that measures the entire target population is called a census.Survey samples can be broadly divided into two types: probability samples and non-probability samples. Probability-based samples implement a sampling plan with specified probabilities (perhaps adapted probabilities specified by an adaptive procedure). Probability-based sampling allows design-based inference about the target population. The inferences are based on a known objective probability distribution that was specified in the study protocol. Inferences from probability-based surveys may still suffer from many types of bias.Surveys that are not based on probability sampling have greater difficulty measuring their bias or sampling error. Surveys based on non-probability samples often fail to represent the people in the target population.In academic and government survey research
column3: probability sampling is a standard procedure. In the United States
column4: the Office of Management and Budget's "List of Standards for Statistical Surveys" states that federally funded surveys must be performed:selecting samples using generally accepted statistical methods (e.g.
column5: probabilistic methods that can provide estimates of sampling error). Any use of nonprobability sampling methods (e.g.
column6: cut-off or model-based samples) must be justified statistically and be able to measure estimation error.Besides
column7: random sampling and design-based inference are supplemented by other statistical methods
column8: such as model-assisted sampling and model-based sampling.For example
column9: many surveys have substantial amounts of nonresponse. Even though the units are initially chosen with known probabilities
column10: the nonresponse mechanisms are unknown. For surveys with substantial nonresponse
column11: statisticians have proposed statistical models
column12: with which data sets are analyzed.Issues related to survey sampling are discussed in several sources including Salant and Dillman (1994).|

column2: mathematics
column3: statistics
column4: and economics
column5: scale invariance is a feature of objects or laws that do not change if scales of length
column6: energy
column7: or other variables
column8: are multiplied by a common factor. The technical term for this transformation is a dilatation (also known as dilation)
column9: and the dilatations can also form part of a larger conformal symmetry.In mathematics
column10: scale invariance usually refers to an invariance of individual functions or curves. A closely related concept is self-similarity
column11: where a function or curve is invariant under a discrete subset of the dilatations. It is also possible for the probability distributions of random processes to display this kind of scale invariance or self-similarity.In classical field theory
column12: scale invariance most commonly applies to the invariance of a whole theory under dilatations. Such theories typically describe classical physical processes with no characteristic length scale.In quantum field theory
column13: scale invariance has an interpretation in terms of particle physics. In a scale-invariant theory
column14: the strength of particle interactions does not depend on the energy of the particles involved.In statistical mechanics
column15: scale invariance is a feature of phase transitions. The key observation is that near a phase transition or critical point
column16: fluctuations occur at all length scales
column17: and thus one should look for an explicitly scale-invariant theory to describe the phenomena. Such theories are scale-invariant statistical field theories
column18: and are formally very similar to scale-invariant quantum field theories.Universality is the observation that widely different microscopic systems can display the same behaviour at a phase transition. Thus phase transitions in many different systems may be described by the same underlying scale-invariant theory.In general
column19: dimensionless quantities are scale invariant. The analogous concept in statistics are standardized moments
column20: which are scale invariant statistics of a variable
column21: while the unstandardized moments are not.|

column1: non-response |Non-response bias occurs in statistical surveys if the answers of respondents differ from the potential answers of those who did not answer. It may occur due to several factors as outlined in Deming (1990).|

statistical-control |Statistical process control (SPC) is a method of quality control which uses statistical methods. SPC is applied in order to monitor and control a process. Monitoring and controlling the process ensures that it operates at its full potential. At its full potential
column2: the process can make as much conforming product as possible with a minimum (if not an elimination) of waste (rework or scrap). SPC can be applied to any process where the "conforming product" (product meeting specifications) output can be measured. Key tools used in SPC include control charts; a focus on continuous improvement; and the design of experiments. An example of a process where SPC is applied is manufacturing lines.|
quasi-likelihood estimation is one way of allowing for overdispersion
column3: that is
column4: greater variability in the data than would be expected from the statistical model used. It is most often used with models for count data or grouped binary data
column5: i.e. data that would otherwise be modelled using the Poisson or binomial distribution.The term quasi-likelihood function was introduced by Robert Wedderburn in 1974 to describe a function which has similar properties to the log-likelihood function
column6: except that a quasi-likelihood function is not the log-likelihood corresponding to any actual probability distribution. Quasi-likelihood models can be fitted using a straightforward extension of the algorithms used to fit generalized linear models.Instead of specifying a probability distribution for the data
column7: only a relationship between the mean and the variance is specified in the form of a variance function giving the variance as a function of the mean. Generally
column8: this function is allowed to include a multiplicative factor known as the overdispersion parameter or scale parameter that is estimated from the data. Most commonly
column9: the variance function is of a form such that fixing the overdispersion parameter at unity results in the variance-mean relationship of an actual probability distribution such as the binomial or Poisson. (For formulae
column10: see the binomial data example and count data example under generalized linear models.)|

column1: k-medoids |The k-medoids algorithm is a clustering algorithm related to the k-means algorithm and the medoidshift algorithm. Both the k-means and k-medoids algorithms are partitional (breaking the dataset up into groups) and both attempt to minimize the distance between points labeled to be in a cluster and a point designated as the center of that cluster. In contrast to the k-means algorithm
column2: k-medoids chooses datapoints as centers (medoids or exemplars) and works with an arbitrary metrics of distances between datapoints instead of {\displaystyle l_{1}}   norm and other distances.k-medoid is a classical partitioning technique of clustering that clusters the data set of n objects into k clusters known a priori. A useful tool for determining k is the silhouette.It is more robust to noise and outliers as compared to k-means because it minimizes a sum of pairwise dissimilarities instead of a sum of squared Euclidean distances.A medoid can be defined as the object of a cluster whose average dissimilarity to all the objects in the cluster is minimal. i.e. it is a most centrally located point in the cluster.|
particularly in regression analysis
column3: a dummy variable (also known as an indicator variable
column4: design variable
column5: Boolean indicator
column6: categorical variable
column7: binary variable
column8: or qualitative variable) is one that takes the value 0 or 1 to indicate the absence or presence of some categorical effect that may be expected to shift the outcome. Dummy variables are used as devices to sort data into mutually exclusive categories (such as smoker/non-smoker
column9: etc.). For example
column10: in econometric time series analysis
column11: dummy variables may be used to indicate the occurrence of wars or major strikes. A dummy variable can thus be thought of as a truth value represented as a numerical value 0 or 1 (as is sometimes done in computer programming).Dummy variables are "proxy" variables or numeric stand-ins for qualitative facts in a regression model. In regression analysis
column12: the dependent variables may be influenced not only by quantitative variables (income
column13: output
column14: prices
column15: etc.)
column16: but also by qualitative variables (gender
column17: religion
column18: geographic region
column19: etc.). A dummy independent variable (also called a dummy explanatory variable) which for some observation has a value of 0 will cause that variable's coefficient to have no role in influencing the dependent variable
column20: while when the dummy takes on a value 1 its coefficient acts to alter the intercept. For example
column21: suppose Gender is one of the qualitative variables relevant to a regression. Then
column22: female and male would be the categories included under the Gender variable. If female is arbitrarily assigned the value of 1
column23: then male would get the value 0. Then the intercept (the value of the dependent variable if all other explanatory variables hypothetically took on the value zero) would be the constant term for males but would be the constant term plus the coefficient of the gender dummy in the case of females.Dummy variables are used frequently in time series analysis with regime switching
column24: seasonal analysis and qualitative data applications. Dummy variables are involved in studies for economic forecasting
column25: bio-medical studies
column26: credit scoring
column27: response modelling
column28: etc. Dummy variables may be incorporated in traditional regression methods or newly developed modeling paradigms.|

column2: total least squares is a type of errors-in-variables regression
column3: a least squares data modeling technique in which observational errors on both dependent and independent variables are taken into account. It is a generalization of Deming regression and also of orthogonal regression
column4: and can be applied to both linear and non-linear models.The total least squares approximation of the data is generically equivalent to the best
column5: in the Frobenius norm
column6: low-rank approximation of the data matrix.|

column2: a likelihood function (often simply the likelihood) is a function of the parameters of a statistical model given data. Likelihood functions play a key role in statistical inference
column3: especially methods of estimating a parameter from a set of statistics. In informal contexts
column4: "likelihood" is often used as a synonym for "probability." In statistics
column5: a distinction is made depending on the roles of outcomes vs. parameters. Probability is used before data are available to describe possible future outcomes given a fixed value for the parameter (or parameter vector). Likelihood is used after data are available to describe a function of a parameter (or parameter vector) for a given outcome.|

column1: interactive-visualization |Interactive visualization or interactive visualisation is a branch of graphic visualization in computer science that involves studying how humans interact with computers to create graphic illustrations of information and how this process can be made more efficient.For a visualization to be considered interactive it must satisfy two criteria:Human input: control of some aspect of the visual representation of information
column2: or of the information being represented
column3: must be available to a human
column4: andResponse time: changes made by the human must be incorporated into the visualization in a timely manner. In general
column5: interactive visualization is considered a soft real-time task.One particular type of interactive visualization is virtual reality (VR)
column6: where the visual representation of information is presented using an immersive display device such as a stereo projector (see stereoscopy). VR is also characterized by the use of a spatial metaphor
column7: where some aspect of the information is represented in three dimensions so that humans can explore the information as if it were present (where instead it was remote)
column8: sized appropriately (where instead it was on a much smaller or larger scale than humans can sense directly)
column9: or had shape (where instead it might be completely abstract).Another type of interactive visualization is collaborative visualization
column10: in which multiple people interact with the same computer visualization to communicate their ideas to each other or to explore information cooperatively. Frequently
column11: collaborative visualization is used when people are physically separated. Using several networked computers
column12: the same visualization can be presented to each person simultaneously. The people then make annotations to the visualization as well as communicate via audio (i.e.
column13: telephone)
column14: video (i.e.
column15: a video-conference)
column16: or text (i.e.
column17: IRC) messages.|

column2: an interaction may arise when considering the relationship among three or more variables
column3: and describes a situation in which the simultaneous influence of two variables on a third is not additive. Most commonly
column4: interactions are considered in the context of regression analyses.The presence of interactions can have important implications for the interpretation of statistical models. If two variables of interest interact
column5: the relationship between each of the interacting variables and a third "dependent variable" depends on the value of the other interacting variable. In practice
column6: this makes it more difficult to predict the consequences of changing the value of a variable
column7: particularly if the variables it interacts with are hard to measure or difficult to control.The notion of "interaction" is closely related to that of "moderation" that is common in social and health science research: the interaction between an explanatory variable and an environmental variable suggests that the effect of the explanatory variable has been moderated or modified by the environmental variable.|

column2: the truncated normal distribution is the probability distribution of a normally distributed random variable whose value is either bounded below or above (or both). The truncated normal distribution has wide applications in statistics and econometrics. For example
column3: it is used to model the probabilities of the binary outcomes in the probit model and to model censored data in the Tobit model.|

column1: probabilistic-programming |A probabilistic programming language (PPL) is a programming language designed to describe probabilistic models and then perform inference in those models. PPLs are closely related to graphical models and Bayesian networks
column2: but are more expressive and flexible. Probabilistic programming represents an attempt to "[unify] general purpose programming with probabilistic modeling."Probabilistic reasoning is a foundational technology of machine learning. It is used by companies such as Google
column3: Amazon.com and Microsoft. Probabilistic reasoning has been used for predicting stock prices
column4: recommending movies
column5: diagnosing computers
column6: detecting cyber intrusions and image detection.PPLs often extend from a basic language. The choice of underlying basic language depends on the similarity of the model to the basic language's ontology
column7: as well as commercial considerations and personal preference. For instance
column8: Dimple and Chimple are based on Java
column9: Infer.NET is based on .NET framework
column10: while PRISM extends from Prolog. However
column11: some PPLs such as WinBUGS and Stan offer a self-contained language
column12: with no obvious origin in another language.Several PPLs are in active development
column13: including some in beta test.|

column2: also known as piecewise regression or 'broken-stick regression'
column3: is a method in regression analysis in which the independent variable is partitioned into intervals and a separate line segment is fit to each interval. Segmented regression analysis can also be performed on multivariate data by partitioning the various independent variables. Segmented regression is useful when the independent variables
column4: clustered into different groups
column5: exhibit different relationships between the variables in these regions. The boundaries between the segments are breakpoints.Segmented linear regression is segmented regression whereby the relations in the intervals are obtained by linear regression.|

column2: also known as Shewhart charts (after Walter A. Shewhart) or process-behavior charts
column3: are a statistical process control tool used to determine if a manufacturing or business process is in a state of control.|

column2: a mixture model is a probabilistic model for representing the presence of subpopulations within an overall population
column3: without requiring that an observed data set should identify the sub-population to which an individual observation belongs. Formally a mixture model corresponds to the mixture distribution that represents the probability distribution of observations in the overall population. However
column4: while problems associated with "mixture distributions" relate to deriving the properties of the overall population from those of the sub-populations
column5: "mixture models" are used to make statistical inferences about the properties of the sub-populations given only observations on the pooled population
column6: without sub-population identity information.Some ways of implementing mixture models involve steps that attribute postulated sub-population-identities to individual observations (or weights towards such sub-populations)
column7: in which case these can be regarded as types of unsupervised learning or clustering procedures. However
column8: not all inference procedures involve such steps.Mixture models should not be confused with models for compositional data
column9: i.e.
column10: data whose components are constrained to sum to a constant value (1
column12: etc.). However
column13: compositional models can be thought of as mixture models
column14: where members of the population are sampled at random. Conversely
column15: mixture models can be thought of as compositional models
column16: where the total size of the population has been normalized to 1.|

column2: a bimodal distribution is a continuous probability distribution with two different modes. These appear as distinct peaks (local maxima) in the probability density function
column3: as shown in Figure 1.More generally
column4: a multimodal distribution is a continuous probability distribution with two or more modes
column5: as illustrated in Figure 3.|

column1: trimmed-mean |A truncated mean or trimmed mean is a statistical measure of central tendency
column2: much like the mean and median. It involves the calculation of the mean after discarding given parts of a probability distribution or sample at the high and low end
column3: and typically discarding an equal amount of both. This number of points to be discarded is usually given as a percentage of the total number of points
column4: but may also be given as a fixed number of points.For most statistical applications
column5: 5 to 25 percent of the ends are discarded; the 25% trimmed mean (when the lowest 25% and the highest 25% are discarded) is known as the interquartile mean. For example
column6: given a set of 8 points
column7: trimming by 12.5% would discard the minimum and maximum value in the sample: the smallest and largest values
column8: and would compute the mean of the remaining 6 points.The median can be regarded as a fully truncated mean and is most robust. As with other trimmed estimators
column9: the main advantage of the trimmed mean is robustness and higher efficiency for mixed distributions and heavy-tailed distribution (like the Cauchy distribution)
column10: at the cost of lower efficiency for some other less heavily-tailed distributions (such as the normal distribution). For intermediate distributions the differences between the efficiency of the mean and the median are not very big
column11: e.g. for the student-t distribution with 2 degrees of freedom the variances for mean and median are nearly equal.|

column1: neuroimaging |Neuroimaging or brain imaging is the use of various techniques to either directly or indirectly image the structure
column2: function/pharmacology of the nervous system. It is a relatively new discipline within medicine
column3: neuroscience
column4: and psychology. Physicians who specialize in the performance and interpretation of neuroimaging in the clinical setting are neuroradiologists.Neuroimaging falls into two broad categories:Structural imaging
column5: which deals with the structure of the nervous system and the diagnosis of gross (large scale) intracranial disease (such as tumor)
column6: and injury
column7: andFunctional imaging
column8: which is used to diagnose metabolic diseases and lesions on a finer scale (such as Alzheimer's disease) and also for neurological and cognitive psychology research and building brain-computer interfaces.Functional imaging enables
column9: for example
column10: the processing of information by centers in the brain to be visualized directly. Such processing causes the involved area of the brain to increase metabolism and "light up" on the scan. One of the more controversial uses of neuroimaging has been research into "thought identification" or mind-reading.|

column2: the multivariate t-distribution (or multivariate Student distribution) is a multivariate probability distribution. It is a generalization to random vectors of the Student's t-distribution
column3: which is a distribution applicable to univariate random variables. While the case of a random matrix could be treated within this structure
column4: the matrix t-distribution is distinct and makes particular use of the matrix structure.|

column2: the theory of optimal stopping is concerned with the problem of choosing a time to take a particular action
column3: in order to maximise an expected reward or minimise an expected cost. Optimal stopping problems can be found in areas of statistics
column4: economics
column5: and mathematical finance (related to the pricing of American options). A key example of an optimal stopping problem is the secretary problem. Optimal stopping problems can often be written in the form of a Bellman equation
column6: and are therefore often solved using dynamic programming.|

column1: sequential-pattern-mining |Sequential pattern mining is a topic of data mining concerned with finding statistically relevant patterns between data examples where the values are delivered in a sequence. It is usually presumed that the values are discrete
column2: and thus time series mining is closely related
column3: but usually considered a different activity. Sequential pattern mining is a special case of structured data mining.There are several key traditional computational problems addressed within this field. These include building efficient databases and indexes for sequence information
column4: extracting the frequently occurring patterns
column5: comparing sequences for similarity
column6: and recovering missing sequence members. In general
column7: sequence mining problems can be classified as string mining which is typically based on string processing algorithms and itemset mining which is typically based on association rule learning.|

column2: a Taylor series is a representation of a function as an infinite sum of terms that are calculated from the values of the function's derivatives at a single point.The concept of a Taylor series was formulated by the Scottish mathematician James Gregory and formally introduced by the English mathematician Brook Taylor in 1715. If the Taylor series is centered at zero
column3: then that series is also called a Maclaurin series
column4: named after the Scottish mathematician Colin Maclaurin
column5: who made extensive use of this special case of Taylor series in the 18th century.A function can be approximated by using a finite number of terms of its Taylor series. Taylor's theorem gives quantitative estimates on the error introduced by the use of such an approximation. The polynomial formed by taking some initial terms of the Taylor series is called a Taylor polynomial. The Taylor series of a function is the limit of that function's Taylor polynomials as the degree increases
column6: provided that the limit exists. A function may not be equal to its Taylor series
column7: even if its Taylor series converges at every point. A function that is equal to its Taylor series in an open interval (or a disc in the complex plane) is known as an analytic function in that interval.|

column2: a zero-inflated model is a statistical model based on a zero-inflated probability distribution
column3: i.e. a distribution that allows for frequent zero-valued observations.|

column2: the skew normal distribution is a continuous probability distribution that generalises the normal distribution to allow for non-zero skewness.|
per-comparison error rate (PCER) is the probability of a Type I error in the absence of any multiple hypothesis testing correction. This is a relatively liberal error rate
column3: in contrast to the false discovery rate and familywise error rate.|

column2: the coverage probability of a confidence interval is the proportion of the time that the interval contains the true value of interest. For example
column3: suppose our interest is in the mean number of months that people with a particular type of cancer remain in remission following successful treatment with chemotherapy. The confidence interval aims to contain the unknown mean remission duration with a given probability. This is the "confidence level" or "confidence coefficient" of the constructed interval which is effectively the "nominal coverage probability" of the procedure for constructing confidence intervals. The "nominal coverage probability" is often set at 0.95. The coverage probability is the actual probability that the interval contains the true mean remission duration in this example.If all assumptions used in deriving a confidence interval are met
column4: the nominal coverage probability will equal the coverage probability (termed "true" or "actual" coverage probability for emphasis). If any assumptions are not met
column5: the actual coverage probability could either be less than or greater than the nominal coverage probability. When the actual coverage probability is greater than the nominal coverage probability
column6: the interval is termed "conservative"
column7: if it is less than the nominal coverage probability
column8: the interval is termed "anti-conservative"
column9: or "permissive."A discrepancy between the coverage probability and the nominal coverage probability frequently occurs when approximating a discrete distribution with a continuous one. The construction of binomial confidence intervals is a classic example where coverage probabilities rarely equal nominal levels. For the binomial case
column10: several techniques for constructing intervals have been created. The Wilson or Score confidence interval is one well known construction based on the normal distribution. Other constructions include the Wald
column11: exact
column12: Agresti-Coull
column13: and likelihood intervals. While the Wilson interval may not be the most conservative estimate
column14: it produces average coverage probabilities that are equal to nominal levels while still producing a comparatively narrow confidence interval.The "probability" in coverage probability is interpreted with respect to a set of hypothetical repetitions of the entire data collection and analysis procedure. In these hypothetical repetitions
column15: independent data sets following the same probability distribution as the actual data are considered
column16: and a confidence interval is computed from each of these data sets; see Neyman construction.|

column2: a Bernoulli process is a finite or infinite sequence of binary random variables
column3: so it is a discrete-time stochastic process that takes only two values
column4: canonically 0 and 1. The component Bernoulli variables Xi are identical and independent. Prosaically
column5: a Bernoulli process is a repeated coin flipping
column6: possibly with an unfair coin (but with consistent unfairness). Every variable Xi in the sequence is associated with a Bernoulli trial or experiment. They all have the same Bernoulli distribution. Much of what can be said about the Bernoulli process can also be generalized to more than two outcomes (such as the process for a six-sided die); this generalization is known as the Bernoulli scheme.The problem of determining the process
column7: given only a limited sample of the Bernoulli trials
column8: may be called the problem of checking whether a coin is fair.|

column1: causalimpact |Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS) model is a machine learning technique used for feature selection
column2: time series forecasting
column3: nowcasting
column4: inferring causal impact and other. The model is designed to work with time series data.The model has also promising application in the field of analytical marketing. In particular
column5: it can be used in order to assess how much different marketing campaigns have contributed to the change in web search volumes
column6: product sales
column7: brand popularity and other relevant indicators (difference-in-differences model is a usual alternative approach in this case). "In contrast to classical difference-in-differences schemes
column8: state-space models make it possible to (i) infer the temporal evolution of attributable impact
column9: (ii) incorporate empirical priors on the parameters in a fully Bayesian treatment
column10: and (iii) flexibly accommodate multiple sources of variation
column11: including the time-varying influence of contemporaneous covariates
column12: i.e.
column13: synthetic controls."|

column2: also non-negative matrix approximation is a group of algorithms in multivariate analysis and linear algebra where a matrix V is factorized into (usually) two matrices W and H
column3: with the property that all three matrices have no negative elements. This non-negativity makes the resulting matrices easier to inspect. Also
column4: in applications such as processing of audio spectrograms or muscular activity
column5: non-negativity is inherent to the data being considered. Since the problem is not exactly solvable in general
column6: it is commonly approximated numerically.NMF finds applications in such fields as computer vision
column7: document clustering
column8: chemometrics
column9: audio signal processing and recommender systems.|

column2: multinomial logistic regression is a classification method that generalizes logistic regression to multiclass problems
column3: i.e. with more than two possible discrete outcomes. That is
column4: it is a model that is used to predict the probabilities of the different possible outcomes of a categorically distributed dependent variable
column5: given a set of independent variables (which may be real-valued
column6: binary-valued
column7: categorical-valued
column8: etc.).Multinomial logistic regression is known by a variety of other names
column9: including polytomous LR
column10: multiclass LR
column11: softmax regression
column12: multinomial logit
column13: maximum entropy (MaxEnt) classifier
column14: conditional maximum entropy model.|

column1: open-bugs |A software bug is an error
column2: flaw
column3: failure or fault in a computer program or system that causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result
column4: or to behave in unintended ways. Most bugs arise from mistakes and errors made in either a program's source code or its design
column5: or in components and operating systems used by such programs. A few are caused by compilers producing incorrect code. A program that contains a large number of bugs
column6: and/or bugs that seriously interfere with its functionality
column7: is said to be buggy (defective).Bugs trigger errors that may have ripple effects. Bugs may have subtle effects or cause the program to crash or freeze the computer. Others qualify as security bugs and might
column8: for example
column9: enable a malicious user to bypass access controls in order to obtain unauthorized privileges.Bugs in code that controls the Therac-25 radiation therapy machine were directly responsible for patient deaths in the 1980s. In 1996
column10: the European Space Agency's US59 billion annually
column11: or about 0.6 percent of the gross domestic product".|

column1: average-precision |Information retrieval (IR) is the activity of obtaining information resources relevant to an information need from a collection of information resources. Searches can be based on full-text or other content-based indexing.Automated information retrieval systems are used to reduce what has been called "information overload". Many universities and public libraries use IR systems to provide access to books
column2: journals and other documents. Web search engines are the most visible IR applications.|

column1: variance-decomposition |In econometrics and other applications of multivariate time series analysis
column2: a variance decomposition or forecast error variance decomposition (FEVD) is used to aid in the interpretation of a vector autoregression (VAR) model once it has been fitted. The variance decomposition indicates the amount of information each variable contributes to the other variables in the autoregression. It determines how much of the forecast error variance of each of the variables can be explained by exogenous shocks to the other variables.|

column1: two-step-estimation |Software development effort estimation is the process of predicting the most realistic amount of effort (expressed in terms of person-hours or money) required to develop or maintain software based on incomplete
column2: uncertain and noisy input. Effort estimates may be used as input to project plans
column3: iteration plans
column4: budgets
column5: investment analyses
column6: pricing processes and bidding rounds.|

column1: matplotlib |matplotlib is a plotting library for the Python programming language and its numerical mathematics extension NumPy. It provides an object-oriented API for embedding plots into applications using general-purpose GUI toolkits like wxPython
column2: Qt
column3: or GTK+. There is also a procedural "pylab" interface based on a state machine (like OpenGL)
column4: designed to closely resemble that of MATLAB. SciPy makes use of matplotlib.matplotlib was originally written by John D. Hunter
column5: has an active development community
column6: and is distributed under a BSD-style license. Michael Droettboom was nominated as matplotlib's lead developer shortly before John Hunter's death in 2012.As of 30 October 2015
column7: matplotlib 1.5.x supports Python versions 2.7 through 3.5. Matplotlib 1.2 is the first version of matplotlib to support Python 3.x. Matplotlib 1.4 is the last version of matplotlib to support Python 2.6.|

column1: directional-statistics |Directional statistics (also circular statistics or spherical statistics) is the subdiscipline of statistics that deals with directions (unit vectors in Rn)
column2: axes (lines through the origin in Rn) or rotations in Rn. More generally
column3: directional statistics deals with observations on compact Riemannian manifolds.The fact that 0 degrees and 360 degrees are identical angles
column4: so that for example 180 degrees is not a sensible mean of 2 degrees and 358 degrees
column5: provides one illustration that special statistical methods are required for the analysis of some types of data (in this case
column6: angular data). Other examples of data that may be regarded as directional include statistics involving temporal periods (e.g. time of day
column7: week
column8: month
column9: year
column10: etc.)
column11: compass directions
column12: dihedral angles in molecules
column13: orientations
column14: rotations and so on.|

column2: a score function
column3: or scoring rule
column4: measures the accuracy of probabilistic predictions. It is applicable to tasks in which predictions must assign probabilities to a set of mutually exclusive discrete outcomes. The set of possible outcomes can be either binary or categorical in nature
column5: and the probabilities assigned to this set of outcomes must sum to one (where each individual probability is in the range of 0 to 1). A score can be thought of as either a measure of the "calibration" of a set of probabilistic predictions
column6: or as a "cost function" or "loss function".If a cost is levied in proportion to a proper scoring rule
column7: the minimal expected cost corresponds to reporting the true set of probabilities. Proper scoring rules are used in meteorology
column8: finance
column9: and pattern classification where a forecaster or algorithm will attempt to minimize the average score to yield refined
column10: calibrated probabilities (i.e. accurate probabilities). Various scoring rules have also been used to assess the predictive accuracy of forecast models for association football.|

column1: nonparametric-regression |Nonparametric regression is a category of regression analysis in which the predictor does not take a predetermined form but is constructed according to information derived from the data. Nonparametric regression requires larger sample sizes than regression based on parametric models because the data must supply the model structure as well as the model estimates.|
linearity |Linearity is the property of a mathematical relationship or function which means that it can be graphically represented as a straight line
column2: that is
column3: that one quantity is simply proportional to another. Examples are the relationship of voltage and current across a resistor (Ohm's law)
column4: or the mass and weight of an object.|

column1: recurrent-events |A recurrent neural network (RNN) is a class of artificial neural network where connections between units form a directed cycle. This creates an internal state of the network which allows it to exhibit dynamic temporal behavior. Unlike feedforward neural networks
column2: RNNs can use their internal memory to process arbitrary sequences of inputs. This makes them applicable to tasks such as unsegmented connected handwriting recognition or speech recognition.|

column1: pie-chart |A pie chart (or a circle chart) is a circular statistical graphic
column2: which is divided into slices to illustrate numerical proportion. In a pie chart
column3: the arc length of each slice (and consequently its central angle and area)
column4: is proportional to the quantity it represents. While it is named for its resemblance to a pie which has been sliced
column5: there are variations on the way it can be presented. The earliest known pie chart is generally credited to William Playfair's Statistical Breviary of 1801.Pie charts are very widely used in the business world and the mass media. However
column6: they have been criticized
column7: and many experts recommend avoiding them
column8: pointing out that research has shown it is difficult to compare different sections of a given pie chart
column9: or to compare data across different pie charts. Pie charts can be replaced in most cases by other plots such as the bar chart
column10: box plot or dot plots.In some very rare instances
column11: pie charts can be found in square form. These kinds of pie charts are sometimes referred to as "pizza charts"
column12: as the square resembles the shape of a pizza box. These square pie charts serve the same purpose as circular pie charts and all percentages are taken from a 100% total.|

column2: overdispersion is the presence of greater variability (statistical dispersion) in a data set than would be expected based on a given statistical model.A common task in applied statistics is choosing a parametric model to fit a given set of empirical observations. This necessitates an assessment of the fit of the chosen model. It is usually possible to choose the model parameters in such a way that the theoretical population mean of the model is approximately equal to the sample mean. However
column3: especially for simple models with few parameters
column4: theoretical predictions may not match empirical observations for higher moments. When the observed variance is higher than the variance of a theoretical model
column5: overdispersion has occurred. Conversely
column6: underdispersion means that there was less variation in the data than predicted. Overdispersion is a very common feature in applied data analysis because in practice
column7: populations are frequently heterogeneous (non-uniform) contrary to the assumptions implicit within widely used simple parametric models.|

column2: matrix calculus is a specialized notation for doing multivariable calculus
column3: especially over spaces of matrices. It collects the various partial derivatives of a single function with respect to many variables
column4: and/or of a multivariate function with respect to a single variable
column5: into vectors and matrices that can be treated as single entities. This greatly simplifies operations such as finding the maximum or minimum of a multivariate function and solving systems of differential equations. The notation used here is commonly used in statistics and engineering
column6: while the tensor index notation is preferred in physics.Two competing notational conventions split the field of matrix calculus into two separate groups. The two groups can be distinguished by whether they write the derivative of a scalar with respect to a vector as a column vector or a row vector. Both of these conventions are possible even when the common assumption is made that vectors should be treated as column vectors when combined with matrices (rather than row vectors). A single convention can be somewhat standard throughout a single field that commonly use matrix calculus (e.g. econometrics
column7: statistics
column8: estimation theory and machine learning). However
column9: even within a given field different authors can be found using competing conventions. Authors of both groups often write as though their specific convention is standard. Serious mistakes can result when combining results from different authors without carefully verifying that compatible notations are used. Therefore
column10: great care should be taken to ensure notational consistency. Definitions of these two conventions and comparisons between them are collected in the layout conventions section.|

column1: latent-semantic-indexing |Latent semantic analysis (LSA) is a technique in natural language processing
column2: in particular distributional semantics
column3: of analyzing relationships between a set of documents and the terms they contain by producing a set of concepts related to the documents and terms. LSA assumes that words that are close in meaning will occur in similar pieces of text. A matrix containing word counts per paragraph (rows represent unique words and columns represent each paragraph) is constructed from a large piece of text and a mathematical technique called singular value decomposition (SVD) is used to reduce the number of rows while preserving the similarity structure among columns. Words are then compared by taking the cosine of the angle between the two vectors (or the dot product between the normalizations of the two vectors) formed by any two rows. Values close to 1 represent very similar words while values close to 0 represent very dissimilar words.An information retrieval technique using latent semantic structure was patented in 1988 (US Patent 4
column6: now expired) by Scott Deerwester
column7: Susan Dumais
column8: George Furnas
column9: Richard Harshman
column10: Thomas Landauer
column11: Karen Lochbaum and Lynn Streeter. In the context of its application to information retrieval
column12: it is sometimes called Latent Semantic Indexing (LSI).|

column1: q-learning |Q-learning is a model-free reinforcement learning technique. Specifically
column2: Q-learning can be used to find an optimal action-selection policy for any given (finite) Markov decision process (MDP). It works by learning an action-value function that ultimately gives the expected utility of taking a given action in a given state and following the optimal policy thereafter. A policy is a rule that the agent follows in selecting actions
column3: given the state it is in. When such an action-value function is learned
