column16: and anomaly detection.A key measure in information theory is "entropy". Entropy quantifies the amount of uncertainty involved in the value of a random variable or the outcome of a random process. For example
column17: identifying the outcome of a fair coin flip (with two equally likely outcomes) provides less information (lower entropy) than specifying the outcome from a roll of a die (with six equally likely outcomes). Some other important measures in information theory are mutual information
column18: channel capacity
column19: error exponents
column20: and relative entropy.Applications of fundamental topics of information theory include lossless data compression (e.g. ZIP files)
column21: lossy data compression (e.g. MP3s and JPEGs)
column22: and channel coding (e.g. for Digital Subscriber Line (DSL)).The field is at the intersection of mathematics
column23: statistics
column24: computer science
column25: physics
column26: neurobiology
column27: and electrical engineering. Its impact has been crucial to the success of the Voyager missions to deep space
column28: the invention of the compact disc
column31: the study of linguistics and of human perception
column33: and numerous other fields. Important sub-fields of information theory include source coding

column1: test-equating |Test equating traditionally refers to the statistical process of determining comparable scores on different forms of an exam. It can be accomplished using either classical test theory or item response theory.In item response theory
column2: equating is the process of placing scores from two or more parallel test forms onto a common score scale. The result is that scores from two different test forms can be compared directly
column3: or treated as though they came from the same test form. When the tests are not parallel
column4: the general process is called linking. It is the process of equating the units and origins of two scales on which the abilities of students have been estimated from results on different tests. The process is analogous to equating degrees Fahrenheit with degrees Celsius by converting measurements from one scale to the other. The determination of comparable scores is a by-product of equating that results from equating the scales obtained from test results.|

column2: the method of moments is a method of estimation of population parameters. One starts with deriving equations that relate the population moments (i.e.
column3: the expected values of powers of the random variable under consideration) to the parameters of interest. Then a sample is drawn and the population moments are estimated from the sample. The equations are then solved for the parameters of interest
column4: using the sample moments in place of the (unknown) population moments. This results in estimates of those parameters. The method of moments was introduced by Karl Pearson in 1894.|

column1: propensity |The propensity theory of probability is one interpretation of the concept of probability. Theorists who adopt this interpretation think of probability as a physical propensity
column2: or disposition
column3: or tendency of a given type of physical situation to yield an outcome of a certain kind
column4: or to yield a long run relative frequency of such an outcome.Propensities are not relative frequencies
column5: but purported causes of the observed stable relative frequencies. Propensities are invoked to explain why repeating a certain kind of experiment will generate a given outcome type at a persistent rate. A central aspect of this explanation is the law of large numbers. This law
column6: which is a consequence of the axioms of probability
column7: says that if (for example) a coin is tossed repeatedly many times
column8: in such a way that its probability of landing heads is the same on each toss
column9: and the outcomes are probabilistically independent
column10: then the relative frequency of heads will (with high probability) be close to the probability of heads on each single toss. This law suggests that stable long-run frequencies are a manifestation of invariant single-case probabilities. Frequentists are unable to take this approach
column11: since relative frequencies do not exist for single tosses of a coin
column12: but only for large ensembles or collectives. Hence
column13: these single-case probabilities are known as propensities or chances.In addition to explaining the emergence of stable relative frequencies
column14: the idea of propensity is motivated by the desire to make sense of single-case probability attributions in quantum mechanics
column15: such as the probability of decay of a particular atom at a particular time.The main challenge facing propensity theories is to say exactly what propensity means
column16: and to show that propensity thus defined has the required properties.|

column2: the White test is a statistical test that establishes whether the variance of the errors in a regression model is constant: that is for homoskedasticity.This test
column3: and an estimator for heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors
column4: were proposed by Halbert White in 1980. These methods have become extremely widely used
column5: making this paper one of the most cited articles in economics.In cases where the White test statistic is statistically significant
column6: heteroskedasticity may not necessarily be the cause; instead the problem could be a specification error. In other words
column7: the White test can be a test of heteroskedasticity or specification error or both. If no cross product terms are introduced in the White test procedure
column8: then this is a pure test of pure heteroskedasticity. If cross products are introduced in the model
column9: then it is a test of both heteroskedasticity and specification bias.|

column2: model checking or property checking refers to the following problem: Given a model of a system
column3: exhaustively and automatically check whether this model meets a given specification. Typically
column4: one has hardware or software systems in mind
column5: whereas the specification contains safety requirements such as the absence of deadlocks and similar critical states that can cause the system to crash. Model checking is a technique for automatically verifying correctness properties of finite-state systems.In order to solve such a problem algorithmically
column6: both the model of the system and the specification are formulated in some precise mathematical language: To this end
column7: it is formulated as a task in logic
column8: namely to check whether a given structure satisfies a given logical formula. The concept is general and applies to all kinds of logics and suitable structures. A simple model-checking problem is verifying whether a given formula in the propositional logic is satisfied by a given structure.|

column2: automatic differentiation (AD)
column3: also called algorithmic differentiation or computational differentiation
column4: is a set of techniques to numerically evaluate the derivative of a function specified by a computer program. AD exploits the fact that every computer program
column5: no matter how complicated
column6: executes a sequence of elementary arithmetic operations (addition
column7: subtraction
column8: multiplication
column9: division
column10: etc.) and elementary functions (exp
column11: log
column12: sin
column13: cos
column14: etc.). By applying the chain rule repeatedly to these operations
column15: derivatives of arbitrary order can be computed automatically
column16: accurately to working precision
column17: and using at most a small constant factor more arithmetic operations than the original program.Automatic differentiation is not:Symbolic differentiation
column18: norNumerical differentiation (the method of finite differences).These classical methods run into problems: symbolic differentiation leads to inefficient code (unless carefully done) and faces the difficulty of converting a computer program into a single expression
column19: while numerical differentiation can introduce round-off errors in the discretization process and cancellation. Both classical methods have problems with calculating higher derivatives
column20: where the complexity and errors increase. Finally
column21: both classical methods are slow at computing the partial derivatives of a function with respect to many inputs
column22: as is needed for gradient-based optimization algorithms. Automatic differentiation solves all of these problems
column23: at the expense of introducing more software dependencies.|

column1: mean-absolute-deviation |The average absolute deviation (or mean absolute deviation) of a data set is the average of the absolute deviations from a central point. It is a summary statistic of statistical dispersion or variability. In this general form
column2: the central point can be the mean
column3: median
column4: mode
column5: or the result of another measure of central tendency. Furthermore
column6: as described in the article about averages
column7: the deviation averaging operation may refer to the mean or the median. Thus the total number of combinations amounts to at least four types of average absolute deviation.|

column2: the second derivative

column4: of a function f is the derivative of the derivative of f. Roughly speaking
column5: the second derivative measures how the rate of change of a quantity is itself changing; for example

column2: a production function relates physical output of a production process to physical inputs or factors of production. The production function is one of the key concepts of mainstream neoclassical theories
column3: used to define marginal product and to distinguish allocative efficiency
column4: the defining focus of economics.The primary purpose of the production function is to address allocative efficiency in the use of factor inputs in production and the resulting distribution of income to those factors
column5: while abstracting away from the technological problems of achieving technical efficiency
column6: as an engineer or professional manager might understand it. Production function denotes an efficient combination of inputs and outputs.In macroeconomics
column7: aggregate production functions are estimated to create a framework in which to distinguish how much of economic growth to attribute to changes in factor allocation (e.g. the accumulation of capital) and how much to attribute to advancing technology. Some non-mainstream economists
column8: however
column9: reject the very concept of an aggregate production function.|

column1: concept-drift |In predictive analytics and machine learning

column6: such as an input
column7: but
column8: in the context of concept drift
column9: the term commonly refers to the target variable.|

column1: efficacy |Efficacy is the ability to get a job done satisfactorily. The word comes from the same roots as

column1: hierarchical-softmax |Word2vec is a group of related models that are used to produce word embeddings. These models are shallow

column4: with each unique word in the corpus being assigned a corresponding vector in the space. Word vectors are positioned in the vector space such that words that share common contexts in the corpus are located in close proximity to one another in the space.Word2vec was created by a team of researchers led by Tomas Mikolov at Google. The algorithm has been subsequently analysed and explained by other researchers. Embedding vectors created using the Word2vec algorithm have many advantages compared to earlier algorithms like Latent Semantic Analysis.|

column2: canonical-correlation analysis (CCA) is a way of making sense of cross-covariance matrices. If we have two vectors X = (X1

column6: Ym) of random variables

column9: which is the general procedure for investigating the relationships between two sets of variables." The method was first introduced by Harold Hotelling in 1936.|

column1: |Bayesian probability| |Bayesian probability is an interpretation of the concept of probability
column2: in which
column3: instead of frequency or propensity of some phenomenon
column4: assigned probabilities represent states of knowledge or belief.The Bayesian interpretation of probability can be seen as an extension of propositional logic that enables reasoning with hypotheses
column5: i.e.
column6: the propositions whose truth or falsity is uncertain. In the Bayesian view
column7: a probability is assigned to a hypothesis
column8: whereas under frequentist inference
column9: a hypothesis is typically tested without being assigned a probability.Bayesian probability belongs to the category of evidential probabilities; to evaluate the probability of a hypothesis
column10: the Bayesian probabilist specifies some prior probability
column11: which is then updated to a posterior probability in the light of new
column12: relevant data (evidence). The Bayesian interpretation provides a standard set of procedures and formulae to perform this calculation.The term "Bayesian" derives from the 18th century mathematician and theologian Thomas Bayes
column13: who provided the first mathematical treatment of a non-trivial problem of Bayesian inference. Mathematician Pierre-Simon Laplace pioneered and popularised what is now called Bayesian probability.Broadly speaking
column14: there are two views on Bayesian probability that interpret the probability concept in different ways. According to the objectivist view
column15: the rules of Bayesian statistics can be justified by requirements of rationality and consistency and interpreted as an extension of logic. According to the subjectivist view
column16: probability quantifies a "personal belief".|

column2: the coefficient of multiple correlation is a measure of how well a given variable can be predicted using a linear function of a set of other variables. It is the correlation between the variable's values and the best predictions that can be computed linearly from the predictive variables.The coefficient of multiple correlation takes values between 0 and 1; a higher value indicates a better predictability of the dependent variable from the independent variables
column3: with a value of 1 indicating that the predictions are exactly correct and a value of 0 indicating that no linear combination of the independent variables is a better predictor than is the fixed mean of the dependent variable.The coefficient of multiple correlation is computed as the square root of the coefficient of determination
column4: but under the particular assumptions that an intercept is included and that the best possible linear predictors are used
column5: whereas the coefficient of determination is defined for more general cases
column6: including those of nonlinear prediction and those in which the predicted values have not been derived from a model-fitting procedure.|

column2: linear regression is an approach for modeling the relationship between a scalar dependent variable y and one or more explanatory variables (or independent variables) denoted X. The case of one explanatory variable is called simple linear regression. For more than one explanatory variable
column3: the process is called multiple linear regression. (This term should be distinguished from multivariate linear regression
column4: where multiple correlated dependent variables are predicted
column5: rather than a single scalar variable.)In linear regression
column6: the relationships are modeled using linear predictor functions whose unknown model parameters are estimated from the data. Such models are called linear models. Most commonly
column7: the conditional mean of y given the value of X is assumed to be an affine function of X; less commonly
column8: the median or some other quantile of the conditional distribution of y given X is expressed as a linear function of X. Like all forms of regression analysis
column9: linear regression focuses on the conditional probability distribution of y given X
column10: rather than on the joint probability distribution of y and X
column11: which is the domain of multivariate analysis.Linear regression was the first type of regression analysis to be studied rigorously
column12: and to be used extensively in practical applications. This is because models which depend linearly on their unknown parameters are easier to fit than models which are non-linearly related to their parameters and because the statistical properties of the resulting estimators are easier to determine.Linear regression has many practical uses. Most applications fall into one of the following two broad categories:If the goal is prediction
column13: or forecasting
column14: or error reduction
column15: linear regression can be used to fit a predictive model to an observed data set of y and X values. After developing such a model
column16: if an additional value of X is then given without its accompanying value of y
column17: the fitted model can be used to make a prediction of the value of y.Given a variable y and a number of variables X1
column19: Xp that may be related to y
column20: linear regression analysis can be applied to quantify the strength of the relationship between y and the Xj
column21: to assess which Xj may have no relationship with y at all
column22: and to identify which subsets of the Xj contain redundant information about y.Linear regression models are often fitted using the least squares approach
column23: but they may also be fitted in other ways
column24: such as by minimizing the "lack of fit" in some other norm (as with least absolute deviations regression)
column25: or by minimizing a penalized version of the least squares loss function as in ridge regression (L2-norm penalty) and lasso (L1-norm penalty). Conversely
column26: the least squares approach can be used to fit models that are not linear models. Thus
column27: although the terms "least squares" and "linear model" are closely linked

column2: the bias (or bias function) of an estimator is the difference between this estimator's expected value and the true value of the parameter being estimated. An estimator or decision rule with zero bias is called unbiased. Otherwise the estimator is said to be biased. In statistics
column3: "bias" is an objective statement about a function
column4: and while not a desired property
column5: it is not pejorative
column6: unlike the ordinary English use of the term "bias".Bias can also be measured with respect to the median
column7: rather than the mean (expected value)
column8: in which case one distinguishes median-unbiased from the usual mean-unbiasedness property. Bias is related to consistency in that consistent estimators are convergent and asymptotically unbiased (hence converge to the correct value)
column9: though individual estimators in a consistent sequence may be biased (so long as the bias converges to zero); see bias versus consistency.All else equal
column10: an unbiased estimator is preferable to a biased estimator
column11: but in practice all else is not equal
column12: and biased estimators are frequently used
column13: generally with small bias. When a biased estimator is used
column14: the bias is also estimated. A biased estimator may be used for various reasons: because an unbiased estimator does not exist without further assumptions about a population or is difficult to compute (as in unbiased estimation of standard deviation); because an estimator is median-unbiased but not mean-unbiased (or the reverse); because a biased estimator reduces some loss function (particularly mean squared error) compared with unbiased estimators (notably in shrinkage estimators); or because in some cases being unbiased is too strong a condition
column15: and the only unbiased estimators are not useful. Further
column16: mean-unbiasedness is not preserved under non-linear transformations
column17: though median-unbiasedness is (see effect of transformations); for example
column18: the sample variance is an unbiased estimator for the population variance
column19: but its square root
column20: the sample standard deviation
column21: is a biased estimator for the population standard deviation. These are all illustrated below.|

column2: sometimes called rotation estimation
column3: is a model validation technique for assessing how the results of a statistical analysis will generalize to an independent data set. It is mainly used in settings where the goal is prediction
column4: and one wants to estimate how accurately a predictive model will perform in practice. In a prediction problem
column5: a model is usually given a dataset of known data on which training is run (training dataset)
column6: and a dataset of unknown data (or first seen data) against which the model is tested (testing dataset). The goal of cross validation is to define a dataset to "test" the model in the training phase (i.e.
column7: the validation dataset)
column8: in order to limit problems like overfitting
column9: give an insight on how the model will generalize to an independent dataset (i.e.
column10: an unknown dataset
column11: for instance from a real problem)
column12: etc.One round of cross-validation involves partitioning a sample of data into complementary subsets
column13: performing the analysis on one subset (called the training set)
column14: and validating the analysis on the other subset (called the validation set or testing set). To reduce variability
column15: multiple rounds of cross-validation are performed using different partitions
column16: and the validation results are averaged over the rounds.One of the main reasons for using cross-validation instead of using the conventional validation (e.g. partitioning the data set into two sets of 70% for training and 30% for test) is that there is not enough data available to partition it into separate training and test sets without losing significant modelling or testing capability. In these cases
column17: a fair way to properly estimate model prediction performance is to use cross-validation as a powerful general technique.In summary
column18: cross-validation combines (averages) measures of fit (prediction error) to derive a more accurate estimate of model prediction performance.|

column2: or genetic data mining is an umbrella term for any data mining using evolutionary algorithms. While it can be used for mining data from DNA sequences
