column4: which helps "predict the value ... of a user-specified goal attribute based on the values of other attributes." For instance
column5: a banking institution might want to predict whether a customer's credit would be "good" or "bad" based on their age
column6: income and current savings. Evolutionary algorithms for data mining work by creating a series of random rules to be checked against a training dataset. The rules which most closely fit the data are selected and are mutated. The process is iterated many times and eventually
column7: a rule will arise that approaches 100% similarity with the training data. This rule is then checked against a test dataset
column8: which was previously invisible to the genetic algorithm.|

column2: the binomial distribution with parameters n and p is the discrete probability distribution of the number of successes in a sequence of n independent yes/no experiments
column3: each of which yields success with probability p. A success/failure experiment is also called a Bernoulli experiment or Bernoulli trial; when n = 1
column4: the binomial distribution is a Bernoulli distribution. The binomial distribution is the basis for the popular binomial test of statistical significance.The binomial distribution is frequently used to model the number of successes in a sample of size n drawn with replacement from a population of size N. If the sampling is carried out without replacement
column5: the draws are not independent and so the resulting distribution is a hypergeometric distribution
column6: not a binomial one. However
column7: for N much larger than n
column8: the binomial distribution remains a good approximation
column9: and widely used.|

column2: deviation is a measure of difference between the observed value of a variable and some other value
column3: often that variable's mean. The sign of the deviation (positive or negative)
column4: reports the direction of that difference (the deviation is positive when the observed value exceeds the reference value). The magnitude of the value indicates the size of the difference.|

column1: |Prediction market| |Prediction markets (also known as predictive markets
column2: information markets
column3: decision markets
column4: idea futures
column5: event derivatives
column6: or virtual markets) are exchange-traded markets created for the purpose of trading the outcome of events. The market prices can indicate what the crowd thinks the probability of the event is. A prediction market contract trades between 0 and 100%. It is a binary option that will expire at the price of 0 or 100%.Research has suggested that prediction markets are at least as accurate as other institutions predicting the same events with a similar pool of participants.|

column1: |Protein subcellular localization prediction| |Protein subcellular localization prediction (or just protein localization prediction) involves the computational prediction of where a protein resides in a cell.In general
column2: it is a computational method to take as input information about a protein
column3: such as a protein sequence
column4: and produce a prediction of a subcellular localization as output.Prediction of protein subcellular localization is an important component of bioinformatics based prediction of protein function and genome annotation
column5: and it can aid the identification of drug targets.|

column2: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods are a class of algorithms for sampling from a probability distribution based on constructing a Markov chain that has the desired distribution of its equilibrium distribution. The state of the chain after a number of steps is then used as a sample of the desired distribution. The quality of the sample improves as a function of the number of steps.Random walk Monte Carlo methods make up a large subclass of MCMC methods.|

column1: |Survey methodology| |A field of applied statistics of human research surveys
column2: survey methodology studies the sampling of individual units from a population and the associated survey data collection techniques
column3: such as questionnaire construction and methods for improving the number and accuracy of responses to surveys. Survey methodology includes instruments or procedures that ask one or more questions that may
column4: or may not
column5: be answered.Statistical surveys are undertaken with a view towards making statistical inferences about the population being studied
column6: and this depends strongly on the survey questions used. Polls about public opinion
column7: public health surveys
column8: market research surveys
column9: government surveys and censuses are all examples of quantitative research that use contemporary survey methodology to answer questions about a population. Although censuses do not include a "sample"
column10: they do include other aspects of survey methodology
column11: like questionnaires
column12: interviewers
column13: and nonresponse follow-up techniques. Surveys provide important information for all kinds of public information and research fields
column14: e.g.
column15: marketing research
column16: psychology
column17: health professionals and sociology.|

column1: Surveying |Surveying or land surveying is the technique
column2: profession
column3: and science of determining the terrestrial or three-dimensional position of points and the distances and angles between them. A land surveying professional is called a land surveyor. These points are usually on the surface of the Earth
column4: and they are often used to establish land maps and boundaries for ownership
column5: locations like building corners or the surface location of subsurface features
column6: or other purposes required by government or civil law
column7: such as property sales.Surveyors work with elements of geometry
column8: trigonometry
column9: regression analysis
column10: physics
column11: engineering
column12: metrology
column13: programming languages and the law. They use equipment like total stations
column14: robotic total stations
column15: GPS receivers
column16: retroreflectors
column17: 3D scanners
column18: radios
column19: handheld tablets
column20: digital levels
column21: drones
column22: GIS and surveying software.Surveying has been an element in the development of the human environment since the beginning of recorded history. The planning and execution of most forms of construction require it. It is also used in transport
column23: communications
column24: mapping
column25: and the definition of legal boundaries for land ownership. It is an important tool for research in many other scientific disciplines.|

column2: errors and residuals are two closely related and easily confused measures of the deviation of an observed value of an element of a statistical sample from its "theoretical value". The error (or disturbance) of an observed value is the deviation of the observed value from the (unobservable) true value of a quantity of interest (for example
column3: a population mean)
column4: and the residual of an observed value is the difference between the observed value and the estimated value of the quantity of interest (for example
column5: a sample mean). The distinction is most important in regression analysis
column6: where the concepts are sometimes called the regression errors and regression residuals and where they lead to the concept of studentized residuals.|

column2: a studentized residual is the quotient resulting from the division of a residual by an estimate of its standard deviation. Typically the standard deviations of residuals in a sample vary greatly from one data point to another even when the errors all have the same standard deviation
column3: particularly in regression analysis; thus it does not make sense to compare residuals at different data points without first studentizing. It is a form of a Student's t-statistic
column4: with the estimate of error varying between points.This is an important technique in the detection of outliers. It is among several named in honor of William Sealey Gosset
column5: who wrote under the pseudonym Student
column6: and dividing by an estimate of scale is called studentizing
column7: in analogy with standardizing and normalizing.|

column1: |List of stochastic processes topics| |In the mathematics of probability
column2: a stochastic process is a random function. In practical applications
column3: the domain over which the function is defined as a time interval (time series) or a region of space (random field).Familiar examples of time series include stock market and exchange rate fluctuations
column4: signals such as speech
column5: audio and video; medical data such as a patient's EKG
column6: EEG
column7: blood pressure or temperature; and random movement such as Brownian motion or random walks.Examples of random fields include static images
column8: random topographies (landscapes)
column9: or composition variations of an inhomogeneous material.|

column1: |SAS (software)| |SAS (Statistical Analysis System) is a software suite developed by SAS Institute for advanced analytics
column2: multivariate analyses
column3: business intelligence
column4: data management
column5: and predictive analytics.SAS was developed at North Carolina State University from 1966 until 1976
column6: when SAS Institute was incorporated. SAS was further developed in the 1980s and 1990s with the addition of new statistical procedures
column7: additional components and the introduction of JMP. A point-and-click interface was added in version 9 in 2004. A social media analytics product was added in 2010.|

column2: a data sample is a set of data collected and/or selected from a statistical population by a defined procedure. The elements of a sample are known as sample points
column3: sampling units or observations.Typically
column4: the population is very large
column5: making a census or a complete enumeration of all the values in the population is either impractical or impossible. The sample usually represents a subset of manageable size. Samples are collected and statistics are calculated from the samples so that one can make inferences or extrapolations from the sample to the population. The data sample may be drawn from a population without replacement
column6: in which case it is a subset of a population; or with replacement
column7: in which case it is a multisubset.|

column1: |Spatial analysis| |Spatial analysis or spatial statistics includes any of the formal techniques which study entities using their topological
column2: geometric
column3: or geographic properties. Spatial analysis includes a variety of techniques
column4: many still in their early development
column5: using different analytic approaches and applied in fields as diverse as astronomy
column6: with its studies of the placement of galaxies in the cosmos
column7: to chip fabrication engineering
column8: with its use of "place and route" algorithms to build complex wiring structures. In a more restricted sense
column9: spatial analysis is the technique applied to structures at the human scale
column10: most notably in the analysis of geographic data.Complex issues arise in spatial analysis
column11: many of which are neither clearly defined nor completely resolved
column12: but form the basis for current research. The most fundamental of these is the problem of defining the spatial location of the entities being studied.Classification of the techniques of spatial analysis is difficult because of the large number of different fields of research involved
column13: the different fundamental approaches which can be chosen
column14: and the many forms the data can take.|

column2: there exist several different notions of convergence of random variables. The convergence of sequences of random variables to some limit random variable is an important concept in probability theory
column3: and its applications to statistics and stochastic processes. The same concepts are known in more general mathematics as stochastic convergence and they formalize the idea that a sequence of essentially random or unpredictable events can sometimes be expected to settle down into a behaviour that is essentially unchanging when items far enough into the sequence are studied. The different possible notions of convergence relate to how such a behaviour can be characterised: two readily understood behaviours are that the sequence eventually takes a constant value
column4: and that values in the sequence continue to change but can be described by an unchanging probability distribution.|

column1: |Logit analysis in marketing| |Logit analysis is a statistical technique used by marketers to assess the scope of customer acceptance of a product
column2: particularly a new product. It attempts to determine the intensity or magnitude of customers' purchase intentions and translates that into a measure of actual buying behaviour. Logit analysis assumes that an unmet need in the marketplace has already been detected
column3: and that the product has been designed to meet that need. The purpose of logit analysis is to quantify the potential sales of that product. It takes survey data on consumers' purchase intentions and converts it into actual purchase probabilities.Logit analysis defines the functional relationship between stated purchase intentions and preferences
column4: and the actual probability of purchase. A preference regression is performed on the survey data. This is then modified with actual historical observations of purchase behavior. The resultant functional relationship defines purchase probability.This is the most useful of the purchase intention/rating translations because explicit measures of confidence level and statistical significance can be calculated. Other purchase intention/rating translations include the preference-rank translation and the intent scale translation. The logit function is the reciprocal function to the sigmoid logistic function.|

column2: the inverse gamma distribution is a two-parameter family of continuous probability distributions on the positive real line
column3: which is the distribution of the reciprocal of a variable distributed according to the gamma distribution. Perhaps the chief use of the inverse gamma distribution is in Bayesian statistics
column4: where the distribution arises as the marginal posterior distribution for the unknown variance of a normal distribution if an uninformative prior is used; and as an analytically tractable conjugate prior if an informative prior is required.However
column5: it is common among Bayesians to consider an alternative parametrization of the normal distribution in terms of the precision
column6: defined as the reciprocal of the variance
column7: which allows the gamma distribution to be used directly as a conjugate prior. Other Bayesians prefer to parametrize the inverse gamma distribution differently
column8: as a scaled inverse chi-squared distribution.|

column2: the normal-inverse-gamma distribution (or Gaussian-inverse-gamma distribution) is a four-parameter family of multivariate continuous probability distributions. It is the conjugate prior of a normal distribution with unknown mean and variance.|
in mathematics and statistics and particularly in the fields of machine learning and inverse problems
column3: refers to a process of introducing additional information in order to solve an ill-posed problem or to prevent overfitting.|

column1: |Reliability (statistics)| |Reliability in statistics and psychometrics is the overall consistency of a measure. A measure is said to have a high reliability if it produces similar results under consistent conditions. "It is the characteristic of a set of test scores that relates to the amount of random error from the measurement process that might be embedded in the scores. Scores that are highly reliable are accurate
column2: reproducible
column3: and consistent from one testing occasion to another. That is
column4: if the testing process were repeated with a group of test takers
column5: essentially the same results would be obtained. Various kinds of reliability coefficients
column6: with values ranging between 0.00 (much error) and 1.00 (no error)
column7: are usually used to indicate the amount of error in the scores."  For example
column8: measurements of people's height and weight are often extremely reliable.|

column2: the exponential distribution (a.k.a. negative exponential distribution) is the probability distribution that describes the time between events in a Poisson process
column3: i.e. a process in which events occur continuously and independently at a constant average rate. It is a particular case of the gamma distribution. It is the continuous analogue of the geometric distribution
column4: and it has the key property of being memoryless. In addition to being used for the analysis of Poisson processes
column5: it is found in various other contexts.The exponential distribution is not the same as the class of exponential families of distributions
column6: which is a large class of probability distributions that includes the exponential distribution as one of its members
column7: but also includes the normal distribution
column8: binomial distribution
column9: gamma distribution
column10: Poisson
column11: and many others.|

column2: to smooth a data set is to create an approximating function that attempts to capture important patterns in the data
column3: while leaving out noise or other fine-scale structures/rapid phenomena. In smoothing
column4: the data points of a signal are modified so individual points (presumably because of noise) are reduced
column5: and points that are lower than the adjacent points are increased leading to a smoother signal. Smoothing may be used in two important ways that can aid in data analysis (1) by being able to extract more information from the data as long as the assumption of smoothing is reasonable and (2) by being able to provide analyses that are both flexible and robust. Many different algorithms are used in smoothing.Smoothing may be distinguished from the related and partially overlapping concept of curve fitting in the following ways:curve fitting often involves the use of an explicit function form for the result
column6: whereas the immediate results from smoothing are the "smoothed" values with no later use made of a functional form if there is one;the aim of smoothing is to give a general idea of relatively slow changes of value with little attention paid to the close matching of data values
column7: while curve fitting concentrates on achieving as close a match as possible.smoothing methods often have an associated tuning parameter which is used to control the extent of smoothing. Curve fitting will adjust any number of parameters of the function to obtain the 'best' fit.However
column8: the terminology used across applications is mixed. For example
column9: use of an interpolating spline fits a smooth curve exactly through the given data points and is sometimes called "smoothing".|

column2: quality assurance
column3: and survey methodology
column4: sampling is concerned with the selection of a subset of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population. Each observation measures one or more properties (such as weight
column5: location
column6: color) of observable bodies distinguished as independent objects or individuals. In survey sampling
column7: weights can be applied to the data to adjust for the sample design
column8: particularly stratified sampling. Results from probability theory and statistical theory are employed to guide the practice. In business and medical research
column9: sampling is widely used for gathering information about a population.The sampling process comprises several stages:Defining the population of concernSpecifying a sampling frame
column10: a set of items or events possible to measureSpecifying a sampling method for selecting items or events from the frameDetermining the sample sizeImplementing the sampling planSampling and data collectingData which can be selected|

column1: |Software verification and validation| |In software project management
column2: software testing
column3: and software engineering
column4: verification and validation (V&V) is the process of checking that a software system meets specifications and that it fulfills its intended purpose. It may also be referred to as software quality control. It is normally the responsibility of software testers as part of the software development lifecycle. In simple terms
column5: software verification is: "Assuming we should build X
column6: does our software actually achieve its goals without any bugs or gaps?" On the other hand
column7: software validation is: "Was X actually what we should have built? Does X actually meet the high level requirements?"|

column2: robust regression is a form of regression analysis designed to circumvent some limitations of traditional parametric and non-parametric methods. Regression analysis seeks to find the relationship between one or more independent variables and a dependent variable. Certain widely used methods of regression
column3: such as ordinary least squares
column4: have favourable properties if their underlying assumptions are true
column5: but can give misleading results if those assumptions are not true; thus ordinary least squares is said to be not robust to violations of its assumptions. Robust regression methods are designed to be not overly affected by violations of assumptions by the underlying data-generating process.In particular
column6: least squares estimates for regression models are highly sensitive to (not robust against) outliers. While there is no precise definition of an outlier
column7: outliers are observations which do not follow the pattern of the other observations. This is not normally a problem if the outlier is simply an extreme observation drawn from the tail of a normal distribution
column8: but if the outlier results from non-normal measurement error or some other violation of standard ordinary least squares assumptions
column9: then it compromises the validity of the regression results if a non-robust regression technique is used.|

column1: |Robust statistics| |Robust statistics are statistics with good performance for data drawn from a wide range of probability distributions
column2: especially for distributions that are not normal. Robust statistical methods have been developed for many common problems
column3: such as estimating location
column4: scale and regression parameters. One motivation is to produce statistical methods that are not unduly affected by outliers. Another motivation is to provide methods with good performance when there are small departures from parametric distributions. For example
column5: robust methods work well for mixtures of two normal distributions with different standard-deviations; under this model
column6: non-robust methods like a t-test work badly.|

column2: a data structure is a particular way of organizing data in a computer so that it can be used efficiently. Data structures can implement one or more particular abstract data types (ADT)
column3: which specify the operations that can be performed on a data structure and the computational complexity of those operations. In comparison
column4: a data structure is a concrete implementation of the specification provided by an ADT.Different kinds of data structures are suited to different kinds of applications
column5: and some are highly specialized to specific tasks. For example
column6: relational databases commonly use B-tree indexes for data retrieval
column7: while compiler implementations usually use hash tables to look up identifiers.Data structures provide a means to manage large amounts of data efficiently for uses such as large databases and internet indexing services. Usually
column8: efficient data structures are key to designing efficient algorithms. Some formal design methods and programming languages emphasize data structures
column9: rather than algorithms
column10: as the key organizing factor in software design. Data structures can be used to organize the storage and retrieval of information stored in both main memory and secondary memory.|

column1: |Bayes estimator| |In estimation theory and decision theory
column2: a Bayes estimator or a Bayes action is an estimator or decision rule that minimizes the posterior expected value of a loss function (i.e.
column3: the posterior expected loss). Equivalently
column4: it maximizes the posterior expectation of a utility function. An alternative way of formulating an estimator within Bayesian statistics is maximum a posteriori estimation.|

column1: |Comparison of deep learning software/Resources| |This page lists resources that can be useful to the Comparison of deep learning software page.|

column2: the ordered subset expectation maximization (OSEM) method is an iterative method that is used in computed tomography.In applications in medical imaging
column3: the OSEM method is used for positron emission tomography
column4: for single photon emission computed tomography
column5: and for X-ray computed tomography.The OSEM method is related to the expectation maximization (EM) method of statistics. The OSEM method is also related to methods of filtered back projection.|

column2: cumulative distribution function (CDF)-based nonparametric confidence intervals are a general class of confidence intervals around statistical functionals of a distribution. To calculate these confidence intervals
column3: all that is required is an independently and identically distributed (iid) sample from the distribution and known bounds on the support of the distribution. The latter requirement simply means that all the nonzero probability mass of the distribution must be contained in some known interval                     [        a
column4: b        ]              {\displaystyle [a

column1: |Illustration of the central limit theorem| |This article gives two concrete illustrations of the central limit theorem. Both involve the sum of independent and identically-distributed random variables and show how the probability distribution of the sum approaches the normal distribution as the number of terms in the sum increases.The first illustration involves a continuous probability distribution
column2: for which the random variables have a probability density function.The second illustration
column3: for which most of the computation can be done by hand
column4: involves a discrete probability distribution
column5: which is characterized by a probability mass function.A free full-featured interactive simulation that allows the user to set up various distributions and adjust the sampling parameters is available through the External links section at the bottom of this page.|

column2: Mood's median test is a special case of Pearson's chi-squared test. It is a nonparametric test that tests the null hypothesis that the medians of the populations from which two or more samples are drawn are identical. The data in each sample are assigned to two groups
column3: one consisting of data whose values are higher than the median value in the two groups combined
column4: and the other consisting of data whose values are at the median or below. A Pearson's chi-squared test is then used to determine whether the observed frequencies in each sample differ from expected frequencies derived from a distribution combining the two groups.|

column1: |Gradient boosting| |Gradient boosting is a machine learning technique for regression and classification problems
column2: which produces a prediction model in the form of an ensemble of weak prediction models
column3: typically decision trees. It builds the model in a stage-wise fashion like other boosting methods do
column4: and it generalizes them by allowing optimization of an arbitrary differentiable loss function.The idea of gradient boosting originated in the observation by Leo Breiman that boosting can be interpreted as an optimization algorithm on a suitable cost function. Explicit regression gradient boosting algorithms were subsequently developed by Jerome H. Friedman simultaneously with the more general functional gradient boosting perspective of Llew Mason
column5: Jonathan Baxter
column6: Peter Bartlett and Marcus Frean. The latter two papers introduced the abstract view of boosting algorithms as iterative functional gradient descent algorithms. That is
column7: algorithms that optimize a cost function over function space by iteratively choosing a function (weak hypothesis) that points in the negative gradient direction. This functional gradient view of boosting has led to the development of boosting algorithms in many areas of machine learning and statistics beyond regression and classification.|

column1: |Likelihood ratios in diagnostic testing| |In evidence-based medicine
column2: likelihood ratios are used for assessing the value of performing a diagnostic test. They use the sensitivity and specificity of the test to determine whether a test result usefully changes the probability that a condition (such as a disease state) exists. The first description of the use of likelihood ratios for decision rules was made at a symposium on information theory in 1954. In medicine
column3: likelihood ratios were introduced between 1975 and 1980.|

column2: a branch predictor is a digital circuit that tries to guess which way a branch (e.g. an if-then-else structure) will go before this is known for sure. The purpose of the branch predictor is to improve the flow in the instruction pipeline. Branch predictors play a critical role in achieving high effective performance in many modern pipelined microprocessor architectures such as x86.Two-way branching is usually implemented with a conditional jump instruction. A conditional jump can either be "not taken" and continue execution with the first branch of code which follows immediately after the conditional jump
column3: or it can be "taken" and jump to a different place in program memory where the second branch of code is stored. It is not known for certain whether a conditional jump will be taken or not taken until the condition has been calculated and the conditional jump has passed the execution stage in the instruction pipeline (see fig. 1).Without branch prediction
column4: the processor would have to wait until the conditional jump instruction has passed the execute stage before the next instruction can enter the fetch stage in the pipeline. The branch predictor attempts to avoid this waste of time by trying to guess whether the conditional jump is most likely to be taken or not taken. The branch that is guessed to be the most likely is then fetched and speculatively executed. If it is later detected that the guess was wrong then the speculatively executed or partially executed instructions are discarded and the pipeline starts over with the correct branch
column5: incurring a delay.The time that is wasted in case of a branch misprediction is equal to the number of stages in the pipeline from the fetch stage to the execute stage. Modern microprocessors tend to have quite long pipelines so that the misprediction delay is between 10 and 20 clock cycles. As a result
column6: making a pipeline longer increases the need for a more advanced branch predictor.The first time a conditional jump instruction is encountered
column7: there is not much information to base a prediction on. But the branch predictor keeps records of whether branches are taken or not taken. When it encounters a conditional jump that has been seen several times before then it can base the prediction on the history. The branch predictor may
column8: for example
column9: recognize that the conditional jump is taken more often than not
column10: or that it is taken every second time.Branch prediction is not the same as branch target prediction. Branch prediction attempts to guess whether a conditional jump will be taken or not. Branch target prediction attempts to guess the target of a taken conditional or unconditional jump before it is computed by decoding and executing the instruction itself. Branch prediction and branch target prediction are often combined into the same circuitry.|

column1: Predictor@home |Predictor@home was a distributed computing project that used BOINC. It was established by The Scripps Research Institute to predict protein structure from protein sequence in the context of the 6th biannual CASP
column2: or Critical Assessment of Techniques for Protein Structure Prediction. A major goal of the project was the testing and evaluating of new algorithms to predict both known and unknown protein structures. The project was most recently run by the University of Michigan.Predictor@home was complementary to Folding@home. Whereas the latter aims to study the dynamics of protein folding
column3: Predictor@home aimed to specify what the final tertiary structure will be. Also
column4: the two projects differ significantly in the infrastructure they use. Predictor@home used BOINC
column5: whereas Folding@home maintains its own software completely outside of BOINC.However
column6: for a time
column7: Predictor@home competed with other BOINC protein structure prediction projects
column8: such as Rosetta@home. Each uses different methods of rapidly and reliably predicting the final tertiary structure.Predictor@home is currently inactive.|

column2: a probit model is a type of regression where the dependent variable can only take two values
column3: for example married or not married. The word is a portmanteau
column4: coming from probability + unit. The purpose of the model is to estimate the probability that an observation with particular characteristics will fall into a specific one of the categories; moreover
column5: if estimated probabilities greater than 1/2 are treated as classifying an observation into a predicted category
column6: the probit model is a type of binary classification model.A probit model is a popular specification for an ordinal or a binary response model. As such it treats the same set of problems as does logistic regression using similar techniques. The probit model
column7: which employs a probit link function
column8: is most often estimated using the standard maximum likelihood procedure
column9: such an estimation being called a probit regression.Probit models were introduced by Chester Bliss in 1934; a fast method for computing maximum likelihood estimates for them was proposed by Ronald Fisher as an appendix to Bliss' work in 1935.|

column2: in particular
column3: in the fitting of linear or logistic regression models
column4: the elastic net is a regularized regression method that linearly combines the L1 and L2 penalties of the lasso and ridge methods.|

column2: the matrix t-distribution (or matrix variate t-distribution) is the generalization of the multivariate t-distribution from vectors to matrices. The matrix t-distribution shares the same relationship with the multivariate t-distribution that the matrix normal distribution shares with the multivariate normal distribution. For example
column3: the matrix t-distribution is the compound distribution that results from sampling from a matrix normal distribution having sampled the covariance matrix of the matrix normal from an inverse Wishart distribution.In a Bayesian analysis of a multivariate linear regression model based on the matrix normal distribution
column4: the matrix t-distribution is the posterior predictive distribution.|

column2: a Bernoulli process is a finite or infinite sequence of binary random variables
column3: so it is a discrete-time stochastic process that takes only two values
column4: canonically 0 and 1. The component Bernoulli variables Xi are identical and independent. Prosaically
column5: a Bernoulli process is a repeated coin flipping
column6: possibly with an unfair coin (but with consistent unfairness). Every variable Xi in the sequence is associated with a Bernoulli trial or experiment. They all have the same Bernoulli distribution. Much of what can be said about the Bernoulli process can also be generalized to more than two outcomes (such as the process for a six-sided die); this generalization is known as the Bernoulli scheme.The problem of determining the process
column7: given only a limited sample of the Bernoulli trials
column8: may be called the problem of checking whether a coin is fair.|

column2: the Huber loss is a loss function used in robust regression
column3: that is less sensitive to outliers in data than the squared error loss. A variant for classification is also sometimes used.|

column2: such as that described in exact test
column3: is a branch of statistics that was developed to provide more accurate results pertaining to statistical testing and interval estimation by eliminating procedures based on asymptotic and approximate statistical methods. The main characteristic of exact methods is that statistical tests and confidence intervals are based on exact probability statements that are valid for any sample size. Exact statistical methods help avoid some of the unreasonable assumptions of traditional statistical methods
column4: such as the assumption of equal variances in classical ANOVA. They also allow exact inference on variance components of mixed models.When exact p-values and confidence intervals are computed under a certain distribution
column5: such as the normal distribution
column6: then the underlying methods are referred to as exact parametric methods. The exact methods that do not make any distributional assumptions are referred to as exact nonparametric methods. The latter has the advantage of making fewer assumptions whereas
column7: the former tend to yield more powerful tests when the distributional assumption is reasonable. For advanced methods such as higher-way ANOVA regression analysis
column8: and mixed models
column9: only exact parametric methods are available.When the sample size is small
column10: asymptotic results given by some traditional methods may not be valid. In such situations
column11: the asymptotic p-values may differ substantially from the exact p-values. Hence asymptotic and other approximate results may lead to unreliable and misleading conclusions.|

column2: engineering
column3: economics
column4: and medical research
column5: censoring is a condition in which the value of a measurement or observation is only partially known.For example
column6: suppose a study is conducted to measure the impact of a drug on mortality rate. In such a study
column7: it may be known that an individual's age at death is at least 75 years (but may be more). Such a situation could occur if the individual withdrew from the study at age 75
column8: or if the individual is currently alive at the age of 75.Censoring also occurs when a value occurs outside the range of a measuring instrument. For example
column9: a bathroom scale might only measure up to 300 pounds (140 kg). If a 350 lb (160 kg) individual is weighed using the scale
column10: the observer would only know that the individual's weight is at least 300 pounds (140 kg).The problem of censored data
column11: in which the observed value of some variable is partially known
column12: is related to the problem of missing data
column13: where the observed value of some variable is unknown.Censoring should not be confused with the related idea truncation. With censoring
column14: observations result either in knowing the exact value that applies
column15: or in knowing that the value lies within an interval. With truncation
column16: observations never result in values outside a given range: values in the population outside the range are never seen or never recorded if they are seen. Note that in statistics
column17: truncation is not the same as rounding.|

column2: resampling is any of a variety of methods for doing one of the following:Estimating the precision of sample statistics (medians
column3: variances
column4: percentiles) by using subsets of available data (jackknifing) or drawing randomly with replacement from a set of data points (bootstrapping)Exchanging labels on data points when performing significance tests (permutation tests
column5: also called exact tests
column6: randomization tests
column7: or re-randomization tests)Validating models by using random subsets (bootstrapping
column8: cross validation)Common resampling techniques include bootstrapping
column9: jackknifing and permutation tests.|

column1: |Software license| |A software license is a legal instrument (usually by way of contract law
column2: with or without printed material) governing the use or redistribution of software. Under United States copyright law all software is copyright protected
column3: in source code as also object code form. The only exception is software in the public domain. A typical software license grants the licensee
column4: typically an end-user
column5: permission to use one or more copies of software in ways where such a use would otherwise potentially constitute copyright infringement of the software owner's exclusive rights under copyright law.|

column1: |Software categories| |The concept of software categories is a challenging topic
column2: and with the continuous development of new software it is becoming increasingly difficult to categorize new software. There is no universally agreed upon set of categories
column3: and different classification schemes consider different aspects.|

column2: a copula is a multivariate probability distribution for which the marginal probability distribution of each variable is uniform. Copulas are used to describe the dependence between random variables. Their name comes from the Latin for "link" or "tie"
column3: similar but unrelated to grammatical copulas in linguistics. Copulas have been used widely in quantitative finance to model and minimize tail risk and portfolio optimization applications.Sklar's Theorem states that any multivariate joint distribution can be written in terms of univariate marginal distribution functions and a copula which describes the dependence structure between the variables.Copulas are popular in high-dimensional statistical applications as they allow one to easily model and estimate the distribution of random vectors by estimating marginals and copulae separately. There are many parametric copula families available
column4: which usually have parameters that control the strength of dependence. Some popular parametric copula models are outlined below.|

column2: especially as introduced into statistical mechanics and thermodynamics by J. Willard Gibbs in 1902
column3: an ensemble (also statistical ensemble) is an idealization consisting of a large number of virtual copies (sometimes infinitely many) of a system
column4: considered all at once
column5: each of which represents a possible state that the real system might be in. In other words
column6: a statistical ensemble is a probability distribution for the state of the system.A thermodynamic ensemble is a specific variety of statistical ensemble that
column7: among other properties
column8: is in statistical equilibrium (defined below)
column9: and is used to derive the properties of thermodynamic systems from the laws of classical or quantum mechanics.|

column1: |Parametric statistics| |Parametric statistics is a branch of statistics which assumes that sample data comes from a population that follows a probability distribution based on a fixed set of parameters. Most well-known elementary statistical methods are parametric. Conversely a non-parametric model differs precisely in that the parameter set (or feature set in machine learning) is not fixed and can increase
column2: or even decrease if new relevant information is collected.A parametric model as it relies on a fixed parameter set assumes more about a given population than non-parametric methods. When the assumptions are correct
column3: parametric methods will produce more accurate and precise estimates than non-parametric methods
column4: i.e. have more statistical power. As more is assumed when the assumptions are not correct they have a greater chance of failing
column5: and for this reason are not a robust statistical method. On the other hand
column6: Non-parametric formulae are often simpler to write down and faster to compute. For this reason their simplicity can make up for their lack of robustness
column7: especially if care is taken to examine diagnostic statistics.|

column2: the Bonferroni correction is one of several methods used to counteract the problem of multiple comparisons.|

column1: |Metropolis\u2013Hastings algorithm| |Bayesian inference of phylogeny uses a likelihood function to create a quantity called the posterior probability of trees using a model of evolution
column2: based on some prior probabilities
column3: producing the most likely phylogenetic tree for the given data. The Bayesian approach has become popular due to advances in computing speeds and the integration of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms. Bayesian inference has a number of applications in molecular phylogenetics and systematics. |

column2: Bayes network
column3: belief network
column4: Bayes(ian) model or probabilistic directed acyclic graphical model is a probabilistic graphical model (a type of statistical model) that represents a set of random variables and their conditional dependencies via a directed acyclic graph (DAG). For example
column5: a Bayesian network could represent the probabilistic relationships between diseases and symptoms. Given symptoms
column6: the network can be used to compute the probabilities of the presence of various diseases.Formally
column7: Bayesian networks are DAGs whose nodes represent random variables in the Bayesian sense: they may be observable quantities
column8: latent variables
column9: unknown parameters or hypotheses. Edges represent conditional dependencies; nodes that are not connected (there is no path from one of the variables to the other in the Bayesian network) represent variables that are conditionally independent of each other. Each node is associated with a probability function that takes
column10: as input
column11: a particular set of values for the node's parent variables
column12: and gives (as output) the probability (or probability distribution
column13: if applicable) of the variable represented by the node. For example
column14: if                     m              {\displaystyle m}   parent nodes represent                     m              {\displaystyle m}   Boolean variables then the probability function could be represented by a table of                               2                      m                                {\displaystyle 2^{m}}   entries
column15: one entry for each of the                               2                      m                                {\displaystyle 2^{m}}   possible combinations of its parents being true or false. Similar ideas may be applied to undirected
column16: and possibly cyclic
column17: graphs; such are called Markov networks.Efficient algorithms exist that perform inference and learning in Bayesian networks. Bayesian networks that model sequences of variables (e.g. speech signals or protein sequences) are called dynamic Bayesian networks. Generalizations of Bayesian networks that can represent and solve decision problems under uncertainty are called influence diagrams.|

column2: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods are a class of algorithms for sampling from a probability distribution based on constructing a Markov chain that has the desired distribution of its equilibrium distribution. The state of the chain after a number of steps is then used as a sample of the desired distribution. The quality of the sample improves as a function of the number of steps.Random walk Monte Carlo methods make up a large subclass of MCMC methods.|

column1: |Discrete Weibull distribution| |In probability theory and statistics
column2: the discrete Weibull distribution is the discrete variant of the Weibull distribution. It was first described by Nakagawa and Osaki in 1975.|

column1: |Leland Wilkinson| |Leland Wilkinson (born c. 1945) is a statistician and computer scientist at H2O.ai
column2: the makers of H2O (software)
column3: and Adjunct Professor of Computer Science at University of Illinois at Chicago. Wilkinson developed the SYSTAT statistical package in the early 1980s
column4: sold it to SPSS in 1995
column5: and worked at SPSS for 10 years recruiting and managing the visualization team. He left SPSS in 2008 and became Executive VP of SYSTAT Software Inc. in Chicago. He then served as the VP of Data Visualization at Skytree
column6: Inc and VP of Statistics at Tableau Software before joining H2O.ai. His research focuses on scientific visualization and statistical graphics. In these communities he is well known for his book The Grammar of Graphics
column7: which was the foundation for the R package ggplot2.|

column1: |Aggregation problem| |An aggregate in economics is a summary measure describing a market or economy. The aggregation problem refers to the difficulty of treating an empirical or theoretical aggregate as if it reacted like a less-aggregated measure
column2: say
column3: about behavior of an individual agent as described in general microeconomic theory. Examples of aggregates in micro- and macroeconomics relative to less aggregated counterparts are:Food vs. applesPrice level and real GDP vs. the price and quantity of applesCapital stock vs. the value of computers of a certain type and the value of steam shovelsMoney supply vs. paper currencyGeneral unemployment rate vs. the unemployment rate of civil engineersStandard theory uses simple assumptions to derive general
column4: and commonly accepted
column5: results such as the law of demand to explain market behavior. An example is the abstraction of a composite good. It considers the price of one good changing proportionately to the composite good
column6: that is
column7: all other goods. If this assumption is violated and the agents are subject to aggregated utility functions
column8: restrictions on the latter are necessary to yield the law of demand. The aggregation problem emphasizes:How broad such restrictions are in microeconomicsUse of broad factor inputs ("labor" and "capital")
column9: real "output"
column10: and "investment"
column11: as if there was only a single such aggregate is without a solid foundation for rigorously deriving analytical results.Franklin Fisher notes that this has not dissuaded macroeconomists from continuing to use such concepts.|

column1: |Statistical learning theory| |Statistical learning theory is a framework for machine learning drawing from the fields of statistics and functional analysis. Statistical learning theory deals with the problem of finding a predictive function based on data. Statistical learning theory has led to successful applications in fields such as computer vision
column2: speech recognition
column3: bioinformatics and baseball.|

column2: classification is the problem of identifying to which of a set of categories (sub-populations) a new observation belongs
column3: on the basis of a training set of data containing observations (or instances) whose category membership is known. An example would be assigning a given email into "spam" or "non-spam" classes or assigning a diagnosis to a given patient as described by observed characteristics of the patient (gender
column4: blood pressure
column5: presence or absence of certain symptoms
column6: etc.). Classification is an example of pattern recognition.In the terminology of machine learning
column7: classification is considered an instance of supervised learning
column8: i.e. learning where a training set of correctly identified observations is available. The corresponding unsupervised procedure is known as clustering
column9: and involves grouping data into categories based on some measure of inherent similarity or distance.Often
column10: the individual observations are analyzed into a set of quantifiable properties
column11: known variously as explanatory variables or features. These properties may variously be categorical (e.g. "A"
column13: "AB" or "O"
column14: for blood type)
column15: ordinal (e.g. "large"
column16: "medium" or "small")
column17: integer-valued (e.g. the number of occurrences of a particular word in an email) or real-valued (e.g. a measurement of blood pressure). Other classifiers work by comparing observations to previous observations by means of a similarity or distance function.An algorithm that implements classification
column18: especially in a concrete implementation
column19: is known as a classifier. The term "classifier" sometimes also refers to the mathematical function
column20: implemented by a classification algorithm
column21: that maps input data to a category.Terminology across fields is quite varied. In statistics
column22: where classification is often done with logistic regression or a similar procedure
column23: the properties of observations are termed explanatory variables (or independent variables
column24: regressors
column25: etc.)
column26: and the categories to be predicted are known as outcomes
column27: which are considered to be possible values of the dependent variable. In machine learning
column28: the observations are often known as instances
column29: the explanatory variables are termed features (grouped into a feature vector)
column30: and the possible categories to be predicted are classes. Other fields may use different terminology: e.g. in community ecology
column31: the term "classification" normally refers to cluster analysis
column32: i.e. a type of unsupervised learning
column33: rather than the supervised learning described in this article.|

column2: bivariate data is data that has two variables. The quantities from these two variables are often represented using a scatter plot. This is done so that the relationship (if any) between the variables is easily seen. For example
column3: bivariate data on a scatter plot could be used to study the relationship between stride length and length of legs.|

column1: |Bioinformatics (journal)| |Bioinformatics is a biweekly peer-reviewed scientific journal covering research and software in computational biology. It is the official journal of the International Society for Computational Biology (ISCB)
column2: together with PLOS Computational Biology. Authors can pay extra for open access and are allowed to self-archive after 1 year.The journal was established as Computer Applications in the Biosciences (CABIOS) in 1985. The founding editor-in-chief was Robert J. Beynon. In 1998
column3: the journal obtained its current name and established an online version of the journal. It is published by Oxford University Press and
column4: as of 2014
column5: the editors-in-chief are Alfonso Valencia and Janet Kelso. Previous editors include Chris Sander
column6: Gary Stormo
column7: Christos Ouzounis
column8: Martin Bishop
column9: and Alex Bateman. In 2014
column10: these five editors were appointed the first Honorary Editors of Bioinformatics. According to the Journal Citation Reports
column11: the journal has a 2015 impact factor of 4.98.From 1998 to 2004
column12: Bioinformatics was the official journal of the ISCB. In 2004
column13: as many ISCB members had institutional subscriptions to Bioinformatics
column14: ISCB decided not to renew its contract with the journal. As of 2005
column15: PLOS Computational Biology became the official ISCB journal. In January 2009 Bioinformatics again became an official journal of the ISCB
column16: alongside PLOS Computational Biology.The proceedings of the Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology conference and the European Conference on Computational Biology have been published in special issues of Bioinformatics since 2001 and 2002
column17: respectively.Following budget problems
column18: Greek universities dropped their subscriptions to Bioinformatics in 2013.|

column1: |Cognitive model| |A cognitive model is an approximation to animal cognitive processes (predominantly human) for the purposes of comprehension and prediction. Cognitive models can be developed within or without a cognitive architecture
column2: though the two are not always easily distinguishable.In contrast to cognitive architectures
column3: cognitive models tend to be focused on a single cognitive phenomenon or process (e.g.
column4: list learning)
column5: how two or more processes interact (e.g.
column6: visual search and decision making)
column7: or to make behavioral predictions for a specific task or tool (e.g.
column8: how instituting a new software package will affect productivity). Cognitive architectures tend to be focused on the structural properties of the modeled system
column9: and help constrain the development of cognitive models within the architecture. Likewise
column10: model development helps to inform limitations and shortcomings of the architecture. Some of the most popular architectures for cognitive modeling include ACT-R and Soar.|

column2: a confidence interval (CI) is a type of interval estimate of a population parameter. It is an observed interval (i.e.
column3: it is calculated from the observations)
column4: in principle different from sample to sample
column5: that frequently includes the value of an unobservable parameter of interest if the experiment is repeated. How frequently the observed interval contains the parameter is determined by the confidence level or confidence coefficient. More specifically
column6: the meaning of the term "confidence level" is that
column7: if CI are constructed across many separate data analyses of replicated experiments
column8: the proportion of such intervals that contain the true value of the parameter will match the given confidence level. Whereas two-sided confidence limits form a confidence interval
column9: their one-sided counterparts are referred to as lower/upper confidence bounds (or limits).Confidence intervals consist of a range of values (interval) that act as good estimates of the unknown population parameter. However
column10: the interval computed from a particular sample does not necessarily include the true value of the parameter. When we say
column11: "we are 99% confident that the true value of the parameter is in our confidence interval"
column12: we express that 99% of the hypothetically observed confidence intervals will hold the true value of the parameter. After any particular sample is taken
column13: the population parameter is either in the interval
column14: realized or not; it is not a matter of chance. The desired level of confidence is set by the researcher (not determined by data). If a corresponding hypothesis test is performed
column15: the confidence level is the complement of the level of significance
column16: i.e. a 95% confidence interval reflects a significance level of 0.05. The confidence interval contains the parameter values that
column17: when tested
column18: should not be rejected with the same sample. Confidence intervals of difference parameters not containing 0 imply that there is a statistically significant difference between the populations.In applied practice
column19: confidence intervals are typically stated at the 95% confidence level. However
column20: when presented graphically
column21: confidence intervals can be shown at several confidence levels
column22: for example 90%
column23: 95% and 99%.Certain factors may affect the confidence interval size including size of sample
column24: level of confidence
column25: and population variability. A larger sample size normally will lead to a better estimate of the population parameter.Confidence intervals were introduced to statistics by Jerzy Neyman in a paper published in 1937.|

column1: |Outline of probability| |The following outline is provided as an overview and guide to probability:Probability is a measure of the likeliness that an event will occur. Probability is used to quantify an attitude of mind towards some proposition of whose truth we are not certain. The proposition of interest is usually of the form "A specific event will occur." The attitude of mind is of the form "How certain are we that the event will occur?" The certainty we adopt can be described in terms of a numerical measure and this number
column2: between 0 and 1 (where 0 indicates impossibility and 1 indicates certainty)
column3: we call probability. Probability theory is used extensively in statistics
column4: mathematics
column5: science and philosophy to draw conclusions about the likelihood of potential events and the underlying mechanics of complex systems.|

column2: a natural exponential family (NEF) is a class of probability distributions that is a special case of an exponential family (EF). Every distribution possessing a moment-generating function is a member of a natural exponential family
column3: and the use of such distributions simplifies the theory and computation of generalized linear models.|

column2: an endogeneity problem occurs when an explanatory variable is correlated with the error term. Endogeneity can arise as a result of measurement error
column3: autoregression with autocorrelated errors
column4: simultaneous causality (see Instrumental variable) and omitted variables. Two common causes of endogeneity are: 1) an uncontrolled confounder causing both independent and dependent variables of a model; and 2) a loop of causality between the independent and dependent variables of a model.For example
column5: in a simple supply and demand model
column6: when predicting the quantity demanded in equilibrium
column7: the price is endogenous because producers change their price in response to demand and consumers change their demand in response to price. In this case
column8: the price variable is said to have total endogeneity once the demand and supply curves are known. In contrast
column9: a change in consumer tastes or preferences would be an exogenous change on the demand curve.|

column2: the restricted (or residual
column3: or reduced) maximum likelihood (REML) approach is a particular form of maximum likelihood estimation which does not base estimates on a maximum likelihood fit of all the information
column4: but instead uses a likelihood function calculated from a transformed set of data
column5: so that nuisance parameters have no effect.In the case of variance component estimation
column6: the original data set is replaced by a set of contrasts calculated from the data
column7: and the likelihood function is calculated from the probability distribution of these contrasts
column8: according to the model for the complete data set. In particular
column9: REML is used as a method for fitting linear mixed models. In contrast to the earlier maximum likelihood estimation
column10: REML can produce unbiased estimates of variance and covariance parameters.The idea underlying REML estimation was put forward by M. S. Bartlett in 1937. The first description of the approach applied to estimating components of variance in unbalanced data was by Desmond Patterson and Robin Thompson of the University of Edinburgh in 1971
column11: although they did not use the term REML. A review of the early literature was given by Harville.REML estimation is available in a number of general-purpose statistical software packages
column12: including Genstat (the REML directive)
column13: SAS (the MIXED procedure)
column14: SPSS (the MIXED command)
column15: Stata (the mixed command)
column16: JMP (statistical software)
column17: and R (especially the lme4 and older nlme packages)
column18: as well as in more specialist packages such as MLwiN
column19: HLM
column20: ASReml
column21: (ai)remlf90
column22: wombat
column23: Statistical Parametric Mapping and CropStat.REML estimation is implemented in Surfstat a Matlab toolbox for the statistical analysis of univariate and multivariate surface and volumetric neuroimaging data using linear mixed effects models and random field theory.|

column1: |PLS (file format)| |PLS is a computer file format for a multimedia playlist. It was originally developed for use with the museArc audio player software by codeArts
column2: and was later used by SHOUTcast and Icecast for streaming media over the Internet. PLS is a more expressive playlist format than basic M3U
column3: as it can store (cache) information on the song title and length (this is supported in extended M3U only). With PLS version 2
column4: playlists also include a PLS version declaration.|

column1: |PLS Logistics| |PLS Logistics (PLS) is a third-party logistics provider. PLS provides international freight transportation
column2: logistics and technology services. It was founded in 1991 as Pittsburgh Logistics Systems in Rochester
column3: Pennsylvania. The company is headquartered in Cranberry Township
column4: Pennsylvania and is one of the 100 fastest growing Pittsburgh area based companies.PLS is a provider of logistics management
column5: dedicated truckload
column6: LTL
column7: brokerage and technology services for shippers across all industries. It operates a proprietary TMS software named PLS Pro and has been dominant in the industrial sector. It recently signed a cooperative agreement with the Industrial Steel Alliance.As of April 2016
column8: PLS was ranked as the twenty-third-largest freight brokerage firm in North America by Transport Topics magazine.PLS opened its 13th office on February 1
column9: 2016 in Las Vegas
column10: giving the company coverage in all US time zones with more than 700 employees.|

column1: |Software bug| |A software bug is an error
column2: flaw
column3: failure or fault in a computer program or system that causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result
column4: or to behave in unintended ways. Most bugs arise from mistakes and errors made in either a program's source code or its design
column5: or in components and operating systems used by such programs. A few are caused by compilers producing incorrect code. A program that contains a large number of bugs
column6: and/or bugs that seriously interfere with its functionality
column7: is said to be buggy (defective).Bugs trigger errors that may have ripple effects. Bugs may have subtle effects or cause the program to crash or freeze the computer. Others qualify as security bugs and might
column8: for example
column9: enable a malicious user to bypass access controls in order to obtain unauthorized privileges.Bugs in code that controls the Therac-25 radiation therapy machine were directly responsible for patient deaths in the 1980s. In 1996
column10: the European Space Agency's US59 billion annually
column11: or about 0.6 percent of the gross domestic product".|

column2: summary statistics are used to summarize a set of observations
column3: in order to communicate the largest amount of information as simply as possible. Statisticians commonly try to describe the observations ina measure of location
column4: or central tendency
column5: such as the arithmetic meana measure of statistical dispersion like the standard deviationa measure of the shape of the distribution like skewness or kurtosisif more than one variable is measured
column6: a measure of statistical dependence such as a correlation coefficientA common collection of order statistics used as summary statistics are the five-number summary
column7: sometimes extended to a seven-number summary
column8: and the associated box plot.Entries in an analysis of variance table can also be regarded as summary statistics.|

column1: S-PLUS |S-PLUS is a commercial implementation of the S programming language sold by TIBCO Software Inc..It features object-oriented programming capabilities and advanced analytical algorithms.|

column2: the restricted (or residual
column3: or reduced) maximum likelihood (REML) approach is a particular form of maximum likelihood estimation which does not base estimates on a maximum likelihood fit of all the information
column4: but instead uses a likelihood function calculated from a transformed set of data
column5: so that nuisance parameters have no effect.In the case of variance component estimation

column7: and the likelihood function is calculated from the probability distribution of these contrasts
column8: according to the model for the complete data set. In particular
column9: REML is used as a method for fitting linear mixed models. In contrast to the earlier maximum likelihood estimation
column10: REML can produce unbiased estimates of variance and covariance parameters.The idea underlying REML estimation was put forward by M. S. Bartlett in 1937. The first description of the approach applied to estimating components of variance in unbalanced data was by Desmond Patterson and Robin Thompson of the University of Edinburgh in 1971
column11: although they did not use the term REML. A review of the early literature was given by Harville.REML estimation is available in a number of general-purpose statistical software packages
