column1: |Data modeling| |Data modeling in software engineering is the process of creating a data model for an information system by applying formal data modeling techniques.|

column2: a pivot table is a data summarization tool found in data visualization programs such as spreadsheets or business intelligence software. Among other functions
column3: a pivot table can automatically sort
column4: count
column5: total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet
column6: displaying the results in a second table showing the summarized data. Pivot tables are also useful for quickly creating unweighted cross tabulations. The user sets up and changes the summary's structure by dragging and dropping fields graphically. This "rotation" or pivoting of the summary table gives the concept its name.The term pivot table is a generic phrase used by multiple vendors. In the United States
column7: Microsoft Corporation has trademarked the specific compound word form
column8: PivotTable.Pivot tables can be seen as a simplification of the more complete and complex online analytical processing concepts (OLAP).|

column2: such as that described in exact test
column3: is a branch of statistics that was developed to provide more accurate results pertaining to statistical testing and interval estimation by eliminating procedures based on asymptotic and approximate statistical methods. The main characteristic of exact methods is that statistical tests and confidence intervals are based on exact probability statements that are valid for any sample size. Exact statistical methods help avoid some of the unreasonable assumptions of traditional statistical methods
column4: such as the assumption of equal variances in classical ANOVA. They also allow exact inference on variance components of mixed models.When exact p-values and confidence intervals are computed under a certain distribution
column5: such as the normal distribution
column6: then the underlying methods are referred to as exact parametric methods. The exact methods that do not make any distributional assumptions are referred to as exact nonparametric methods. The latter has the advantage of making fewer assumptions whereas
column7: the former tend to yield more powerful tests when the distributional assumption is reasonable. For advanced methods such as higher-way ANOVA regression analysis
column8: and mixed models
column9: only exact parametric methods are available.When the sample size is small
column10: asymptotic results given by some traditional methods may not be valid. In such situations
column11: the asymptotic p-values may differ substantially from the exact p-values. Hence asymptotic and other approximate results may lead to unreliable and misleading conclusions.|

column2: sometimes called the exact mathematical sciences are those sciences "which admit of absolute precision in their results"; especially the mathematical sciences. Examples of the exact sciences are mathematics
column3: optics
column4: astronomy
column5: and physics
column6: which many philosophers from Descartes
column7: Leibniz
column8: and Kant to the logical positivists took as paradigms of rational and objective knowledge. These sciences have been practiced in many cultures from Antiquity to modern times. Given their ties to mathematics
column9: the exact sciences are characterized by accurate quantitative expression
column10: precise predictions and/or rigorous methods of testing hypotheses involving quantifiable predictions and measurements.The distinction between the quantitative exact sciences and those sciences which deal with the causes of things is due to Aristotle
column11: who distinguished mathematics from natural philosophy and considered the exact sciences to be the "more natural of the branches of mathematics." Thomas Aquinas employed this distinction when he pointed out that astronomy explains the spherical shape of the Earth by mathematical reasoning while physics explains it by material causes. This distinction was widely
column12: but not universally
column13: accepted until the Scientific Revolution of the Seventeenth Century. Edward Grant has proposed that a fundamental change leading to the new sciences was the unification of the exact sciences and physics by Kepler
column14: Newton
column15: and others
column16: which resulted in a quantitative investigation of the physical causes of natural phenomena.|

column1: |Probabilistic data association filter| |The probabilistic data association filter (PDAF) is a statistical approach to the problem of plot association in a radar tracker
column2: in which all of the potential candidates for association to a track are combined in a single statistically most probable update
column3: taking account of the statistical distribution of the track errors and clutter and assuming that only one of the candidates is a target
column4: and the rest are false alarms. An extension of the PDAF is the Joint Probabilistic Data Association Filter which takes account of the situation where more than one of the potential candidates represents an actual target.|

column2: a Markov model is a stochastic model used to model randomly changing systems where it is assumed that future states depend only on the current state not on the events that occurred before it (that is
column3: it assumes the Markov property). Generally
column4: this assumption enables reasoning and computation with the model that would otherwise be intractable.|

column1: |Multivariate statistics| |Multivariate statistics is a subdivision of statistics encompassing the simultaneous observation and analysis of more than one outcome variable. The application of multivariate statistics is multivariate analysis.Multivariate statistics concerns understanding the different aims and background of each of the different forms of multivariate analysis
column2: and how they relate to each other. The practical implementation of multivariate statistics to a particular problem may involve several types of univariate and multivariate analyses in order to understand the relationships between variables and their relevance to the actual problem being studied.In addition
column3: multivariate statistics is concerned with multivariate probability distributions
column4: in terms of bothhow these can be used to represent the distributions of observed data;how they can be used as part of statistical inference
column5: particularly where several different quantities are of interest to the same analysis.Certain types of problem involving multivariate data
column6: for example simple linear regression and multiple regression
column7: are not usually considered as special cases of multivariate statistics because the analysis is dealt with by considering the (univariate) conditional distribution of a single outcome variable given the other variables.|

column2: a benchmark is the act of running a computer program
column3: a set of programs
column4: or other operations
column5: in order to assess the relative performance of an object
column6: normally by running a number of standard tests and trials against it. The term 'benchmark' is also mostly utilized for the purposes of elaborately designed benchmarking programs themselves.Benchmarking is usually associated with assessing performance characteristics of computer hardware
column7: for example
column8: the floating point operation performance of a CPU
column9: but there are circumstances when the technique is also applicable to software. Software benchmarks are
column10: for example
column11: run against compilers or database management systems.Benchmarks provide a method of comparing the performance of various subsystems across different chip/system architectures.Test suites are a type of system intended to assess the correctness of software.|

column2: scale and shape| |The Generalized Additive Model for Location
column3: Scale and Shape (GAMLSS) is about statistical modelling and learning. GAMLSS is a modern distribution based approach to (semiparametric) regression analysis. A parametric distribution is assumed for the response (target) variable but the parameters of this distribution can vary according to explanatory variables using linear
column4: nonlinear or smooth functions. In data science language GAMLSS is about supervised machine learning.A guiding principle of GAMLSS is how to learn from data generated in many fields. In particular
column5: the GAMLSS statistical framework enables flexible regression and smoothing models to be fitted to the data. The GAMLSS model assumes that the distribution of response variable has any parametric distribution which might be heavy or light-tailed
column6: and positively or negatively skewed. In addition
column7: all the parameters of the distribution [location (e.g.
column8: mean)
column9: scale (e.g.
column10: variance) and shape (skewness and kurtosis)] can be modelled as linear
column11: nonlinear or smooth functions of explanatory variables.The book "Flexible Regression and Smoothing: Using GAMLSS in R" provides an easy and comprehensive introduction to GAMLSS models
column12: which practitioners could refer to
column13: describing the different functionalities of the GAMLSS software.|

column2: an additive model (AM) is a nonparametric regression method. It was suggested by Jerome H. Friedman and Werner Stuetzle (1981) and is an essential part of the ACE algorithm. The AM uses a one-dimensional smoother to build a restricted class of nonparametric regression models. Because of this
column3: it is less affected by the curse of dimensionality than e.g. a p-dimensional smoother. Furthermore
column4: the AM is more flexible than a standard linear model
column5: while being more interpretable than a general regression surface at the cost of approximation errors. Problems with AM include model selection
column6: overfitting
column7: and multicollinearity.|

column2: semiparametric regression includes regression models that combine parametric and nonparametric models. They are often used in situations where the fully nonparametric model may not perform well or when the researcher wants to use a parametric model but the functional form with respect to a subset of the regressors or the density of the errors is not known. Semiparametric regression models are a particular type of semiparametric modelling and
column3: since semiparametric models contain a parametric component
column4: they rely on parametric assumptions and may be misspecified and inconsistent
column5: just like a fully parametric model.|

column1: |Explanatory power| |This article deals with explanatory power in the context of the philosophy of science. For a statistical measure of explanatory power
column2: see Coefficient of determination or Mean squared prediction error.Explanatory power is the ability of a hypothesis or theory to effectively explain the subject matter it pertains to. The opposite of explanatory power is explanatory impotence.In the past
column3: various criteria or measures for explanatory power have been proposed. In particular
column4: one hypothesis
column5: theory or explanation can be said to have more explanatory power than another about the same subject matterif more facts or observations are accounted for;if it changes more "surprising facts" into "a matter of course" (following Peirce);if more details of causal relations are provided
column6: leading to a high accuracy and precision of the description;if it offers greater predictive power
column7: i.e.
column8: if it offers more details about what we should expect to see
column9: and what we should not;if it depends less on authorities and more on observations;if it makes fewer assumptions;if it is more falsifiable
column10: i.e.
column11: more testable by observation or experiment (following Popper).Recently
column12: David Deutsch proposed that the correct hypothesis or theory
column13: the one that stands out among all possible explanations
column14: is that specific explanation thatis hard to vary.By this expression he intends to state that the correct theory
column15: i.e.
column16: the true explanation
column17: provides specific details which fit together so tightly that it is impossible to change any one detail without affecting the whole theory.|

column1: |Cohort study| |A cohort study is a particular form of longitudinal study (panel study) that sample a cohort (a group of people who share a defining characteristic
column2: typically who experienced a common event in a selected period
column3: such as birth or graduation)
column4: performing a cross-section at intervals through time. A cohort study is a panel study
column5: but a panel study is not always a cohort study as individuals in a panel study do not always share a common characteristic.A cohort study is a quasi-experiment used in medicine
column6: nursing
column7: psychology
column8: social science
column9: actuarial science
column10: business analytics
column11: and ecology. For instance in medicine
column12: it is an analysis of risk factors and follows a group of people who do not have the disease
column13: and uses correlations to determine the absolute risk of subject contraction. It is one type of clinical study design and should be compared with a cross-sectional study. Cohort studies are largely about the life histories of segments of populations
column14: and the individual people who constitute these segments.A cohort is a group of people who share a common characteristic or experience within a defined period (e.g.
column15: are currently living
column16: are exposed to a drug or vaccine or pollutant
column17: or undergo a certain medical procedure). Thus a group of people who were born on a day or in a particular period
column18: say 1948
column19: form a birth cohort. The comparison group may be the general population from which the cohort is drawn
column20: or it may be another cohort of persons thought to have had little or no exposure to the substance under investigation
column21: but otherwise similar. Alternatively
column22: subgroups within the cohort may be compared with each other.Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are a superior methodology in the hierarchy of evidence in therapy
column23: because they limit the potential for any biases by randomly assigning one patient pool to an intervention and another patient pool to non-intervention (or placebo). This minimizes the chance that the incidence of confounding (particularly unknown confounding) variables will differ between the two groups. However
column24: it is important to note that RCTs may not be suitable in all cases and other methodologies could be much more suitable to investigate the study's objective(s).Cohort studies can be retrospective (looking back in time
column25: thus using existing data such as medical records or claims database) or prospective (requiring the collection of new data).|

column2: marketing and demography
column3: a cohort is a group of subjects who share a defining characteristic (typically subjects who experienced a common event in a selected time period
column4: such as birth or graduation).Demography often contrasts cohort perspectives and period perspectives. For instance
column5: the total cohort fertility rate is an index of the average completed family size for cohorts of women
column6: but since it can only be known for women who have finished child-bearing
column7: it cannot be measured for currently fertile women. It can be calculated as the sum of the cohort's age-specific fertility rates that obtain as it ages through time. In contrast
column8: the total period fertility rate uses current age-specific fertility rates to calculate the completed family size for a notional woman were she to experience these fertility rates through her life.A study on a cohort is a cohort study.|

column1: |Automatic taxonomy construction| |Automatic taxonomy construction (ATC) is the use of autonomous or semi-autonomous software programs to create hierarchical outlines or taxonomical classifications from a body of texts (corpus). It is a branch of natural language processing
column2: which in turn is a branch of artificial intelligence. ATC programs are examples of software agents and intelligent agents
column3: and may be autonomous as well (see autonomous agent).Other names for ATC include taxonomy generation
column4: taxonomy learning
column5: taxonomy extraction
column6: taxonomy building
column7: and taxonomy induction. Any of these terms may be preceded by the word "automatic"
column8: as in automatic taxonomy induction. ATC is also referred to as semantic taxonomy induction.A taxonomy is a tree structure and includes familial (parent-offspring
column9: sibling
column10: etc.) relationships built-in (like in a family tree). For example
column11: physics is an offspring of physical science
column12: which in turn is an offspring of science.As mentioned above
column13: the process is also called taxonomy induction. This is because
column14: in order for a software program to construct a taxonomy from a corpus (for example
column15: from Wikipedia
column16: a web page
column17: or the World Wide Web)
column18: it must induce which terms belong to the taxonomy and what the relationships between them are. Such as by identifying hyponym-hypernym pairs
column19: among other approaches. This is done using algorithms
column20: including statistical algorithms. Note that deduction (deductive logic) is often also employed (e.g.
column21: if B is a sibling of A
column22: then B has the same parent as A and gets placed under that parent in the taxonomy).The primary application of automatic taxonomy construction is in ontology learning
column23: a central activity within ontology engineering. In computer science and artificial intelligence
column24: an ontology is a conceptual model of a (subject) domain. A domain is a given subject area or specifically defined sphere of interest. An ontology of a domain includes the vocabulary of that domain and the relationships between those concepts or entities. The backbone of most ontologies is a taxonomy
column25: and taxonomical structure may be used throughout an ontology.As building taxonomies manually is extremely labor-intensive and time-consuming
column26: there is great motivation to automate the process.|

column3: and survey methodology
column4: sampling is concerned with the selection of a subset of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population. Each observation measures one or more properties (such as weight
column5: location
column6: color) of observable bodies distinguished as independent objects or individuals. In survey sampling
column7: weights can be applied to the data to adjust for the sample design
column8: particularly stratified sampling. Results from probability theory and statistical theory are employed to guide the practice. In business and medical research
column9: sampling is widely used for gathering information about a population.The sampling process comprises several stages:Defining the population of concernSpecifying a sampling frame
column10: a set of items or events possible to measureSpecifying a sampling method for selecting items or events from the frameDetermining the sample sizeImplementing the sampling planSampling and data collectingData which can be selected|

column1: |Orthogonal array| |Orthogonal array testing is a black box testing technique that is a systematic
column2: statistical way of software testing. It is used when the number of inputs to the system is relatively small
column3: but too large to allow for exhaustive testing of every possible input to the systems. It is particularly effective in finding errors associated with faulty logic within computer software systems. Orthogonal arrays can be applied in user interface testing
column4: system testing
column5: regression testing
column6: configuration testing and performance testing. The permutations of factor levels comprising a single treatment are so chosen that their responses are uncorrelated and therefore each treatment gives a unique piece of information. The net effects of organizing the experiment in such treatments is that the same piece of information is gathered in the minimum number of experiments.|

column2: a moving average (rolling average or running average) is a calculation to analyze data points by creating series of averages of different subsets of the full data set. It is also called a moving mean (MM) or rolling mean and is a type of finite impulse response filter. Variations include: simple
column3: and cumulative
column4: or weighted forms (described below).Given a series of numbers and a fixed subset size
column5: the first element of the moving average is obtained by taking the average of the initial fixed subset of the number series. Then the subset is modified by "shifting forward"; that is
column6: excluding the first number of the series and including the next number following the original subset in the series. This creates a new subset of numbers
column7: which is averaged. This process is repeated over the entire data series. The plot line connecting all the (fixed) averages is the moving average. A moving average is a set of numbers
column8: each of which is the average of the corresponding subset of a larger set of datum points. A moving average may also use unequal weights for each datum value in the subset to emphasize particular values in the subset.A moving average is commonly used with time series data to smooth out short-term fluctuations and highlight longer-term trends or cycles. The threshold between short-term and long-term depends on the application
column9: and the parameters of the moving average will be set accordingly. For example
column10: it is often used in technical analysis of financial data
column11: like stock prices
column12: returns or trading volumes. It is also used in economics to examine gross domestic product
column13: employment or other macroeconomic time series. Mathematically
column14: a moving average is a type of convolution and so it can be viewed as an example of a low-pass filter used in signal processing. When used with non-time series data
column15: a moving average filters higher frequency components without any specific connection to time
column16: although typically some kind of ordering is implied. Viewed simplistically it can be regarded as smoothing the data.|

column2: a partial regression plot attempts to show the effect of adding another variable to a model already having one or more independent variables. Partial regression plots are also referred to as added variable plots
column3: adjusted variable plots
column4: and individual coefficient plots.When performing a linear regression with a single independent variable
column5: a scatter plot of the response variable against the independent variable provides a good indication of the nature of the relationship. If there is more than one independent variable
column6: things become more complicated. Although it can still be useful to generate scatter plots of the response variable against each of the independent variables
column7: this does not take into account the effect of the other independent variables in the model.|

column2: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods are a class of algorithms for sampling from a probability distribution based on constructing a Markov chain that has the desired distribution of its equilibrium distribution. The state of the chain after a number of steps is then used as a sample of the desired distribution. The quality of the sample improves as a function of the number of steps.Random walk Monte Carlo methods make up a large subclass of MCMC methods.|

the bias (or bias function) of an estimator is the difference between this estimator's expected value and the true value of the parameter being estimated. An estimator or decision rule with zero bias is called unbiased. Otherwise the estimator is said to be biased. In statistics
column3: "bias" is an objective statement about a function
column4: and while not a desired property
column5: it is not pejorative
column6: unlike the ordinary English use of the term "bias".Bias can also be measured with respect to the median
column7: rather than the mean (expected value)
column8: in which case one distinguishes median-unbiased from the usual mean-unbiasedness property. Bias is related to consistency in that consistent estimators are convergent and asymptotically unbiased (hence converge to the correct value)
column9: though individual estimators in a consistent sequence may be biased (so long as the bias converges to zero); see bias versus consistency.All else equal
column10: an unbiased estimator is preferable to a biased estimator
column11: but in practice all else is not equal
column12: and biased estimators are frequently used
column13: generally with small bias. When a biased estimator is used
column14: the bias is also estimated. A biased estimator may be used for various reasons: because an unbiased estimator does not exist without further assumptions about a population or is difficult to compute (as in unbiased estimation of standard deviation); because an estimator is median-unbiased but not mean-unbiased (or the reverse); because a biased estimator reduces some loss function (particularly mean squared error) compared with unbiased estimators (notably in shrinkage estimators); or because in some cases being unbiased is too strong a condition
column15: and the only unbiased estimators are not useful. Further
column16: mean-unbiasedness is not preserved under non-linear transformations
column17: though median-unbiasedness is (see effect of transformations); for example
column18: the sample variance is an unbiased estimator for the population variance
column19: but its square root
column20: the sample standard deviation
column21: is a biased estimator for the population standard deviation. These are all illustrated below.|

column1: |Bradley\u2013Terry model| |Numerical weather prediction (NWP) uses mathematical models of the atmosphere and oceans to predict the weather based on current weather conditions. Though first attempted in the 1920s
column2: it was not until the advent of computer simulation in the 1950s that numerical weather predictions produced realistic results. A number of global and regional forecast models are run in different countries worldwide
column3: using current weather observations relayed from radiosondes
column4: weather satellites and other observing systems as inputs.Mathematical models based on the same physical principles can be used to generate either short-term weather forecasts or longer-term climate predictions; the latter are widely applied for understanding and projecting climate change. The improvements made to regional models have allowed for significant improvements in tropical cyclone track and air quality forecasts; however
column5: atmospheric models perform poorly at handling processes that occur in a relatively constricted area
column6: such as wildfires.Manipulating the vast datasets and performing the complex calculations necessary to modern numerical weather prediction requires some of the most powerful supercomputers in the world. Even with the increasing power of supercomputers
column7: the forecast skill of numerical weather models extends to only about six days. Factors affecting the accuracy of numerical predictions include the density and quality of observations used as input to the forecasts
column8: along with deficiencies in the numerical models themselves. Post-processing techniques such as model output statistics (MOS) have been developed to improve the handling of errors in numerical predictions.A more fundamental problem lies in the chaotic nature of the partial differential equations that govern the atmosphere. It is impossible to solve these equations exactly
column9: and small errors grow with time (doubling about every five days). Present understanding is that this chaotic behavior limits accurate forecasts to about 14 days even with perfectly accurate input data and a flawless model. In addition
column10: the partial differential equations used in the model need to be supplemented with parameterizations for solar radiation
column11: moist processes (clouds and precipitation)
column12: heat exchange
column13: soil
column14: vegetation
column15: surface water
column16: and the effects of terrain. In an effort to quantify the large amount of inherent uncertainty remaining in numerical predictions
column17: ensemble forecasts have been used since the 1990s to help gauge the confidence in the forecast
column18: and to obtain useful results farther into the future than otherwise possible. This approach analyzes multiple forecasts created with an individual forecast model or multiple models.|

column1: |Active learning (machine learning)| |Active learning is a special case of semi-supervised machine learning in which a learning algorithm is able to interactively query the user (or some other information source) to obtain the desired outputs at new data points.  In statistics literature it is sometimes also called optimal experimental design. There are situations in which unlabeled data is abundant but manually labeling is expensive. In such a scenario
column2: learning algorithms can actively query the user/teacher for labels. This type of iterative supervised learning is called active learning. Since the learner chooses the examples
column3: the number of examples to learn a concept can often be much lower than the number required in normal supervised learning. With this approach
column4: there is a risk that the algorithm be overwhelmed by uninformative examples. Recent developments are dedicated to hybrid active learning and active learning in a single-pass (on-line) context
column5: combining concepts from the field of Machine Learning (e.g.
column6: conflict and ignorance) with adaptive
column7: incremental learning policies in the field of Online machine learning.|

column2: FRS known as C R Rao (born 10 September 1920) is an Indian-born
column3: naturalized American
column4: mathematician and statistician. He is currently professor emeritus at Penn State University and Research Professor at the University at Buffalo. Rao has been honoured by numerous colloquia
column5: honorary degrees
column6: and festschrifts and was awarded the US National Medal of Science in 2002. The American Statistical Association has described him as "a living legend whose work has influenced not just statistics
column7: but has had far reaching implications for fields as varied as economics
column8: genetics
column9: anthropology
column10: geology
column11: national planning
column12: demography
column13: biometry
column14: and medicine." The Times of India listed Rao as one of the top 10 Indian scientists of all time. Rao is also a Senior Policy and Statistics advisor for the Indian Heart Association non-profit focused on raising South Asian cardiovascular disease awareness.|

column2: a probit model is a type of regression where the dependent variable can only take two values
column3: for example married or not married. The word is a portmanteau
column4: coming from probability + unit. The purpose of the model is to estimate the probability that an observation with particular characteristics will fall into a specific one of the categories; moreover
column5: if estimated probabilities greater than 1/2 are treated as classifying an observation into a predicted category
column6: the probit model is a type of binary classification model.A probit model is a popular specification for an ordinal or a binary response model. As such it treats the same set of problems as does logistic regression using similar techniques. The probit model
column7: which employs a probit link function
column8: is most often estimated using the standard maximum likelihood procedure
column9: such an estimation being called a probit regression.Probit models were introduced by Chester Bliss in 1934; a fast method for computing maximum likelihood estimates for them was proposed by Ronald Fisher as an appendix to Bliss' work in 1935.|

column2: the multivariate probit model is a generalization of the probit model used to estimate several correlated binary outcomes jointly. For example
column3: if it is believed that the decisions of sending at least one child to public school and that of voting in favor of a school budget are correlated (both decisions are binary)
column4: then the multivariate probit model would be appropriate for jointly predicting these two choices on an individual-specific basis.|

column1: |Outline of logic| |The following outline is provided as an overview of and topical guide to logic:Logic is the formal science of using reason and is considered a branch of both philosophy and mathematics. Logic investigates and classifies the structure of statements and arguments
column2: both through the study of formal systems of inference and through the study of arguments in natural language. The scope of logic can therefore be very large
column3: ranging from core topics such as the study of fallacies and paradoxes
column4: to specialized analyses of reasoning such as probability
column5: correct reasoning
column6: and arguments involving causality. One of the aims of logic is to identify the correct (or valid) and incorrect (or fallacious) inferences. Logicians study the criteria for the evaluation of arguments.|

column2: a data sample is a set of data collected and/or selected from a statistical population by a defined procedure. The elements of a sample are known as sample points
column3: sampling units or observations.Typically
column4: the population is very large
column5: making a census or a complete enumeration of all the values in the population is either impractical or impossible. The sample usually represents a subset of manageable size. Samples are collected and statistics are calculated from the samples so that one can make inferences or extrapolations from the sample to the population. The data sample may be drawn from a population without replacement
column6: in which case it is a subset of a population; or with replacement
column7: in which case it is a multisubset.|

|Spatial analysis| |Spatial analysis or spatial statistics includes any of the formal techniques which study entities using their topological
column2: geometric
column3: or geographic properties. Spatial analysis includes a variety of techniques
column4: many still in their early development
column5: using different analytic approaches and applied in fields as diverse as astronomy
column6: with its studies of the placement of galaxies in the cosmos
column7: to chip fabrication engineering
column8: with its use of "place and route" algorithms to build complex wiring structures. In a more restricted sense
column9: spatial analysis is the technique applied to structures at the human scale
column10: most notably in the analysis of geographic data.Complex issues arise in spatial analysis
column11: many of which are neither clearly defined nor completely resolved
column12: but form the basis for current research. The most fundamental of these is the problem of defining the spatial location of the entities being studied.Classification of the techniques of spatial analysis is difficult because of the large number of different fields of research involved
column13: the different fundamental approaches which can be chosen
column14: and the many forms the data can take.|

column1: |Earthquake prediction| |Earthquake prediction is a branch of the science of seismology concerned with the specification of the time
column2: location
column3: and magnitude of future earthquakes within stated limits
column4: and particularly "the determination of parameters for the next strong earthquake to occur in a region. Earthquake prediction is sometimes distinguished from earthquake forecasting
column5: which can be defined as the probabilistic assessment of general earthquake hazard
column6: including the frequency and magnitude of damaging earthquakes in a given area over years or decades. Prediction can be further distinguished from earthquake warning systems
column7: which upon detection of an earthquake
column8: provide a real-time warning of seconds to neighboring regions that might be affected.In the 1970s
column9: scientists were optimistic that a practical method for predicting earthquakes would soon be found
column10: but by the 1990s continuing failure led many to question whether it was even possible. Demonstrably successful predictions of large earthquakes have not occurred and the few claims of success are controversial. Extensive searches have reported many possible earthquake precursors
column11: but
column12: so far
column13: such precursors have not been reliably identified across significant spatial and temporal scales. While part of the scientific community hold that
column14: taking into account non-seismic precursors and given enough resources to study them extensively
column15: prediction might be possible
column16: most scientists are pessimistic and some maintain that earthquake prediction is inherently impossible.|

column1: |Lightning-prediction system| |A lightning prediction system detects atmospheric conditions likely to produce lightning strikes and sounds an alarm
column2: warning those nearby that lightning is imminent and giving them the chance to find safety before the storm arrives in the area. Lightning protection systems are often installed in outdoor areas which are often congested with people
column3: lack sufficient shelter
column4: and are difficult to evacuate quickly (such as water parks
column5: college campuses
column6: and large swimming pool or athletic field complexes). These locations are particularly dangerous during lightning storms. Prediction systems are prone to false alarms as they respond to conditions that are not always attributed to a developing thunderstorm. Electric field data is typically used in conjunction with detection information to limit false positives.|

column1: |Lag windowing| |Lag windowing is a technique that consists of windowing the auto-correlation coefficients prior to estimating Linear prediction coefficients (LPC). The windowing in the auto-correlation domain has the same effect as a convolution (smoothing) in the power spectral domain and helps stabilizing the result of the Levinson-Durbin algorithm. The window function is typically a Gaussian function.|

column2: quality assurance
column3: and survey methodology
column4: sampling is concerned with the selection of a subset of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population. Each observation measures one or more properties (such as weight
column5: location
column6: color) of observable bodies distinguished as independent objects or individuals. In survey sampling
column7: weights can be applied to the data to adjust for the sample design
column8: particularly stratified sampling. Results from probability theory and statistical theory are employed to guide the practice. In business and medical research
column9: sampling is widely used for gathering information about a population.The sampling process comprises several stages:Defining the population of concernSpecifying a sampling frame
column10: a set of items or events possible to measureSpecifying a sampling method for selecting items or events from the frameDetermining the sample sizeImplementing the sampling planSampling and data collectingData which can be selected|

column2: linear regression is an approach for modeling the relationship between a scalar dependent variable y and one or more explanatory variables (or independent variables) denoted X. The case of one explanatory variable is called simple linear regression. For more than one explanatory variable
column3: the process is called multiple linear regression. (This term should be distinguished from multivariate linear regression
column4: where multiple correlated dependent variables are predicted
column5: rather than a single scalar variable.)In linear regression
column6: the relationships are modeled using linear predictor functions whose unknown model parameters are estimated from the data. Such models are called linear models. Most commonly
column7: the conditional mean of y given the value of X is assumed to be an affine function of X; less commonly
column8: the median or some other quantile of the conditional distribution of y given X is expressed as a linear function of X. Like all forms of regression analysis
column9: linear regression focuses on the conditional probability distribution of y given X
column10: rather than on the joint probability distribution of y and X
column11: which is the domain of multivariate analysis.Linear regression was the first type of regression analysis to be studied rigorously
column12: and to be used extensively in practical applications. This is because models which depend linearly on their unknown parameters are easier to fit than models which are non-linearly related to their parameters and because the statistical properties of the resulting estimators are easier to determine.Linear regression has many practical uses. Most applications fall into one of the following two broad categories:If the goal is prediction
column13: or forecasting
column14: or error reduction
column15: linear regression can be used to fit a predictive model to an observed data set of y and X values. After developing such a model
column16: if an additional value of X is then given without its accompanying value of y
column17: the fitted model can be used to make a prediction of the value of y.Given a variable y and a number of variables X1
column19: Xp that may be related to y
column20: linear regression analysis can be applied to quantify the strength of the relationship between y and the Xj
column21: to assess which Xj may have no relationship with y at all
column22: and to identify which subsets of the Xj contain redundant information about y.Linear regression models are often fitted using the least squares approach
column23: but they may also be fitted in other ways
column24: such as by minimizing the "lack of fit" in some other norm (as with least absolute deviations regression)
column25: or by minimizing a penalized version of the least squares loss function as in ridge regression (L2-norm penalty) and lasso (L1-norm penalty). Conversely
column26: the least squares approach can be used to fit models that are not linear models. Thus
column27: although the terms "least squares" and "linear model" are closely linked

column1: |Computational Statistics (journal)| |Computational Statistics is a quarterly peer-reviewed scientific journal that publishes applications and research in the field of computational statistics
column2: as well as reviews of hardware
column3: software
column4: and books. According to the Journal Citation Reports
column5: the journal has a 2012 impact factor of 0.482. It was established in 1986 as Computational Statistics Quarterly and obtained its current title in 1992. The journal is published by Springer Science+Business Media and the editor-in-chief is Yuichi Mori (Okayama University of Science).|

column2: a score function
column3: or scoring rule
column4: measures the accuracy of probabilistic predictions. It is applicable to tasks in which predictions must assign probabilities to a set of mutually exclusive discrete outcomes. The set of possible outcomes can be either binary or categorical in nature
column5: and the probabilities assigned to this set of outcomes must sum to one (where each individual probability is in the range of 0 to 1). A score can be thought of as either a measure of the "calibration" of a set of probabilistic predictions
column6: or as a "cost function" or "loss function".If a cost is levied in proportion to a proper scoring rule
column7: the minimal expected cost corresponds to reporting the true set of probabilities. Proper scoring rules are used in meteorology
column8: finance
column9: and pattern classification where a forecaster or algorithm will attempt to minimize the average score to yield refined
column10: calibrated probabilities (i.e. accurate probabilities). Various scoring rules have also been used to assess the predictive accuracy of forecast models for association football.|

column1: |Convergence in measure| |Convergence in measure is either of two distinct mathematical concepts both of which generalize the concept of convergence in probability.|

column2: deviance is a quality-of-fit statistic for a model that is often used for statistical hypothesis testing. It is a generalization of the idea of using the sum of squares of residuals in ordinary least squares to cases where model-fitting is achieved by maximum likelihood.|
particularly in analysis of variance and linear regression
column3: a contrast is a linear combination of variables (parameters or statistics) whose coefficients add up to zero
column4: allowing comparison of different treatments.|

column1: Self-replication |Self-replication is any behavior of a dynamical system that yields construction of an identical copy of itself. Biological cells
column2: given suitable environments
column3: reproduce by cell division. During cell division
column4: DNA is replicated and can be transmitted to offspring during reproduction. Biological viruses can replicate
column5: but only by commandeering the reproductive machinery of cells through a process of infection. Harmful prion proteins can replicate by converting normal proteins into rogue forms. Computer viruses reproduce using the hardware and software already present on computers. Self-replication in robotics has been an area of research and a subject of interest in science fiction. Any self-replicating mechanism which does not make a perfect copy will experience genetic variation and will create variants of itself. These variants will be subject to natural selection
column6: since some will be better at surviving in their current environment than others and will out-breed them.|

column1: |Fiducial inference| |Fiducial inference is one of a number of different types of statistical inference. These are rules
column2: intended for general application
column3: by which conclusions can be drawn from samples of data. In modern statistical practice
column4: attempts to work with fiducial inference have fallen out of fashion in favour of frequentist inference
column5: Bayesian inference and decision theory. However
column6: fiducial inference is important in the history of statistics since its development led to the parallel development of concepts and tools in theoretical statistics that are widely used. Some current research in statistical methodology is either explicitly linked to fiducial inference or is closely connected to it.|

column2: isotonic regression or monotonic regression is the technique of fitting a free-form line to a sequence of observations under the following constraints: the fitted free-form line has to be non-decreasing everywhere
column3: and it has to lie as close to the observations as possible.|

column2: the continuous uniform distribution or rectangular distribution is a family of symmetric probability distributions such that for each member of the family
column3: all intervals of the same length on the distribution's support are equally probable. The support is defined by the two parameters
column4: a and b
column5: which are its minimum and maximum values. The distribution is often abbreviated U(a
column6: b). It is the maximum entropy probability distribution for a random variate X under no constraint other than that it is contained in the distribution's support.|

column1: |Generalized normal distribution| |The generalized normal distribution or generalized Gaussian distribution (GGD) is either of two families of parametric continuous probability distributions on the real line. Both families add a shape parameter to the normal distribution. To distinguish the two families
column2: they are referred to below as "version 1" and "version 2". However this is not a standard nomenclature.|

the generalized linear model (GLM) is a flexible generalization of ordinary linear regression that allows for response variables that have error distribution models other than a normal distribution. The GLM generalizes linear regression by allowing the linear model to be related to the response variable via a link function and by allowing the magnitude of the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value.Generalized linear models were formulated by John Nelder and Robert Wedderburn as a way of unifying various other statistical models
column3: including linear regression
column4: logistic regression and Poisson regression. They proposed an iteratively reweighted least squares method for maximum likelihood estimation of the model parameters. Maximum-likelihood estimation remains popular and is the default method on many statistical computing packages. Other approaches
column5: including Bayesian approaches and least squares fits to variance stabilized responses
column6: have been developed.|

column2: the class of vector generalized linear models (VGLMs) was proposed to enlarge the scope of models catered for by generalized linear models (GLMs). In particular
column3: VGLMs allow for response variables outside the classical exponential family and for more than one parameter. Each parameter (not necessarily a mean) can be transformed by a link function. The VGLM framework is also large enough to naturally accommodate multiple responses; these are several independent responses each coming from a particular statistical distribution with possibly different parameter values.Vector generalized linear models are described in detail in Yee (2015). The central algorithm adopted is the iteratively reweighted least squares method
column4: for maximum likelihood estimation of usually all the model parameters. In particular
column5: Fisher scoring is implemented by such
column6: which
column7: for most models
column8: uses the first and expected second derivatives of the log-likelihood function.|

column2: the method of contraction hierarchies is a technique to speed up shortest-path routing by first creating precomputed "contracted" versions of the connection graph. It can be regarded as a special case of "highway-node routing".Contraction hierarchies can be used to generate shortest-path routes much more efficiently than Dijkstra's algorithm or previous highway-node routing approaches
column3: and is used in many advanced routing techniques. It is publicly available in open source software to calculate routes from one place to another.|

column1: |Likelihood ratios in diagnostic testing| |In evidence-based medicine
column2: likelihood ratios are used for assessing the value of performing a diagnostic test. They use the sensitivity and specificity of the test to determine whether a test result usefully changes the probability that a condition (such as a disease state) exists. The first description of the use of likelihood ratios for decision rules was made at a symposium on information theory in 1954. In medicine
column3: likelihood ratios were introduced between 1975 and 1980.|

column2: M-estimators are a broad class of estimators
column3: which are obtained as the minima of sums of functions of the data. Least-squares estimators are a special case of M-estimators. The definition of M-estimators was motivated by robust statistics
column4: which contributed new types of M-estimators. The statistical procedure of evaluating an M-estimator on a data set is called M-estimation.More generally
column5: an M-estimator may be defined to be a zero of an estimating function. This estimating function is often the derivative of another statistical function: For example
column6: a maximum-likelihood estimate is often defined to be a zero of the derivative of the likelihood function with respect to the parameter: thus
column7: a maximum-likelihood estimator is often a critical point of the score function. In many applications
column8: such M-estimators can be thought of as estimating characteristics of the population.|

column2: the bias (or bias function) of an estimator is the difference between this estimator's expected value and the true value of the parameter being estimated. An estimator or decision rule with zero bias is called unbiased. Otherwise the estimator is said to be biased. In statistics
column3: "bias" is an objective statement about a function
column4: and while not a desired property
column5: it is not pejorative
column6: unlike the ordinary English use of the term "bias".Bias can also be measured with respect to the median
column7: rather than the mean (expected value)
column8: in which case one distinguishes median-unbiased from the usual mean-unbiasedness property. Bias is related to consistency in that consistent estimators are convergent and asymptotically unbiased (hence converge to the correct value)
column9: though individual estimators in a consistent sequence may be biased (so long as the bias converges to zero); see bias versus consistency.All else equal
column10: an unbiased estimator is preferable to a biased estimator
column11: but in practice all else is not equal
column12: and biased estimators are frequently used
column13: generally with small bias. When a biased estimator is used
column14: the bias is also estimated. A biased estimator may be used for various reasons: because an unbiased estimator does not exist without further assumptions about a population or is difficult to compute (as in unbiased estimation of standard deviation); because an estimator is median-unbiased but not mean-unbiased (or the reverse); because a biased estimator reduces some loss function (particularly mean squared error) compared with unbiased estimators (notably in shrinkage estimators); or because in some cases being unbiased is too strong a condition
column15: and the only unbiased estimators are not useful. Further
column16: mean-unbiasedness is not preserved under non-linear transformations
column17: though median-unbiasedness is (see effect of transformations); for example
column18: the sample variance is an unbiased estimator for the population variance
column19: but its square root
column20: the sample standard deviation
column21: is a biased estimator for the population standard deviation. These are all illustrated below.|

column2: errors-in-variables models or measurement error models are regression models that account for measurement errors in the independent variables. In contrast
column3: standard regression models assume that those regressors have been measured exactly
column4: or observed without error; as such
column5: those models account only for errors in the dependent variables
column6: or responses.In the case when some regressors have been measured with errors
column7: estimation based on the standard assumption leads to inconsistent estimates
column8: meaning that the parameter estimates do not tend to the true values even in very large samples. For simple linear regression the effect is an underestimate of the coefficient
column9: known as the attenuation bias. In non-linear models the direction of the bias is likely to be more complicated.|

column1: Risk |Risk is the potential of gaining or losing something of value. Values (such as physical health
column2: social status
column3: emotional well-being or financial wealth) can be gained or lost when taking risk resulting from a given action or inaction
column4: foreseen or unforeseen. Risk can also be defined as the intentional interaction with uncertainty. Uncertainty is a potential
column5: unpredictable
column6: and uncontrollable outcome; risk is a consequence of action taken in spite of uncertainty.Risk perception is the subjective judgment people make about the severity and probability of a risk
column7: and may vary person to person. Any human endeavor carries some risk
column8: but some are much riskier than others.|

column1: |Risk assessment| |Risk assessment is the determination of quantitative or qualitative estimate of risk related to a well-defined situation and a recognized threat (also called hazard). Quantitative risk assessment requires calculations of two components of risk (R): the magnitude of the potential loss (L)
column2: and the probability (p) that the loss will occur. An acceptable risk is a risk that is understood and tolerated usually because the cost or difficulty of implementing an effective countermeasure for the associated vulnerability exceeds the expectation of loss. "Health risk assessment" includes variations
column3: such as risk as the type and severity of response
column4: with or without a probabilistic context.In all types of engineering of complex systems sophisticated risk assessments are often made within safety engineering and reliability engineering when it concerns threats to life
column5: environment or machine functioning. The nuclear
column6: aerospace
column7: oil
column8: rail and military industries have a long history of dealing with risk assessment. Also
column9: medical
column10: hospital
column11: social service and food industries control risks and perform risk assessments on a continual basis. Methods for assessment of risk may differ between industries and whether it pertains to general financial decisions or environmental
column12: ecological
column13: or public health risk assessment.|

column2: an F-test for the null hypothesis that two normal populations have the same variance is sometimes used
column3: although it needs to be used with caution as it can be sensitive to the assumption that the variables have this distribution.Notionally
column4: any F-test can be regarded as a comparison of two variances
column5: but the specific case being discussed in this article is that of two populations
column6: where the test statistic used is the ratio of two sample variances. This particular situation is of importance in mathematical statistics since it provides a basic exemplar case in which the F-distribution can be derived. For application in applied statistics
column7: there is concern that the test is so sensitive to the assumption of normality that it would be inadvisable to use it as a routine test for the equality of variances. In other words
column8: this is a case where "approximate normality" (which in similar contexts would often be justified using the central limit theorem)
column9: is not good enough to make the test procedure approximately valid to an acceptable degree.|

column1: |Statistical regularity| |Statistical regularity is a notion in statistics and probability theory that random events exhibit regularity when repeated enough times or that enough sufficiently similar random events exhibit regularity. It is an umbrella term that covers the law of large numbers
column2: all central limit theorems and ergodic theorems.If one throws a die once
column3: it is difficult to predict the outcome
column4: but if we repeat this experiment many times
column5: we will see that the number of times each result occurs divided by the number of throws will eventually stabilize towards a specific value.Repeating a series of trials will produce similar
column6: but not identical
column7: results for each series: the average
column8: the standard deviation and other distributional characteristics will be around the same for each series of trials.The notion is used in games of chance
column9: demographic statistics
column10: quality control of a manufacturing process
column11: and in many other parts of our lives.Observations of this phenomenon provided the initial motivation for the concept of what is now known as frequency probability.This phenomenon should not be confused with the Gambler's fallacy
column12: it only concerns regularity in the (possibly very) long run. Gambler's fallacy does not apply to statistical regularity because the latter considers the whole rather than individual cases.|

column1: Randomness |Randomness is the lack of pattern or predictability in events. A random sequence of events
column2: symbols or steps has no order and does not follow an intelligible pattern or combination. Individual random events are by definition unpredictable
column3: but in many cases the frequency of different outcomes over a large number of events (or "trials") is predictable. For example
column4: when throwing two dice
column5: the outcome of any particular roll is unpredictable
column6: but a sum of 7 will occur twice as often as 4. In this view
column7: randomness is a measure of uncertainty of an outcome
column8: rather than haphazardness
column9: and applies to concepts of chance
column10: probability
column11: and information entropy.The fields of mathematics
column12: probability
column13: and statistics use formal definitions of randomness. In statistics
column14: a random variable is an assignment of a numerical value to each possible outcome of an event space. This association facilitates the identification and the calculation of probabilities of the events. Random variables can appear in random sequences. A random process is a sequence of random variables whose outcomes do not follow a deterministic pattern
column15: but follow an evolution described by probability distributions. These and other constructs are extremely useful in probability theory and the various applications of randomness.Randomness is most often used in statistics to signify well-defined statistical properties. Monte Carlo methods
column16: which rely on random input (such as from random number generators or pseudorandom number generators)
column17: are important techniques in science
column18: as
column19: for instance
column20: in computational science. By analogy
column21: quasi-Monte Carlo methods use quasirandom number generators.Random selection is a method of selecting items (often called units) from a population where the probability of choosing a specific item is the proportion of those items in the population. For example
column22: with a bowl containing just 10 red marbles and 90 blue marbles
column23: a random selection mechanism would choose a red marble with probability 1/10. Note that a random selection mechanism that selected 10 marbles from this bowl would not necessarily result in 1 red and 9 blue. In situations where a population consists of items that are distinguishable
column24: a random selection mechanism requires equal probabilities for any item to be chosen. That is
column25: if the selection process is such that each member of a population
column26: of say research subjects
column27: has the same probability of being chosen then we can say the selection process is random.|

column2: given suitable environments
column3: reproduce by cell division. During cell division
column4: DNA is replicated and can be transmitted to offspring during reproduction. Biological viruses can replicate
column5: but only by commandeering the reproductive machinery of cells through a process of infection. Harmful prion proteins can replicate by converting normal proteins into rogue forms. Computer viruses reproduce using the hardware and software already present on computers. Self-replication in robotics has been an area of research and a subject of interest in science fiction. Any self-replicating mechanism which does not make a perfect copy will experience genetic variation and will create variants of itself. These variants will be subject to natural selection
column6: since some will be better at surviving in their current environment than others and will out-breed them.|

column2: the law (or formula) of total probability is a fundamental rule relating marginal probabilities to conditional probabilities. It expresses the total probability of an outcome which can be realized via several distinct events - hence the name.|
deviation is a measure of difference between the observed value of a variable and some other value
column3: often that variable's mean. The sign of the deviation (positive or negative)
column4: reports the direction of that difference (the deviation is positive when the observed value exceeds the reference value). The magnitude of the value indicates the size of the difference.|
